PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Medicare
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows-
That with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Crowley (from 39 citizens), Giles (from 20 citizens) and Reid (from 604 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows-
That, with the exception of the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Non-Government School Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia, being parents and other persons concerned about the education of all children, showeth that the present Government has commenced a policy of reduction and eventual abolition in Government funding to independent schools. This policy has been adopted without an appropriate and reasoned consideration of the circumstances of those schools and the parents who choose to send their children to them. In particular the Government, in making its decision, has failed to take into account the impact on the State school system of an increased enrolment of students who otherwise would have attended independent schools in the event that Government funding had not been reduced or abolished. The change in policy overlooks the fact that the cost of educating a child in a Government school is two to three times the cost to the taxpayer of educating the same child in an independent school.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled reverse the decision of the Government and reinstate funding on an equitable basis as has been the case in previous years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectfully showeth that:
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decisions which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government school costs.
3. They endorse the Federal Government's opposition to the provision of a 'base grant' to all non-government schools.
4. They ask that the Federal Government create a general recurrent resource base which is adequate for government schools through the provision of increased recurrent funding.

5. They call upon the Federal Government to negotiate agreements with State/ Territory Governments which will ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 16 citizens) and Ryan (from 239 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. We deplore the unprincipled and self-interested attacks being orchestrated by minority sects and groups against the policies and person of the Commonwealth Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, the Hon. Senator Susan Ryan.
2. We fully support the Federal Government's actions in reducing funds for the wealthiest private schools, and in breaking the nexus between government and non -government school costs.

3. We endorse the Federal Government's principled opposition to the provision of 'base grants' to all non-government schools, as a positive step towards fulfilling their commitment of primary obligation to Australia's government schools.

4. We call upon the Federal Government however to recognise that its failure to create an adequate general recurrent resource base for government schools through providing increased recurrent grants, will undermine its own special programs and thus frustrate its own stated educational objectives of greater equity and participation.

5. We support the Federal Government's stated policy of entering into direct negotiations for joint agreements on these grants with State/Territory Governments, to ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We fully support the Federal Government's actions in reducing funds for the wealthiest private schools, and in breaking the nexus between government and non -government school costs.

2. We endorse the Federal Government's principled opposition to the provision of 'base grants' to all non-government schools, as a positive step towards fulfilling their commitment of primary obligation to Australia's government schools.

3. We call upon the Federal Government however to recognise that its failure to create an adequate general recurrent resource base for government schools through providing increased recurrent grants, will undermine its own special programs and thus frustrate its own stated educational objectives of greater equity and participation.

4. We support the Federal Government's stated policy of entering into direct negotiations for joint agreements on these grants with State/Territory Governments, to ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every child in Australia is entitled to government financial support for their education whether they attend government schools or non-government schools .

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that urgent consideration be given to a favourable decision for the continuation of Federal Government per capita grants payable in respect of all children in non-government schools at a rate calculated as a percentage of Government standard costs at a level not less than that prevailing in 1983.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that in November 1978 more than sixty-two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to territorial or local government your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action nor legislate in respect of territorial or local government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Marriage
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned citizens of Australia Concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown, Convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and Believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened.
Humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to
1. Reject any moves towards divorce by post
2. Restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or marriage
3. Protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will
4. Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage
5. Encourage counselling towards reconciliation
6. Restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of: i. intolerable behaviour; ii. desertion for two years; iii. separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Sir John Carrick (from 34 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Scheyville Airport, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally importants wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wynyard Airport, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Tasmania shows:
(a) We are shocked and dissappointed at the Federal Government's decision not to upgrade the Wynyard Airport.
(b) This decision will inevitably lead to downgrading and closure of the Wynyard Airport.
(c) Closure of Wynyard Airport will cause grave hardship and inconvenience to the people of the North West and West Coast regions of Tasmania.
(d) We urge the Federal Government to immediately reverse this disastrous decision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights affirms the principle of the inadmissibility of discrimination and proclaims that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights and that everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth therein, without distinction of any kind including distinction based on sex.

However extensive discrimination against women continues to exist. It is an obstacle to the participation of women on equal terms with men, in the political , social, economic and cultural life of this country. It hampers the growth of the prosperity of society and the family and makes more difficult the full development of the potentialities of women in the service of this country and of humanity.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will act to ratify the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against Women.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Post-School Education Sector
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the post-school education sector has been neglected in recent years .
Therefore we call on the members of the Senate to endorse:
(1) Increases in TEAS to at least the level of the poverty line. All people should be guaranteed a living wage.
(2) Increased funding for campus based childcare.
(3) The abolition of the overseas student visa charge, which is grossly discriminatory.
(4) Increased funding for student housing.
(5) Increased funding for libraries to ensure facilities are adequate.
(6) The establishment or supplementation of campus based student loan funds which are interest free and short-term.
(7) Increasing the level and number of postgraduate awards.
(8) Extending services to part-time, mature age and external students to open access to education.
(9) Increasing student representation at all levels.
(10) Innovation in curriculum to ensure curriculum is relevant and critical.
(11) Increasing education funding to improve existing facilities.
(12) Funding quality student health services which help contribute to the successful completion of courses.
(13) Expanding enrolments to open access to education.
(14) Compensating institutions for the costs of amalgamation.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will support the above claims.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Women continue to suffer discrimination in many areas of employment. In traditional 'male' industries such as steel, the denial of equal rights and opportunities has resulted in disproportionate numbers of women being hired and fired.

We therefore humbly request that the government of the Commonwealth of Australia introduce, extend and implement anti-discrimination legislation which includes affirmative action policies to effectively remedy this injustice.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth.
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms.
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action hospitals, doctors and nurses who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations.
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school 'community' provide an environment conducive to the development, including the moral development of their children.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of the principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to undermine civil liberties and religious freedom.
It could also be a means of undermining the traditional family structure of our nation.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should delay the Bill and ask that the Government set up a joint Parliamentary Committee to examine:
(a) the implications of the U.N. Covenant for public policy, the extent of Australian commitments, responsibilities and accountability in terms of the Covenant;
(b) the full effects of the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 for public policy in giving effect to the U.N. Covention.
The Terms of Reference of the Joint Parliamentary Committee to be widely publicised and oral and written submissions sought from the interested organisations and individuals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Force Reserve
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned citizens of Australia are concerned at the termination of the tax exemption on Defence Force Reserve pay. We are convinced that unequal relativities in pay will occur and the Reserve Force will lose a large number of dedicated training servicemen and women which will make it impossible for the Reserve to meet its commitments to the defence of Australia.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will act to form a Senate Select Committee to inquire into and report on the effect of the removal of the tax exemption prior to the implementation of Government policy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: ALLIED NAVAL UNITS: ACCESS TO PORTS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Durack proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for a clear policy statement on access to Australian port facilities by allied naval units in light of the misunderstanding, confusion and ambiguity caused by the Government's handling of the visit by HMS Invincible.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —There could be no more important subject for this Parliament than that of the defence of the nation, and there is certainly no more important issue in regard to the defence of Australia than the state of our alliances and the attitude of our allies to the defence of Australia and to Australia's support and responsibility in relation to our defence arrangements and our treaty arrangements, particularly under the ANZUS treaty with the United States but also the traditional arrangements that we have had with Britain. That is why the Opposition this morning has brought forward as a matter of public importance, indeed as a matter of urgency, the need for a clear policy statement on access to Australian port facilities by allied warships in the light of the misunderstanding, confusion and ambiguity caused by the Government's handling of the visit by HMS Invincible. Those words ' misunderstanding, confusion and ambiguity' are not my choice of words; they are the words used by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) when interviewed on Tuesday morning as he came into Parliament House. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Americans will be sending their local representatives into the Foreign Affairs Department this morning so that any misunderstanding, confusion, ambiguity can be got out of the way fairly quickly.

Later in that interview he said that the Americans believed that the uncertainty was unjustified and that the Government was in the process of resolving it or eliminating it in the course of the next few hours. He said that at 8.45 a.m. last Tuesday. It is now 48 hours later, two days later, and still confusion, ambiguity and misunderstanding reign supreme. That is why the Opposition believes it must be cleared up quickly without further delay.

The sorry episode-indeed, this deeply serious episode-has arisen from the way in which the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) in particular has handled this matter. I accuse the Government as a whole and other Ministers as well as the Minister for Defence of mishandling this visit by the HMS Invincible to Australia. No wonder there has been such misunderstanding and confusion. That confusion has been caused by the incompetence of the Minister for Defence in particular. The Invincible was clearly coming to Australia-it cut short its visit to New Zealand to come to Sydney-because it was in need of repairs to a propeller shaft. Clearly that visit was being received by Australia for that purpose. Mr Scholes, on the AM program the other day, said that there had been constant discussion with officials of the Department of Defence and the Royal Australian Navy in relation to these matters. We know now, of course, that the Garden Island dockyard has incurred expenditure in anticipation of the dry docking of the HMS Invincible for these repairs. It was quite clear that the Invincible expected to be able to use this facility in Australia as needed. Yet something very serious went wrong. We are entitled to know what went wrong. We have not been told by the Government what went wrong. No clear statement has been made about the circumstances of this matter at any stage by the Minister for Defence or, indeed, by any other Minister. Not only has no clear statement been made to us but also it appears that no clear statement has been made to the British. Even now, despite the great problem which has arisen with our allies, no clear statement has yet been made to the Americans and certainly no clear statement has been made to this Parliament and to the people of Australia in relation to this very serious matter. Let us examine again what Mr Scholes has said and what he has not said. First of all, having admitted that there had been discussions, the other morning he went on to say:
. . . the British Government advised us that it would not be taking up the offer of docking in Sydney.

Apparently he did not intend to use the word 'offer', although he does not deny that he used it. Clearly an indication, if not an offer, was available. The Attorney-General suggested yesterday that the Minister meant to say 'option'. How could the British have an option of taking up these facilities unless some clear indication had been given to them that the facilities would be available? Certainly there had to be discussions. Certainly arrangements had to be made. A whole lot of matters would have had to be discussed and determined. Clearly the facilities were made available to the British. They had an option, an offer or whatever. At a very late stage the arrangements went wrong, which necessitated the British High Commissioner seeing Mr Scholes. We still do not know clearly what happened at those discussions between the British High Commissioner and the Minister for Defence, Mr Scholes, except that as a result the British stated-as they put it, being as diplomatic as they could be, to save embarrassment for the Australian Government-that they would not make a request for docking facilities, for operational reasons. But again we know from a statement by Mr Scholes on the AM program on Tuesday morning that in the course of his discussion with the British High Commissioner he said:
I set out what were the Government's requirements, the Government's long standing policies.

In answer to questions in the House of Representatives last week it appears that Mr Scholes indicated that he saw those policies as not permitting nuclear weapons on Australian soil and that he saw dry docking of the vessel as tantamount to breaching that policy. Nevertheless, the Minister still refuses to admit that that was the case. Yet, of course, it must be assumed that that is the case from what he has said in various other places at other times. So we have a situation in which the Government knows and accepts the policies of our nuclear power allies, Britain and America, of never to confirm or deny that their ships are carrying nuclear weapons. The Attorney-General has acknowledged that the Government understands and accepts that policy. Knowing that policy, the Minister must have known that problems would undoubtedly arise if he insisted on explaining the Government's policy in the terms in which he put it to the House of Representatives. Yet no proper attempt was made, as far as we can see, to resolve those problems at the time.

Some further weak excuse was given to us by the Ministers concerned that a problem would be that the vessel would have to be disarmed-we know now that that was not the proper term, but that is by the way-that the ship had to be de- ammunitioned. But now it is conceded that for the particular repairs to HMS Invincible-they were not major or difficult repairs involving any greater length of time than a few days in dry dock-such action to de-ammunition the ship was not necessary. Senator Hamer made that clear yesterday from his knowledge of these matters. It is not part of policy that a ship has to be de-ammunitioned in those circumstances.

Utter confusion, uncertainty and very serious disruption to our allies has been caused by the incompetence of the Minister for Defence. But it does not rest there. It was clear from last week that the problem was facing the Government. The Government allowed the confusion to become even deeper by the way the Minister for Defence answered questions in the House of Representatives. After last Thursday's questioning in the House of Representatives there was no way in the world that anybody could understand what the Minister for Defence had said, what he was doing, what our policies were, what the particular problems were or why this docking did not proceed. It was no wonder in those circumstances that not only were the British embarrassed but also, even importantly, our American allies were deeply worried and confused.

That situation was brought to the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs or his Department last weekend on the initiative of the United States of America Department of State and resulted in a call by the United States of America Charge d'Affaires on our Department of Foreign Affairs last weekend. Even so, last Tuesday morning the Minister for Foreign Affairs said:
There is no confusion in our minds. There does not seem to be any confusion in the American minds.

As I said, he was making out last Tuesday morning that it would all be cleared up within a few hours. The matter was serious enough for Mr Hayden to ring Secretary of State George Shultz in Madrid using a facility which we are fortunate to have but which should be resorted to only if there were serious misunderstanding. It was quite clear that the Americans were worried. George Shultz said that the matter had to be nipped in the bud there and then. Yet, confusion and ambiguity still reign. It does not appear that it will be resolved in the simple way that Mr Hayden or the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) would have us believe it could be solved when he answered a question in this chamber last Tuesday.

It is now clear from yesterday's statement by the Attorney-General on behalf of the Ministers that the matter will continue to cause problems. He said that the matter was discussed in Cabinet yesterday and that it would be the subject of further consideration in Cabinet. He said that the matter would be the subject of quite detailed consultations with our allies in the period immediately ahead. He referred to some manifest difficulties and obscurities in the situation and in the application of what is said to be the Government's policies.

I find it very difficult to understand why there are any difficulties or ambiguities about the Government's policies in providing facilities for ships of our allies when they visit Australia such as those required by the Invincible on this occasion. Last year, Mr Hayden, when he was Leader of the Opposition, had his famous meeting with the Assistant Secretary of State who came to Australia because of the deep concern of our American allies over the attitude of the then Opposition. This attitude was expressed by Mr Hayden, Mr Cain and others in relation to the visits of nuclear armed and powered ships. Of course, Mr Hayden backed down on behalf of the Opposition and accepted that the Opposition's policy would be to accept visits by nuclear armed warships otherwise the ANZUS alliance would be effectively demolished. Mr Hayden said:
Nothing I have said here would prevent the use of our ports for maintenance, essential repairs or refits, regular rest and recreation for crews and ships of allies or treaty partners.

It seems to be clear from the Australian Labor Party's policy enunciated over a year ago by the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, that there should be no problem or confusion in relation to the relatively minor repairs that the Invincible required. If there is to be confusion, doubt, misunderstanding and ambiguity about the availability of such facilities and such repairs as were required by the Invincible, of course the visits to Australia by warships of our nuclear allies will be thrown into real doubt and confusion. If the application of what seems to be a perfectly simple policy cannot be resolved very quickly and very clearly in a situation like this, there is a serious problem indeed in relation to the ANZUS alliance. That is the problem we are facing. As I said, the matter has gone on for several days. Consultations are still going on. The matter has been the subject of discussion in Cabinet. The Australian Government, by its failure to make perfectly clear what its policy is and by its failure to make perfectly clear what the application of it is in a relatively simple situation such as the one we have had with the Invincible, has not only, as I have said, embarrassed our British allies but also confused and deeply worried our American allies. It is of the utmost urgency and importance that the Government make clear and make public to our allies, to this Parliament and to Australia just what our policies are and how they will be applied in a situation of this kind. It is absolutely vital that that be done quickly and clearly. It must be made perfectly clear that in cases in the future similar to that of the Invincible Australian repair facilities will be available without doubt, without confusion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, there is no confusion in the Government's mind as to the matters raised in the matter of public importance brought on by Senator Durack, nor is there any confusion in the minds of our allies as a result of the discussions which have taken place around these matters in recent days. However, to the extent that there is any lingering uncertainty in the public mind because of our natural concern not to make public matters of sensitivity and ongoing consultation internationally, I do acknowledge on behalf of the Government that there is a need now to give a clearer statement of the whole position and the course of events leading up to it than it has been possible to give so far. I will now endeavour to proceed to do so in as succinct a fashion as I can.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me begin with the basic policy situation. There are a number of different strands in that policy situation, some of which are better developed than others , as I will explain. The first strand of relevant policy here is the proposition that the Australian Government will not allow nuclear arms on Australian soil. That proposition has been enunciated with vigour and clarity by the present Government, both before the last election and certainly during our term of office. It is also, of course, consistent with the policy adopted by our predecessors, the Liberal-National Party Government, at least so far as the B52 bomber issue was concerned.

The second strand of relevant policy relates to the visits of nuclear powered ships to Australian ports. Again here, a clear bipartisan approach-perhaps even clearer than in the case of nuclear arms on Australian soil-has evolved over time and there is no question of that bipartisan approach being in any way at risk. The situation here is that nuclear powered vessels will be allowed to visit Australia subject to certan guidelines. Those guidelines were first laid down after some considerable period of discussion and negotiation by the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, in the House of Representatives on 4 June 1976. They have subsequently been slightly modified to take account of later developments including, in particular, the controversy around the proposed visit of a nuclear warship to Victoria in 1982. As they now stand, with only very minor modifications to the original 1976 statement, they are as follows:
(a) Visits will be for purposes such as crew rest and recreation and not for fuel handling or repair to reactor plant necessitating breach of reactor containment;

(b) Visits will be subject to satisfactory arrangements concerning liability and indemnity and to provision of adequate assurances relating to the operation and safety of the warships while they are in Australian waters;
(c) Movement of vessels must take place during daylight hours under conditions where visibility is not less than three quarters of a mile;
(d) Navigational controls on other shipping will be applied during the time that nuclear powered ships are entering or leaving ports;

(e) There must be a capability to remove the vessel either under its own power or under tow to a designated safe anchorage or to a designated distance to sea within the time frame specified for the particular berth or anchorage and in any case within 24 hours, if an accident should occur; and

(f) An operating safety organisation competent to carry out a suitable radiation monitoring program and able to initiate actions and provide services necessary to safeguard the public in the event of a release of radioactivity following an accident must exist for the port being visited.
There is no ambiguity or uncertainty about that particular policy statement, nor any disposition on the part of the Government to review or modify it in any way.

The third strand in the relevant policy relates to the visits of nuclear armed ships, or ships which may be nuclear armed, to Australian ports. Again, there is a long-standing bipartisan policy initiated by the previous Government and continued by the present Labor Government that we do not ask our allies either to confirm or deny whether nuclear weapons are being carried.

The fourth element in the policy network that relates to this issue concerns dry docking of ships armed with conventional weapons. Again, there has been a clear policy in existence for a long period which the present Government inherited from its predecessors. The essence of that policy is that naval ships armed with conventional weapons going into dry dock are to be required to de- ammunition or disarm in the sense in which we discussed it yesterday, subject, however, to waiver or exemption-partially or wholly-depending on the circumstances of the individual case. So much is clear. But as a matter of general statement, how that particular policy is to be applied in a particular case will depend on all the circumstances of the particular case.

The next element that comes into the policy equation, however, concerns the dry docking of naval ships armed with non-conventional weapons, or ships which may or may not be armed with non-conventional weapons. The difficulty is that there is simply no established policy in place in this respect. To the extent that there has been a clear policy about dry docking naval ships, that policy was formulated in the context of conventional weapons and it is the case that attention has simply never been addressed previously to what the situation is or ought to be in relation to ships which may be armed with non-conventional weapons, and how that particular aspect of the policy is to be integrated or interrelated with the previous matters that I have mentioned, about no nuclear arms on Australian soil, and about the rules governing nuclear armed ships visiting Australian ports, namely, that we do not ask our allies to confirm or deny. Clearly, a different situation arises with non-conventional weapons than arises with respect to conventional weapons. What needs to be done is to establish guidelines to ensure that urgent needs can be accommodated, and the policy is clearly very much in need of review and development in this particular area.

The final policy strand that is relevant and which can be stated as a policy of general application which would, I believe, command ready bipartisan support- although I do not believe that it has been articulated so clearly in the past- concerns the weight to be given to safety considerations when it comes to dry docking or otherwise harbouring warships visiting Australian ports. We have not, as I understand it, clearly articulated guidelines to deal with this in the past . But as the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) has said, and as I have said, representing him in this place, there is no question but that Australia would not in any way endanger the safety of any ship or crew by not accommodating genuine needs that that ship or crew had. What, of course, will constitute a danger to the safety of the ship or its crew will vary quite considerably according to particular circumstances, not least whether the nation is at peace or at war. If the particular disability being experienced by the ship is a breakdown in one of its engines, which means that it cannot cruise or steam at its otherwise maximum speed, that may be of no particular significance at all in a peace time environment but manifestly of very great significance in a war time environment.

Clearly guidelines of a fairly specific kind need to be developed in this particular area, again involving the interrelationship of these considerations with all the other policy considerations that I have mentioned. In that respect again the overall policy is manifestly in need of review and development. So to clarify it to the extent that I have not already, when I said yesterday on behalf of the Minister for Defence that a review was contemplated of our policy with respect to the visits of nuclear warships, I was not to be taken as contemplating in any sense that there would be a full review of all the different policy areas that I have now outlined, or that in any way most of those policy areas were in some way at risk. It is only to be understood that a review is necessary in the limited context that I have specifically outlined where it is the case that policy simply has not been clearly formulated in the past and it simply has not been thought through as to how some of the principles of general application are to be applied to the circumstances of particular cases. There is a need for quite a lot of work to be done to develop guidelines for the application of those general principles to particular practical situations.

So much for general policy considerations. Let me turn to the particular sequence of events so far as HMS Invincible itself is concerned. It is not possible to be quite as forthcoming as I might wish in giving the full details of discussions that proceeded in relation to this because of the international considerations and Defence policy considerations that are involved. But I think it can be quite succinctly stated what the main events were in the order in which they occurred, and hopefully this will put some of this into perhaps clearer context than it has been up to this point. The situation was this: Before the ship arrived a week ago discussions did take place at both a Service and departmental officer level with respect to the possibility of HMS Invincible being dry docked in Australia. The second thing that occurred was that, arising out of those discussions certain preparations did commence at Garden Island in anticipation that the British Navy might want to use the dry dock facility there . Work that was being done on HMAS Adelaide, which was at that point in dry dock , was rapidly completed and that ship was moved out. That did occupy some workmen in overtime that would not otherwise have been incurred. As we understand it, the overall cost that was associated with those preparations was of the order of $30,000-no more. The third thing that occurred was that on 29 November the Defence Minister, Mr Scholes, had discussions with the United Kingdom High Commissioner, Mr Mason, in the course of which a variety of--

TALK.START.PARA: —Sir John Mason.

—Sir John Mason. I am indebted to his brother in law in this place for correcting the record in that respect. Discussions were held as to the options and possibilities of the Invincible dry docking, given the policies of the Australian Government, to the extent that they have been developed in this area, concerning disarming, de-ammunitioning and all the other interrelated factors that I have mentioned.

SPEECH.PARA: The fourth thing that occurred was that following those discussions within, I gather, quite a short time thereafter the British Government advised the Australian Government that for operational reasons it would not require to use the Australian dockyard. That is all there was to it so far as the basic course of events with Invincible was concerned. As I understand it, nothing in the nature of any formal request was made; certainly no request was denied by the Australian Government. It was a matter of preliminary discussions at which the various options and possibilities and policy implications were canvassed, following which discussions the British Government advised the Australian Government, I repeat, that for operational reasons it would not require to use the dockyard in question.

Finally, may I say something about the other policy and political aspects of this affair and what lies ahead so far as future policy developments are concerned. Let me again make a succinct series of points here. First, it was appreciated right from the outset, as soon as the issue of the Invincible possibly wanting to dock was raised, that there would need to be clarification and a development of Australian policy to cope with this situation, which had not previously arisen. Preliminary discussions were undertaken within the Government at departmental level to begin the process of shaping up appropriate lines of policy to deal with this kind of situation. What happened was that then the matter became a matter of public controversy, largely fuelled by the Opposition and various statements by Mr Sinclair and others to the effect that Australia was actually banning the docking of the Invincible. Those newspaper reports, fuelled as they were by what I might say with all due respect to those concerned were some rather irresponsible statements, did provoke some reaction from the United States, initially at an officer or an official level rather at a high political level.

Following that reaction from the United States-again some account of it found its way into the Press-there was the exchange between Mr Hayden and Mr Shultz, the United States Secretary of State, the substance of which discussion I retailed in this place in Question Time a couple of days ago. That discussion was essentially a very relaxed one. It was made clear by Mr Shultz that there was no particular concern being expressed by the United States-just a desire for some clarification. In particular, there was no question of the ANZUS relationship being in any way put at risk by the particular matters in issue. Subsequently-yesterday, in fact-Cabinet discussed the whole question at some length in circumstances which I am not, of course, at liberty to here retail, but arising out of which a number of what I described yesterday as discussion points were formulated around which consultations might then continue with our allies in order to shape up an appropriate set of clear guidelines for the application of policy in the future.

Further to that Cabinet decision yesterday and the formulation of those discussion points, discussions took place last night between Mr Scholes, the Minister for Defence, and his counterpart in Britain Mr Heseltine, and in the United States, Mr Weinberger, around the particular issues of what guidelines needed to be developed to deal with these sorts of situations should they arise in the future. My information and advice is that those discussions were again relaxed and amicable, that they were simply designed to contribute to a situation where in due course we would have in place clear, understandable guidelines for the application in practice of those basic principles of Australian policy which remain quite secure. Those discussions at a ministerial level are to be followed by more detailed discussions now at an official level. No time frame has yet been set for those discussions but it would be realistic to anticipate that we are talking here about a matter of months rather than days or merely weeks.

Might I say in conclusion that what may have been at one stage, as Mr Hayden said and as he was quoted by Senator Durack, a situation of some misunderstanding, confusion and ambiguity in various people's minds has in the last few days been very much resolved. Delicate and sensitive matters of defence and international relations are here involved and it simply was not possible to clear the air publicly in every respect although at a very early stage the diplomatic air was, I assure honourable senators, well and truly cleared. I hope that in what I have said today on behalf of the Government I have now put on the public record, as requested by Senator Durack-not unreasonably-a clear and unambiguous statement of what the basic policy issues are and to the extent that further matters remain to be resolved in relation to those policy issues I have identified what those matters are and where the discussions are now proceeding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already heard enough in this debate to convince me that it is indeed a matter of public importance which, for a variety of reasons, cries out to be resolved. That is dependent to a large extent on what I have not heard in the debate so far as well as what I have actually heard. Also, the Australian Democrats believe that this problem will not be resolved quickly or easily. It will not be resolved just by talk. Some action, much of it likely to be unwelcome to some people, is also required. There has also been a lot of quite unwarranted hysteria and politicking over the issue which, I suppose, is to be expected but it certainly does not help.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very important issue, involving as it does a careful reasonable compromise between two major objectives. The first objective, and it must be the one of overriding importance, is the safety of our cities and people. That is, or should be, the paramount issue for all of us in this place without any qualification whatsoever. We are Australian members of parliament and our first duty is to Australia and the Australian people. The second major point is that due to inept defence policies in the past we still depend on our more powerful allies substantially and would have to depend on them in time of major war. We have an historic association with them and they have a right to expect some kind of assistance from us especially in time of need. That time of need must include an allied ship in urgent need of a haven, assistance or repairs in time of war. When we look at the matter in that way the problem becomes clearer. Can we do both these things? Can we help our allies in all those circumstances and, at the same time, provide our own people with the maximum degree of security which they have a right to expect from us as members of parliament?

Before I go on I will make a preparatory comment to try to place us in a world frame, which has not yet been done by any speaker in this debate. Are we alone in Australia in our concern about having nuclear powered or armed ships in our ports? The answer, of course, is no. The Australian Democrats are greatly indebted to material which was cabled to us this morning from the Centre for Defense Information in Washington. It is a highly reputable organisation, well known and respected, under the directorship of retired United States Admiral Gene Laroque. The information which I will quote comes from that institute. It states:
Nuclear Powered ships--

Port visit for nuclear powered warships are cleared by the United States Government on a case by case basis. Some ports, such as the home port for nuclear squadrons have a permanent clearance for routine entrance and exit. All criteria for granting clearance for other ports are not specified, but such factors as population density-
I stress that-
and harbor characteristics, (tide, depth etc), are taken into consideration along with potential accidents. Using these criteria-
I take it that busy ports, on those criteria, are usually avoided-
the United States Navy has never requested visits to New York or Boston and those cities have never been visited by nuclear powered ships.
I will repeat that sentence because I think it is of basic importance, coming from the absolutely reputable authority from which it comes. It states:
the United States Navy has never requested visits to New York or Boston and those cities have never been visited by nuclear powered ships.
The obvious reason, of course, being the criterion of population density. The information continues:
For foreign port clearance, the US uses the same criteria as for domestic ports .

I would have thought that would mean that the United States would apply to Sydney the same standards it would apply to Boston or New York, including population density and busyness of the harbour area. The information continues:
US Government provided host government with 'standard statement' that visit safety is guaranteed and the US accepts some liability in the event of a nuclear reactor accident.
Again I stress for the sake of the record the word 'some'. It is a qualified degree of responsibility. The information continues:
No other clarification is presented. Request to visit certain foreign ports are not initiated because of this criteria. France and Spain will not allow visit by US nuclear powered ships.

Nuclear weapons policy is controlled by different criteria. To the best of our knowledge the US Government does not prevent court visits when nuclear weapons are on board. Standard US policy is always to neither 'confirm or deny' the presence of nuclear weapons anywhere. Agreement between US and foreign governments may affect this policy. The US has tacitly agreed to respect the Japanese principles, i.e. no possession, no manufacture, no introduction of nuclear weapons. India has consistently refused to accept the US policy to neither 'confirm or deny'. And for this reason US warships do not visit Indian ports. Approximately 80 percent of all US warships carry nuclear weapons.
I stress that point again because this information has come from a highly informed source. Finally it says:
It is the right of a sovereign nation to judge and decide whether foreign warships should be accorded access to that nations ports'.

I will speak on the final point because I think it is one of fairly considerable importance. I must say something that I think has not yet been said by anybody, that is, that we are a sovereign nation and we are a free people. It is our right and our duty to decide for ourselves what actions we take in this matter. It is not for us to spring to attention and automatically defer to anything required of us by any foreign power no matter how friendly we are with it. If we surrender that ground we forfeit the right to any self-respect or, for that matter, any respect from anyone else. We truly would have reached a poor white trash mentality. I am somewhat concerned about the extent to which Senator Durack, speaking for the Liberal Party of Australia, has approached that point of view. I ask him to remember please that he is an Australian and an Australian senator. If he wants to be a United States senator maybe he would like to go to America somewhere and put himself up for election. That is not an anti-American statement; it is merely a statement that we in this country must resolve this problem ourselves. We are not susceptible to pressure or suggestions from overseas on this matter. Certainly from the point of view of the Australian Democrats, those suggestions and pressures are unwelcome. I suggest the problem will be solved much more easily and much better if we are left to decide it for ourselves.

The key to the problem of HMS Invincible is the location of our major naval bases. I made this point yesterday and I will make it again today. The difficulty was that HMS Invincible went into Garden Island. What is Garden Island? Garden Island is a naval base which has been there for a long time and which has continued to exist only because it has always been there-for no other reason whatsoever-right in the middle of Sydney, a quarter of a mile from the Sydney Opera House. It is located bizarrely and inappropriately in one of the world's densest population areas and certainly in Australia's densest population areas. The area of threat around it, if it were ever attacked, would involve death or injury to something like a quarter of Australia's population. It is intolerable that it should continue to exist in its present location.

What is the attitude of the previous Government and this Government on the matter? It is to devote huge sums of money, many millions of dollars, to extend Garden Island. In other words, the Government wants to extend the threat to the people of Sydney. Is the Government looking at this matter responsibly? Is it providing a civil defence program along the lines of the Swiss program for the people of Sydney to balance this out? No, it is providing absolutely nothing in the way of civil defence for our people. In 1962 the people of Switzerland-I might say using a citizen initiated referendum-decided, independently of their government, that a quarter of their defence budget was to go to providing proper civil defence for themselves. As a result of that they are one of the best prepared people in the world. Australia does not do that. We sit here and play around with this issue, pit-pat it around as Senator Durack and the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) have done, ignoring these aspects. They say: 'We will decide whether we will allow nuclear weapons to sit regularly in the centre of one of our major areas of population and still we will do nothing for those people. But we have provided a funk hole for ourselves in the basement of the new and permanent Parliament House where we will creep and retreat in time of war'. I will quote briefly from Jim Falk's excellent Penguin book recently published called Taking Australia off the Map, which I urge all Australians who have a sense of responsibility for their own future and that of their families to read. It describes the zones of destruction of a one-megatonne bomb exploded in Sydney. This is the case I want to consider at the moment, because it is possible and quite likely that weapons on board visiting naval ships would be of that nature. It states:
Within Inner Circle 5 km Total Devastation (over-pressure more than 10 psi).

Everything would be destroyed and everybody killed within five kilometres of Garden Island in all directions, it being a very suitable point for marking the actual physical centre of population and property in Sydney. To continue:

Within Medium Circle 8 km High Devastation severe burns to all exposed high winds, fire. (Over pressure more than 5 psi.) Within Outer Circle 20 km Light- High Damage significant blast, flash burn and fire. (Over pressure more than one psi.)

That is merely the explosion of a one-megatonne bomb, a typical submarine weapon that might be launched in Sydney. However, what are the consequences if that same weapon is launched and finds as its target, as it might well do, a ship in port carrying a large number of those weapons? Nobody has been able to research this accurately but it is known that because of the vapourisation effect of those weapons-like everything else in that five kilometre zone they would simply be vapourised-the extent of fallout from the total explosion would be greatly extended. It would depend on the number of nuclear weapons actually on that ship at the time of the explosion, but certainly there is no doubt that very little of Sydney would be left and that even people in the outer suburbs, beyond Parramatta, would suffer from radiation sickness and burns which would probably be fatal within a few days. I am saying these things not to shock and horrify people but because it is important that we understand the nature of the risk we are considering here. That is the nature of the risk. It is not good enough to say that it is a small risk and that these weapons are safe there. They are not necessarily safe there. We do not know when some idiot or maniac might gain access to them and somehow be able to create an accident on one of those ships. We do not know whether, if a ship is placed in dry dock in Sydney with nuclear weapons aboard, there will be a welding error with a welding torch with a major fire breaking out on the ship. These are things which have to be considered.

I and the Australian Democrats agree that this is a very important matter which should now be the basis of sincere discussions with our allies so that we can do the best we can for them according to the policy guidelines which the Government and Senator Evans have stated and which we, the Australian Democrats, not being the Government, accept. We accept the Government's right to lay down policy guidelines and implement them. We do not accept that the Government has a right to be lazy and slovenly about it and to say: 'We will go ahead and still allow major areas to be at risk'. Of course, the major area at risk is Garden Island, Sydney. Cockburn Sound in Perth is another area with the same kinds of problems, although they are not quite so acute. If our major allies want bases here they should be willing to discuss helping us to finance the relocation of these places. For instance, it has been said to us that the Indian Ocean is the main area needing surveillance. All honourable senators will probably agree with that . Darwin and Sydney are not particularly suitable locations to assist naval and air surveillance of that area. They are not particularly good locations for a ship to seek refuge if she were in difficulties in, say, the northern part of the Timor Sea or somewhere like that in time of war.

We have a very large and good airfield at Learmonth. I have said before and I say again that that is where the B52 aircraft should be operating from. It is logical and strategically sensible. If the Government wants to continue its policy of offering assistance to the ships of other countries, we should say to them: 'We have this problem. Go back to the guidelines'. I have quoted them to the Senate. The American Government itself does not send warships into Boston and New York because one of its criteria is population density. The Attorney- General could reasonably say to the United States Government that it has no right to expect of us and of our people things that it would not expect of its own people. I think that is a perfectly rational and reasonable point of view. It is not unfriendly, it is not anti-American. The Australian Democrats suggest that the Government look again at this long term problem. What I suggest can be done readily enough. As I said yesterday, the sale of the real estate at Garden Island would probably substantially finance the moving of the dockyard to a more rational place. I suggest that the sooner the Government gets on with that the sooner this problem will be resolved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Hawke Government had gravely misled both this Parliament and the people of Australia. The Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans), who, along with Mr Scholes, has led in this gross misleading, revealed today an entirely different set of arguments from the ones he has put forward in the last week. I proceed to demonstrate that. For the last week or so the arguments of the Government and particularly the Attorney- General have been that the captain of HMS Invincible decided for operational reasons-a wonderful euphemism-not to dry dock at Garden Island. Day by day the Attorney-General has denied that those decisions had anything at all to do with either Australian Government policies or whether or not we sought the deammunitioning of the ship. He has denied that there was any threat or danger of industrial blackballing. He has said that all those things were irrelevant. He has said that we were of good will but the captain of the ship decided against dry docking, not for operational reasons, not for reasons of maintenance and repair.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only are the facts against Senator Evans but also what he has said today entirely refutes his previous statement. He asked us to believe this nonsense of his, when in Britain, for example, the defence people were saying: 'We are now gravely concerned about what is happening in Australia and we will be seeking alternative dry docking elsewhere in the Pacific and South East Asia'. Senator Evans asked us to believe that this occurred for operational reasons.

Let me just sketch how grave this misleading was. Today we know, as has been said before by Mr Scholes, that the question of the visit to Sydney 'by HMS Invincible has been under active consideration for some considerable time'. Mr Scholes said:
I engaged in conversations with the British High Commissioner in respect to the dry docking of HMS Invincible.

We know that the Captain Cook Dockyard set aside what is called a window of three to four days-19, 20, 21 and 22 December-to do the dry docking and that preparations costing tens of thousands of dollars were made on that dry dock to receive the Invincible. There was no question of options, no question of some casual discussion, but a determined arrangement to receive the vessel and to repair it. That cannot be denied. That not being denied, the Attorney-General once again has misled this place. Let me take the matter one step further. Who better than the captain of the Invincible to let us know about this matter? The captain of the Invincible said:
At one time we thought we would do it here. It would have been fairly attractive to do so.
It was investigated and then decided not to do it here.

He did not say: 'We decided for reasons other than those concerning repair and maintenance; we decided for operational reasons'. He said: 'We decided to do it here. We investigated and then decided not to do it here'. Was there no question of politics, of the Australian Government being involved? A reporter asked the captain whether he was the ham in the sandwich. Admiral Black said:
Yes, but to no great resentment. It is often the story of the military man where governments run military things.

Could we have anything clearer than Admiral Black saying that he wanted his ship repaired at Garden Island but that that could not be done for political reasons, and having to use a euphemism in the polite diplomacy of international affairs to disguise the real reasons? Those were the words of Admiral Black; a clear statement that they wanted to repair the ship here. Indeed arrangements were made to repair it here. A window of days was set aside and Garden Island Dockyard was prepared for it to be done there. I repeat: This is what Admiral Black said about this incident:
It is often the story of the military man where governments run military things.

For political reasons Admiral Black was made the ham in the sandwich by the Australian Government. How grave it is that day after day the Attorney-General yet again misled this place and said that he had nothing to do with these matters at all. What he said today is quite a different story; he said that there were six basic policies that governed the Australian Government. As we know, he said the other day that it was not anything to do with Mr Scholes's statement about nuclear arms being on board that caused this debate. But the policy today, is that everybody knows that we will not have nuclear arms on Australian soil. Of course the Attorney-General has left the chamber; why would he stay here, having gravely misled this place once again? He said that we will have no nuclear arms on Australian soil. He went on to talk about nuclear ships and armaments, and gave a clear understanding that six weighty matters had to be decided.

No reason of Australian internal politics or industrial matters caused the Invincible to go. Why then did the Cabinet have to be locked up for hour after hour to make important decisions on this matter? Why did Mr Hayden have to talk to Secretary of State, Mr Shultz? Of course, it had nothing to do with the politics of the Australian Government, nothing to do with the policies of the Australian Government! Clearly it was to be said by the Attorney-General that we were willing to dry dock this ship but the Admiral changed his mind and went. Then why does Mr Shultz want this matter nipped in the bud? Why are the British looking to the rest of the world to get dry docking?

Is the situation not really contained in two quite important matters that ought to be mentioned? Suppose one ought to look at what the labour force on Garden Island thought and said about this matter. The president of the Captain Cook Garden Island naval dockyard union, a shop steward named Mike Jackson, is reported to have said that the workers understood that the Invincible work was off because of the armaments she carried. That is an interesting statement. When I asked whether this had anything to do with industrial pressures about armaments that were carried Senator Evans said no. But yesterday, having thought it over, he said something very interesting. He said:

Consideration also needs to be given to the possibility that industrial relations questions could arise if there were doubts about the risks entailed in having ammunition and other explosives on a ship being worked in the dry dock.

There again was the hint that quite clearly what had happened was a twofold thing; an unequivocal statement by the Hawke Government that we would not have a ship carrying nuclear weapons in the dock, and an understanding that there would be great industrial turmoil and a likely black balling of the ship. The most ugly thing about this situation is not in fact the misleading by the Attorney- General and Mr Scholes, but the absolute silence of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke . Here is a Prime Minister who has strutted the world saying that we are making strong relations with our allies and that our alliances are to be preserved and strengthened-while, of course, Mr Hayden was busy trying to weaken the Association of South East Asian Nations pact. My goodness, what does ASEAN think of us now, our having taken a different view on Kampuchea and not now being willing to service an allied ship? Mr Hawke, as Prime Minister, had one responsibility. Seeing an allied nation, Britain, wanting a ship serviced, he should have said: 'I, the Prime Minister, will guarantee the servicing of this ship; I will guarantee that it will be repaired in Australia; and I will guarantee that that will be done quickly and efficiently and that the ship will be released'. He absolutely abdicated. If ever there were a craven action by an Australian Prime Minister it was the silence of this Prime Minister, his refusal to accept the responsibility of Australia. What he said to the world was that he , the Prime Minister, could not, in fact, accept the responsibility of getting a job of repair work done in Australia for one of our most precious allies, an ally which is a part of our heritage. He has said to the world that he, as Prime Minister, abdicates this responsibility, abdicates any ability to control the work force, to control the union force in Australia. He sat back and let his mates, the Attorney-General and Mr Scholes, take the odium for this situation. The Prime Minister of Australia should have been the only front runner.

The issue got at the very guts of our whole defence security, at the very integrity of Australia in terms of its relations with its allies. How could a Prime Minister stay silent when, in fact, what Mr Scholes was saying to the British Government and to the British admiral was in direct contradiction to what Mr Hayden had said on 22 June. We should not forget that Mr Hayden, after having egg on his face regarding the Port Phillip incident, acknowledged that a failure to accept visits by nuclear armed warships would 'effectively demolish' the ANZUS alliance. After wiping the egg off his face, the Foreign Minister went on to state what was to be the policy of the Government. That policy was quite clear. He said:
If we were to require a declaration that ships were nuclear armed, it would make it virtually impossible for the Americans to operate in the context of ANZUS.
He went on:
Nothing I have said here would prevent the use of our ports for maintenance, essential repairs or refits, regular rest and recreation for crews and ships of allies or treaty partners.

What he said clearly on 22 June was that the policy of the Hawke Government, of this Prime Minister, was that if nuclear armed ships came here we would repair them. That statement was not qualified at all. He did not say 'We have to take time off; this is a most difficult, confused and involved situation'-as now the Attorney-General says-'we will work out a policy later'. He said unambiguously, because he was forced to, that if one of our allies came here with nuclear armed ships we would repair and maintain them. The very reverse happened. Mr Scholes said: 'No, it is our policy not to deal with nuclear armed ships'.

The situation is not helped by the Senator Masons of this world, who use fear threats. In this world, in which we have peace by mutual terror, in which the only way to have peace is by the use of a deterrent, the fact that ships such as Invincible sail the seas and are equipped to offer a ready deterrent at any time is one of the great factors in ensuring the safety of Australia and of the free world itself. To restrict the right of our allies to provide at any time an effective deterrent, is to work, however unwittingly, to aid our possible opponents and place upon people a fear that is unfair. We should be willing to ensure that while we cannot get total nuclear disarmament the deterrent force will be there at all times. How can we ask a ship whether it is carrying nuclear arms? How can the ship know whenever it has to be ready to act as a deterrent? I have not heard a more serious issue than this in many years in this place. For a Prime Minister to remain silent and not to be able to give a guarantee to his ally because he could not enforce it because of his left wing in the Caucus and the militant industrial unions outside, is for a Prime Minister to abdicate his job.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will speak very briefly on this matter. I realise that the matter is very important but we are constrained by time. I will take only five minutes of the Senate's time. It is, indeed, ironical that the issue surrounds the vessel HMS Invincible. Only two years ago this vessel was, in fact, offered to Australia. It was described by the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, as a spruce goose. I think time has told that it is a vessel with manifest capabilities. It is certainly not a spruce goose. It is a unfortunate situation that we in Australia and the government of the day allowed the United Kingdom to get away with reneging on the agreement that had been entered into between Australia and the British Government at that time. I believe we should not have done that. We should have stuck to our guns and, if that were the case, Invincible would have been Australia's. We are now in a less defensible position than we would have been in had the government of the day stuck to its guns.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to the other matter and that is the availability of docking facilities for such vessels of not only friendly allied nations but also of direct parties to the ANZUS Treaty-for example, the United States of America. This controversy has raised concern, rightly or wrongly, in the minds of people in the United States. It has certainly raised concern among those of us in Australia who are most concerned about the defence of this country. Whatever is able to be said about the ANZUS Treaty, one thing can be said, that is, that much depends upon the interpretation of the imprecise terms of the Treaty.

Nevertheless, on even the worst interpretation of those terms-that is, the interpretation given by Nixon at Guam, which has now been shorthanded to the Guam Doctrine-there is no doubt that, if Australia were attacked either by proxy or directly by a super-power such as the, Soviet Union, the United States would come to Australia's defence. That is clear under the terms, and even on the worst interpretation, of the ANZUS Treaty. For that reason alone, the ANZUS Treaty is of national strategic importance, given the fact that Australia could not withstand the onslaught of a super-power without increasing tenfold its defence expenditure and, for the information of Senator Mason and the Australian Democrats, without obtaining a nuclear capability. That is what is missing in this debate. It must be recognised by the Australian Democrats, and by the people who may be influenced by the fears being engendered by them, that the alternative option for Australia is to obtain a nuclear capability.

I believe, therefore, that it is absolutely vital that what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said and the commitment that he gave when he was in America to the upkeep and the honouring of the ANZUS Treaty must be observed in practice in this case so that an example can be given to our direct partners in the ANZUS Treaty that we are serious about that Treaty, we regard the obligations under that Treaty seriously and that we expect that in the event of the worst coming to the worst the terms and obligations of the other parts of the Treaty will also be honoured.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance raised this morning asks us as a Government to have a clear policy statement on access to Australian port facilities, et cetera. This morning the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) has given one of the clearest statements possible on this issue. He has in 20 minutes managed concisely and in measured tone to give us what the Government policy is and what directions it will be taking in future. As such, I guess the matter of public importance raised by the Liberal Party of Australia this morning has been valuable in that it has cleared up many of the misconceptions that have surrounded this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to devote some time, though, to the contributions made by the Opposition. I turn first to Senator Sir John Carrick who first of all made the very serious charge against the Attorney-General of misleading parliament. I do not think Senator Sir John Carrick heard or understood what Senator Evans said today because the very charges Senator Sir John Carrick made here today were met by Senator Evans's explanations. It was a baseless accusation; it was unnecessary. Senator Sir John Carrick went on to tell us what Admiral Black said . He then helped us out further and interpreted what Admiral Black said. Admiral Black is capable of saying what he has to say and so is the British Government. I do not think it is necessary to come into this chamber and say: 'Admiral Black said this but he really meant that'. If we are going to get into that game we can go into all sorts of interpretations. The fact that Senator Sir John Carrick mostly missed is that there has been no formal request for docking in Australia and there has been no formal refusal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we go again.

—Does Senator Walters wish to debate that? There has been no formal request. Senator Sir John Carrick started to get carried away with his rhetoric when he accused the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, of silence. He went on to accuse him of craven action. I would have thought that if an issue such as this were of some importance a Prime Minister would take the matter to Cabinet. That is precisely what the Prime Minister did yesterday and the matter was discussed there. I do not have any knowledge of the details of those discussions other than the matter that was discussed, as the Attorney-General has explained today. As a throw-away line Senator Sir John Carrick went on to accuse the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) of weakening the Association of South East Asian Nations, et cetera. I think some of these accusations that have been brought up today are getting to the point of paranoia. I think where the misleading is happening is misleading the public and our allies as to the purported position of the Australian Government that it does not hold.
