SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a statement on the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence entitled 'Indo-Chinese Refugee Resettlement- Australia's Involvement'.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

On behalf of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and other Ministers with an interest in matters covered by the report, in particular the Minister for Foreign Affairs, I take this opportunity to refer to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence entitled '' Indochinese Refugee Resettlement-Australia's Involvement''.

The report has been the subject of detailed consideration by this Government and its predecessor. The Committee has performed a most useful task in an effective way, reviewing the progress of the resettlement of Indochinese refugees in Australia and making recommendations for Australia's refugee policy and programs in the future. The Government welcomes the report and broadly endorses both its conclusions and its recommendations.

As the report was tabled on 16 February 1982, it is clearly somewhat dated and does not take into account the policy initiatives of the Government elected to office in March this year. Because of the significant passage of time since the report was tabled the Government does not propose making a substantive or detailed response. Nonetheless there is a range of specific conclusions and recommendations which do not have a limit in time and which are still pertinent to current circumstances and the thinking of this Government.
The report broadly endorses the management of Australia's refugee program but concludes that the problem of Indochinese refugees and displaced persons in the region has not been resolved.

We are dealing with one of the major refugee problems of history. Already nearly 870,000 refugees from this region have been resettled in third countries, not including the more than 250,000 border crossers accepted by the People's Republic of China. At the end of October 1983 there were some 174,000 persons in UNHCR camps or Regional Processing Centres in the region. Of these nearly 46,000 are boat people. This compares with camp populations at the same time last year of some 196,000 with the boat people component amounting to just over 44,000. The outflow continues albeit at a reduced rate.

The Committee makes a number of suggestions and observations concerning the refugee situation itself, the Australian response and the adequacy of existing international legal and political arrangements, and goes on to comment on the specifics of the Australian role given our unique situation as a major resettlement country within the region.

Mr President, the Government's response to this report should be seen in the context that while there are some significant elements of continuity between the previous Government's approach to refugee policy and our own, there are nevertheless some marked differences of emphasis. The new directions of Government policy will, we consider, have a favourable impact on international management of the Indochinese problem.

The report deals extensively with the foreign policy aspects of the Indochinese refugee problem. The complexities of the Indochinese situation and its many dimensions have been elaborated in this place by the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs on 8 December.

The Report notes that Australia's prominent role in resettling Indochinese has raised expectations concerning our role in helping to solve similar problems in other areas of the world. The Government has considered Australia's worldwide refugee role and the expectations arising from our performance in the past with great care. Accordingly, the Government is placing greater emphasis on political solutions to problems facing refugees. We are committed to give increased attention to human rights and humanitarian concerns in our foreign policy objectives. We will be looking at a wider range of approaches to address both cause and effect of refugee outflows. These will include more emphasis on mediation, negotiation and the provision of assistance to alleviate those conditions creating refugee outflows where this is appropriate. Australia has been an active participant in the United Nations and related forums in discussions of durable solutions to refugee situations.

There are an estimated 9-10 million refugees and displaced persons in the world today. Australia is prominent among those nations which accept for resettlement people for whom this is the appropriate solution. We have resisted the temptation during a time of recession and serious unemployment to reduce drastically our humanitarian intake. Our policy is to concentrate mainly on family reunion and refugee migration, with a further commitment to policies which diversify the socio-economic background of intended migrants.

Our diversification of the source of refugees resettled in Australia is based on the belief that none of the ethnic, religious or regional groupings represented in our population should feel that the Government is ignoring the plight of their fellow nationals because of a preoccupation with our own region.

Consequently, the Australian Labor Government is increasing intakes of refugees and other humanitarian cases from areas such as Central and South America, the Middle East and Africa, and we will look at other problem areas as necessary.

The Government was interested to see that the Committee recognises the changing nature of the Indochinese refugee outflow and the need to address such questions as ''the phenomenon of the economic refugees''. Consistent with this view, the Government is maintaining the policy introduced in July 1982, whereby applicants must demonstrate, on an individual basis, claims to refugee status as a prerequisite to admission under the Australian program. This procedure is applied without discrimination world-wide. We believe this to be an important element in deterring non-refugee outflows and in convincing Australians that the refugee program is not being abused.
It must be recognised that resettlement alone will not solve the Indochinese refugee situation.

As the Parliament will be aware, the responsible Ministers have been energetic in fostering dialogue on the political obstacles to the resolution of the plight of displaced Indochinese. The Prime Minister, Foreign Minister, and the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs have all addressed the various aspects of this problem in recent visits to South East Asia.

The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs also attended a conference in Honolulu in August of this year with representatives of other major resettlement countries at which it was agreed that a combination of policies, including voluntary repatriation, was necessary in working towards resolution of the problem.

In the light of these considerations, while resettlement and other forms of assistance must continue to be extended to the countries of first refuge which are providing care and protection to refugees and displaced persons within their territory, there is a need to pursue as vigorously as possible non-resettlement solutions to the Indochinese refugee situation. This diversified approach recognises the difficulties which lie in the way of political settlements in the region. Discussion of such issues as the creation of acceptable conditions for voluntary repatriation will be an essential element in this process.

With regard to Australia's resettlement program, the Government is pleased to note that in the view of the Committee 'overall, positive measures have been introduced to assist refugee resettlement' and that 'the settlement of Indochinese refugees in Australia is progressing well'.

Australia has already resettled over 82,000 Indochinese. Our annual intake rose from 1,135 in 1976-77 to above 15,000 in 1979-80. In 1982-83 our intake was 12, 435. In 1983-84 we envisage an intake of some 10,000. In addition we expect that in the coming year orderly departure arrangements for migration from Vietnam to Australia will provide a safe alternative to illegal departures by boat for some 2,000 people.

As regards resettlement and welfare aspects within Australia, the Committee recommends that, to allow the resettlement program to function properly, the Government should continue to provide support to Government agencies and voluntary groups engaged in providing post-arrival services and conducting settlement schemes and where possible, to increase that support. The Senate may be assured that, within existing budgetary constraints, the Government has moved to ensure that settlement programs and services for refugees and indeed all other migrant groups are maintained and, to the extent possible, enhanced. The Government considers that it is essential to ensure that refugees and migrants are able to become fully participating members of Australian society.
The Government believes that these measures give tangible proof of its continuing commitment to the development of a truly multicultural Australia.

To move to more specific concerns, the Committee recommends that steps be taken to resolve problems in the area of alteration of some refugees' personal particulars and the non-recognition of certain overseas qualifications.

With regard to the first matter, I am pleased to be able to say that significant steps have been taken. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has developed a set of guidelines aimed at resolving most cases. The guidelines recognise that many refugees do not possess documentary evidence of their true personal particulars and provide for alternative methods of backing up claims (for example medical evidence and consideration of opinions from professional people closely associated with individual refugees over a period of time). They also take account of relevant existing legislation.
Departmental officers applying the guidelines have scope to use their discretion and to request sufficient evidence to enable a judgment to be made on the bona fide of any case.

With regard to the non-recognition of overseas qualifications, honourable senators will be aware that a Committee of Inquiry into the Recognition of Overseas Qualifications, known as the Fry Committee, was set up to review the entire question of the recognition of overseas qualifications and to make recommendations on ways to alleviate present difficulties. The Committee's report was tabled earlier in the session, and consideration is currently being given by the Government to the recommendations in the report.

Finally, the Committee recommends that studies of the settlement experience of Indochinese refugees and the settlement process be conducted on an ongoing basis . The Government fully endorses this recommendation. Honourable Senators may be aware that the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has published a report on the settlement experience of Indochinese refugees in Australia the title of which ''Please Listen to What I'm Not Saying'' is indicative of its imaginative and perceptive approach to its subject. It has also commissioned other major surveys and studies and made wide use of material from academic and other sources. This material provides an important input to policy planning.

I have dealt briefly with the major thrust of the report and the fact that it is broadly consistent with the refugee policy directions of the present Government. In conclusion, I would like to commend members of the Standing Committee of Foreign Affairs and Defence for their report and to assure Honourable Senators that the Government will continue to respond to the increasingly serious world refugee problem with energy, sympathy and flexibility .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence during most of the inquiry in question, before it reported. I do not intend to canvass things on behalf of the Committee, but I indicate disappointment at the response that has been presented today by the Government. The Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, a moment ago indicated certain things in relation to responses. It does not claim to be an interim response; it claims to be a government response, and it is a very thin document. The Minister says in one part of the statement:
As the report was tabled on 16 February 1982, it is clearly somewhat dated and does not take into account the policy initiatives of the Government elected to office in March of this year.
Indeed, how could it? He goes on:
Because of the significant passage of time since the report was tabled the Government does not propose making a substantive or detailed response.

Now that really is an insult. One could certainly say that perhaps there should have been a response by the previous Government, but this Government has had since March this year to give a better response than this one. To use as an excuse the length of time since the report was tabled is about the worst excuse possible. I understood from what Senator Button was saying that in principle general responses to committee reports were, because of a shortage of time, a self-imposed shortage by the Government, reduced from six months to three months .

The report on the resettlement of Indo-Chinese refugees was a follow-up study to a study that that Committee had done in 1976. It contained not a very large number of recommendations. It was a survey of the resettlement program and since it was not the first survey it was not numerous in its recommendations, but they were specific. What we have received from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) in response is a very broad statement, including some statements of government policy which are not specifically directed to recommendations of the Committee. One statement of government policy in particular has already been contained in a ministerial statement on immigration made in the first session this year. So that is reiteration which adds nothing to consideration of specifics recommended by this Committee, which spent a very long time on this matter and put a great deal of effort into travelling around Australia and talking to a large number of people, including people who have developed some expertise on the subject of settlement of Indo-Chinese refugees.

The Indo-Chinese refugee program is a very important one because it was the first time Australia had embarked on a multiracial program and on one of substantial size. It was considerably experimental. I think that one could fairly say that it has been very successful, and the Government is not the only one which should get the credit for that. There are important issues on the subject of the resettlement of these refugees. It is disappointing that the Minister is not prepared to address himself to the specifics of the report. The statement made by the Minister contains this rather curious statement:
Our policy is to concentrate mainly on family reunion and refugee migration, with a further commitment to policies which diversify the socio-economic background of intended migrants.

I just wonder what on earth that means. I spoke in the Senate on the statement by the Minister on some variation in immigration policies under this Government. Unless one draws a very long bow, one would be guessing at what part of the Government's immigration policy would cover the statement 'a further commitment to policies which diversify the socio-economic background of intended migrants'. The Minister may have something in mind, but it is not clear to me from the statement the Government has made just what it is. It bears some elaboration if we are to do something about the engineering of people's socio-economic backgrounds. The statement also says:

With regard to Australia's resettlement program, the Government is pleased to note that in the view of the Committee 'overall, positive measures have been introduced to assist refugee resettlement.' . . . 'the settlement of Indochinese refugees in Australia is progressing well'.
I am very pleased that the Hawke Government thinks that the Fraser Government did such a good job on that. I hope that continues to be the case.

The other main aspect of the report was some emphasis on repatriation programs rather than resettlement programs. Certainly that is something I think everybody involved with refugees sees as desirable, if it is practical. I just want to put in a word of warning here. Refugees generally are fairly voiceless people. They are usually not welcome in the country they go to. They may be tolerated and looked after but they are certainly not welcome. There are those who claim that some of the repatriation programs, notably the Laotian repatriation program, have been implemented forcibly. It has resulted in people being repatriated who did not truly want to be repatriated. When people have been repatriated and have escaped again, because they have not gone back to a situation they were promised , people tend to want to turn their backs. Repatriation programs are good if they are implemented in an orderly fashion and if they meet the particular problems of the refugees. If the refugees are in their particular positions because of political or military harassment we should not kid ourselves that by shoving them back into their own countries, no matter in how orderly a fashion, we are necessarily solving the problem. I think that a great deal of humanitarianism has to be brought to bear. The statement rightly says that this program is very much involved with our foreign affairs program. I just hope that refugees never become victims of a foreign affairs program which has objectives different from the humanitarian handling of these poor people who have no country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Electoral and Referendum Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1983 No. 274 and made under the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 and the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Act 1906, be disallowed.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a document which I have shown to honourable senators.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
DISALLOWANCE OF AN INVALID REGULATION

On 25 August 1983 Mr President was supplied with an undated opinion of the Attorney-General's Department (copy attached), which is to the effect that it is not possible for the Senate to pass a motion disallowing regulations which have been held to be invalid by the High Court. The Attorney-General subsequently took a point of order to this effect in the Senate, but no ruling was made in response to the point of order, and the notice of motion to disallow the regulations in question was withdrawn.

Neither the opinion nor the debate in the Senate adduced any authority to support the proposition that an invalid regulation may not be disallowed, except the argument that because such a regulation is a nullity, there is nothing for the Senate to disallow.

It is clear that a resolution of the Senate disallowing a regulation which has been held to be invalid would have no effect on the actual state of the law. A disallowance motion means that the disallowed regulation ceases to have effect from the time of disallowance (sub-section 48 (4) of the Acts Interpretation Act ), and a regulation held to be invalid is one which has had no effect at all. It may be argued, however, that an invalid regulation still has some residual existence, even though it has no force or effect, and that it is, so to speak, ' 'still on the statute book''. A resolution of disallowance passed by the Senate would, in this argument, have the effect of depriving the regulation of that residual existence and ''removing it from the statute book''. If this is so, it would be quite proper for the Senate to pass a resolution disallowing an invalid regulation.
There appears to be no precedent for either House of the Parliament disallowing a regulation which has been held to be invalid.

Sub-section 48 (6) of the Acts Interpretation Act provides that the disallowance of a regulation shall have the same effect as the repeal of the regulation. If it is possible to repeal an invalid regulation, such repeal having the effect of depriving the regulation of its residual existence, and ' removing it from the statute book', it follows that it is also possible to disallow an invalid regulation, the disallowance resolution having that same effect as the repeal.

Cases of regulations made under Commonwealth Acts of Parliament being held to be invalid are not numerous. It is particularly rare in recent years for regulations to be held invalid, partly because the vigilance of the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee ensures that care is taken to see that regulations are in accordance with the Act under which they are made, and partly because Commonwealth legislation of dubious validity is more likely to be contained in Acts of the Parliament than in regulations.

Moreover, where regulations are held to be invalid, remedial action other than repeal may be taken. For example, in 1971 the High Court found the Dried Fruits Export Control (Election of Board) Regulations to be invalid (Willcocks v Anderson, 45 ALJR). Subsequently the Act under which the regulations were made was repealed and a completely new legislative scheme substituted.

Nevertheless, there have been cases of regulations being found to be invalid and subsequently repealed, which indicates that the executive government regarded those regulations as having some continued existence, notwithstanding their invalidity, which existence was terminated by the act of repeal. For example, in 1951 the High Court found a regulation under the Excise act to be invalid, and that regulation was subsequently repealed (Morton v Union Steamship Company, 83 CLR; SR 1953 No. 86). Similarly, in 1953 the High Court found a regulation under the Patents Act to be invalid and that regulation was subsequently repealed (Martin v Commissioner of Patents, 80 CLR; SR 1954 No. 56) .

If the opinion were correct, it would not be possible to repeal regulations held to be invalid, because the regulations would have had no existence; they would, as it were, be blank spaces in the volume of regulations. It is clear, however, that the executive government has not taken this view in the past.

It should be noted that the view contained in the opinion has also not been adhered to in relation to Acts of the Parliament; Acts and parts of Acts held to be invalid have also been repealed. Thus in 1975 the High Court held Sections 3, 4, and 12 (a) of the Representation Act to be invalid, and those sections were subsequently repealed (A.G. ex rel McKinlay v Commonwealth, 135 CLR; Representation Amendment Act 1977).

It may therefore be concluded that, just as invalid regulations may be repealed , they may also be disallowed by a House of the Parliament, either of those actions, repeal or disallowance, having the effect of terminating the existence of the invalid regulations.
AUSTRALIA
ATTORNEY-GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT
CANBERRA
Motion for disallowance of World Heritage (Western Tasmania Wilderness) Regulations No. 31 of 1983
Attorney-General I understand that this matter is to come on this afternoon.

2. These regulations were made pursuant to s. 69 of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975. They were declared to be wholly invalid by a majority of the High Court in its decision of 31 July 1983. (Gibbs C. J., Wilson and Dawson JJ. found that s. 69 was not supported in relevant respects by the external affairs power and Deane J. found that the regulations, as amended by s. 19 (2) of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983, involved an acquisition of property without provision of just terms).

3. The situation is, therefore, that as the High Court has found that the Governor-General had no power to make the regulations they are of no effect. Therefore, there is nothing for Parliament to disallow. This means that the provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 ss. 48 (as amended by Act No. 26 of 1982), 49 and 50 concerning the effect of disallowance have no application. If the Senate were to purport to disallow the 'regulations' its own action would be without effect.

4. Although the motion for disallowance is therefore misconceived, other statutory instruments made pursuant to the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 are in force and subject to disallowance. Except for those instruments held to be invalid by the High Court, these instruments remain in force and are needed to ensure that construction of the Gordon-below-Franklin Dam remains illegal.

5. In case a general debate on this matter should ensue, I attach a copy of your second reading speech on the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill 1983. I have marked some passages that might be relevant to a general debate. These passages concern the new Act and are not relevant to regulations made under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act.
G. P. M. DABB Senior Assistant Secretary Constitutional and International Branch Advisings Division

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-It is a most unusual course for the Government to concede without debate the disallowance of one of its own regulations. In this instance the Government does so because the regulations are no longer of any force or effect, or at least will not be if the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Amendment Bill 1983 in fact becomes law, as it is intended to. The subject matter of the regulations has been wholly superseded by the subject matter of that legislation. Under those circumstances it would be necessary for the regulations either to lapse or to be repealed. Senator Harradine has chosen the route of disallowance to remove them from the Statute Book. The Government has no objection to that course being followed in these circumstances.

DEBATE.TITLE: STEEL INDUSTRY AUTHORITY BILL 1983BOUNTY (STEEL MILL PRODUCTS) BILL 1983BOUNTY (HIGH ALLOY STEEL PRODUCTS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 December 1983, on motion by Senator Ryan:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night, when speaking on these Bills, I indicated that I generally welcomed the idea behind the Government's move to involve itself, relevant State governments, the industry and the unions in the important changes which need to be made to ensure that this important basic industry improves its general position. Last night I raised some of the concerns of the Opposition with respect to the inadequate response or apparent non-response of the State governments concerned-New South Wales and South Australia-and the doubts that we had about the extent to which the actual commitment of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd represented a realistic assessment of what was required satisfactorily to modernise the steel industry. In that respect, I referred to BHP's own assessment given to the Industries Assistance Commission. I also referred to the failure of the Government and the trade unions to agree on arrangements which could in fact ensure the profitability of the industry. I also drew attention to the fact that the industry in Australia under these arrangements is guaranteeing wage rises to its work force under the general community arrangements-the 4.5 per cent wage increase and full indexation thereafter which have already been granted by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I contrasted that with the situation of the United States steel industry where the unions have in fact been prepared to take a cut in the present salaries of their workers to restore the competitiveness of that major industry.

SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon I want to touch on only the price surveillance powers which are to be given under this legislation to the Steel Industry Authority and the possible effect of any failure on the part of the principal contributors to the plan to deliver on their commitments. The legislation before the Senate provides that the Steel Industry Authority has power to look at the domestic and overseas prices of steel. However, we have also, of course, seen legislation, not supported by the Opposition, go through this place that ensures that the Prices Surveillance Authority also has the power to inquire into steel prices because of the monopoly situation of that industry. It may be that the price surveillance arrangements in any single case are reasonable. We put our views earlier this week about the Prices Surveillance Authority. However, we are concerned about duplication and the possibility that there will be not just one but two avenues of bureacratic interference in the commercial operation of BHP and its subsidiaries. This is analagous to the duplication that takes place in the oil industry between the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority, which was established by the Commonwealth, and the State pricing authorities which control petroleum prices within a particular State. It is possible that the recommendations of each authority could be in conflict and this, of course, could seriously undermine the situation of the industry and threaten the success of the plan. The Opposition would like to receive assurances from the Government that there will be no conflict of interests between the two authorities and that the Government has some way of ensuring that that problem is removed.

The second issue I wish to mention relates to the question of what happens if the unions, BHP, the Commonwealth Government or the State governments fail to contribute to the plan in the way the plan envisages. As far as the Opposition can see, the Government's plan for the industry and the Bills which are before us at the moment do not provide any mechanism to redress the situation where any of the parties fail to deliver on its contribution. What, for example, happens to the steel package if BHP does not invest $800m? We are told that it is committed to $500m firm; it is probably committed to $300m. But what is the situation if that commitment is not met? Surely that would seriously threaten the development of a modern, internationally competitive steel industry. Indeed, as I said earlier, perhaps even greater investment is required. But what is the remedy if that part of the obligations under this package is simply not delivered? Again, what happens if the unions fail to increase productivity in the way in which the package suggests and, so, the industry becomes less competitive rather than more competitive?

They are a series of concerns which the Opposition has about this matter. I ask the Government to address itself to those concerns because the Opposition, like the Government, wishes to see a healthy and thriving steel industry in Australia . It is important that Australia should have such a steel industry. We welcome the fact that the Government has brought forward a plan. We welcome certain elements of it. I merely rise to express some of the serious questions which remain in our minds, having considered the package.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Crichton-Browne, I should point out to the Senate that there is an agreement that at 12.45 p.m. we will shift to a first reading debate. Therefore, it would be convenient if Senator Crichton- Browne at 12.45 p.m. sought leave to continue his remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Steel Industry Authority Bill 1983, the Bounty (Steel Mill Products) Bill 1983 and the Bounty (High Alloy Steel Products) Bill 1983. I notice that the second reading speech accompanying the Steel Industry Authority Bill tells us that in return for the taxpayers' commitment of $350m to the shareholders and employees of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, plus the additional indirect costs of tariffs which were calculated by the Industries Assistance Commission to represent $150m for 1981-82, BHP will spend between $500m and $800m of its own money upgrading facilities. Each decision will, of course, be made on the conventional commercial criteria of reducing production costs and improving productivity, product quality and customer service. That figure is a great deal less than was spent in the four years to 1981-82 without such promises of assistance of taxpayers' funds.

SPEECH.PARA: For their part, the unions have agreed that wages for the industry's work force will be consistent with the prices and incomes accord. In other words, the unions' contribution towards its share of the $350m is to undertake to honour an agreement previously made. They have further undertaken to increase productivity to levels of man hour output which they have not previously worked, notwithstanding that in the four years to 1982 BHP invested $355m with the primary purpose of improving labour productivity only to see it decline. The Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) referred in his second reading speech to a target of re-establishing a productivity level of 250 tonnes per employee per annum in the major steel works. I can find no evidence of that level being previously achieved.

The essence of the Government's proposal is to continue to prop up an inefficient and technically outdated steel industry which has grown lazy, uncompetitive and incompetent. It is an industry which previously has been happy to lurch along behind the barriers of protection and quotas, ever mindful that it was in a monopoly situation in Australia. Senator Button's second reading speech talks of the steel industry plan reflecting the Government's commitment to the maintenance of a viable and efficient steel industry in Australia. That, of course, is a contradiction in terms. The steel industry in Australia, as has been clearly demonstrated in the IAC report on the subject, is not efficient. In fact, on the evidence given to the Commission and by comparison with other steel producing countries, Australia's steel industry is far from efficient. To suggest that it is viable is absurd. According to BHP, in its submission to the IAC, the minimum protection needs for continuation of the industry were a guarantee of 85 per cent of the domestic market through tariff quotas, with a penalty duty of 150 per cent on imports. That means that, if BHP is to be competitive with overseas producers, imported steel would have to attract duty which would make it 150 per cent more expensive than it would normally be. Mr Deputy President, it being 12.45 p.m., I seek leave to continue my remarks later .
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take advantage of this opportunity during the Senate luncheon hour to raise for note, and not for elaborate comment , the case of Father Brian Gore, an Australian Catholic priest held under house arrest in the Philippines. Father Gore is a Columban missionary who, with two other missionaries of his order and six lay workers, has been subjected to allegations to do with conspiracy to murder, at various times incitement to rebellion, possession of weapons which were clearly intended to bring about the death of adversaries, and the distribution of subversive literature. All these charges have been levelled at one time or another against these missionaries and their lay workers who, as far as can be judged from this distance, have tried to carry into practical, concrete effect the demands in the social dimension of the gospel.

SPEECH.PARA: Father Gore is supported by his parishioners. I saw an article in the Canberra Times earlier this week to this effect:
A nine-day daytime fast in protest at delays in bail hearing would be held by parishioners of three missionaries and six other people accused of murder, church sources said yesterday.

That news item indicates that the Basic Christian Community, the group to which Father Gore ministers, is engaging in a novena up to Christmas Day in order to show its solidarity with his plight. The Australian Government has taken a very supportive and keen interest in ensuring that the due processes of law are accorded to Father Gore in relation to the charges which have been brought against him. As far as I have been able to judge, the due processes of the law have been followed through following the initial rather draconian invoking by military authorities of the charges and assertions against these missionaries. The local bishop, Antonio Fortich, has described the method of arrest and serving of warrants as a malicious act and there is no doubt that the initial movement by the military in this situation on an island of the Philippines was hatched and perpetrated in a way designed to create the maximum amount of terror amongst those with whom Father Gore is associated in order to subvert the very real work which the Basic Christian Community is carrying out.

The charge is made that the conspiracy to murder was organised at secret meetings which Father Gore and Father O'Brien had organised and that at those meetings which were infiltrated, it is alleged, by outlawed communist New People 's Army elements, the conspiracy to liquidate a local mayor was perpetrated. Both missionaries have in affidavits asserted that the charge is quite false, fabricated and concocted. As an outsider it would appear that the missionaries' crime has been to arouse within the minds of the sugar plantation workers, the most deprived and depressed segment of the population in that area of the Philippines, an awareness of their plight and the means by which they can liberate themselves from that plight by speaking out against abuses of authority , corruption and land grabbing which have been undertaken for years by the sugar barons in conjunction with army elements as their military and enforcement arm. Father Brian Gore, whom these persons wanted to deport as an undesirable alien, has been able to insist that the due processes of internal domestic law be followed through. He is at the moment awaiting further developments within those processes.

I have tried to tread fairly carefully in my description of the situation. A very heartening Christmas card has been signed by most senators in this chamber whom I have been able to contact over the last few days. The Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator John Button, the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Fred Chaney, and the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Don Chipp, have joined with well over 50 senators from all sides of the chamber in signing a very simple Christmas card to Father Gore. It contains no political message and is not to be used in any propagandist way but I think it is a very heartening expression of solidarity and awareness of the plight of Father Gore. It is very apt that at a time when Australians are exchanging Christmas greetings amongst each other in the spirit of goodwill which prevails during this season so many senators have seen fit to extend overseas that spirit of goodwill towards an Australian who is undergoing such distress and uncertainty.

I will be in the Philippines over the Christmas period and hope to deliver the Christmas card to Father Gore on Boxing Day or as near to that day as possible. One hopes that the judicial processes will be brought to a speedy conclusion in order that he and the other missionaries may determine how they will carry through their ministry in the future in that freedom of choice they ought to have in relation to such matters. I simply want to put on the record the concern of so many senators with Father Gore's plight and their extending to him of this message of goodwill which is so appropriate to the season. I imagine that his parents in Perth will be heartened and buoyed up by this expression of non- partisan support. I hope to bring back to the Senate a message from Father Gore in the autumn session.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I refer yet again to a case I have raised in the Parliament on a number of occasions in the past three years. It is the case of Kenneth Dax who was killed aboard HMAS Tobruk. To recap briefly, the Dax family, after a two-year fight with the previous Government and the current Government, was offered an ex gratia payment of $3,500 from the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes. The Dax family felt that this amount is insufficient to meet the costs it has incurred in its lengthy battle with the Government and it has deferred acceptance in the hope that the amount will be reconsidered. Despite the evidence that is now piling up on the Tobruk-the evidence I refer to here is that contained in the two inquiries into Kenneth Dax 's death as well as the evidence given to the previous Parliament's Joint Committee of Public Accounts and to this Parliament's Public Accounts Committee- I believe there has been a continuing reluctance to accept responsibility in this area. The previous Minister for Defence, Mr Sinclair, virtually ignored the pleas from the Dax family and the current Government was also slow to act. The present Minister for defence (Mr Scholes) in a letter dated 9 May refused to consider an ex gratia payment because he said it would 'circumvent the provisions of existing legislation'.

SPEECH.PARA: In a previous speech in the Senate in response to that letter I pointed out that that is precisely what an ex gratia payment is all about. The Dax family acknowledged, as I acknowledged, that any payment to them relating to the death of Kenneth Dax was not required by any Federal legislation. I am happy to say that the Minister for Social Security has given an undertaking that the Government is considering bringing in such legislation so that in cases such as this in the future where a person meets an untimely death in a situation that can, in part, be said to be under the responsibility of the Commonwealth, there is legislative compensation. The Government has used the Queensland legislation in this area to work out the amount of money that it believes could rightly be paid. An amount of $3,550 is approximately the amount of money that would be paid in similar circumstances if the matter had fallen under Queensland State Government legislation. I hope the Government has undertaken the exercise that it promised to undertake and that, in the autumn session, there will be legislation which will cover these problems in the future.

I am of the belief that the amount of money profferred by the Government is an insufficient amount. The Government has admitted a moral responsibility by paying compensation in this case. I believe in doing so the amount ought to be set at a reasonable level. The Dax family has suffered much distress as a result of the previous Government's actions in this regard and the inability and the unwillingness of the previous Government to accept a moral responsibility that the current Labor Government has at least accepted. The previous Government was quite willing to make unsolicited payments of over $6,000 to athletes who did not attend the Moscow Olympic Games. Yet after two years it was not willing to compensate the Dax family for the loss of their son under circumstances which I believe were the responsibility of the Commonwealth. The compensation is less than half the amount which was offered to athletes not to attend the Olympic Games.

I think it is time that the current Government moved beyond the position that it has taken, that it settled this matter at a reasonable level once and for all . Justice should be done to Kenneth Dax's parents by offering a reasonable ex gratia payment. In no way could that ex gratia payment be seen as compensation to the Dax family for the loss of their son. It cannot be seen as satisfying, in any way, that particular element; rather it is directed quite specifically and quite directly at the costs that have been involved in their son's untimely death and to the intransigence of the previous Government and the current Government in accepting fully the moral obligations of the Commonwealth. I believe that next year-as I understand will probably be the case-the Public Accounts Committee will be able to table a report on the Tobruk. Yet again I will probably have to raise this issue. I hope-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Macklin is referring to a matter that is before the Public Accounts Committee and a matter on which the Public Accounts Committee will report. It has completed its report. I must admit that the Dax matter is very much before the Committee and it will make recommendations. Therefore, I do not think that Senator Macklin ought to anticipate what the Committee will recommend and the comments the Committee will make.
—Order! Senator Georges, I think you have made your point without raising a point of order. I call Senator Macklin.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I was not attempting to canvass the decisions or the comments the Committee might make, I was merely suggesting that I will probably be required, the next time the Committee reports, to comment on this matter yet again. I hope in the mean time that the Government may look at this matter so that any further grief and any further injustice to the Dax family will not be committed and that this case may be put aside and settled once and for all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said before that for Australia to halt its slide on the per capita wealth table and be able to provide continuing and rewarding employment for its people it will have to become an outward looking, sophisticated, post-industrial society. The lesson should be learned that such wealth will not be created by primary and extractive industry alone. Furthermore, we will not be able to compete in the fields of mass-produced, high labour content manufacture. Our costs will be too high. We must realise we are not a Third World country. We should have passed that stage of our economic development. An economically profitable future for Australia will lie in embracing new technology, in utilising that technology in our manufacturing processes to the maximum and aggressively marketing high value added top quality products. Professor Bill Ford, Professor of Organisational Behaviour at the University of New South Wales, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We can't attract industries on the basis of low wages and low skills-we live in a highly educated skilled East Asian world. We have no alternative but to compete with our skills.

To date, our technological performance has been poor. We have been slow to maximise the potential for economic growth that new technology offers. We, in the public office, have a responsibility to identify such failings and to urge change when such change is within the capacity of government. Taxation policies oriented to encourage productive economic growth is a subject I have spoken on from time to time. Failings in our industrial research and development is another area upon which I spoke only yesterday. Another area I have already covered is the stifling effect of a lack of venture capital. But the failing I wish to speak upon today in this very short time available is even more basic and more critical if we are to have an increasingly prosperous economy. The subject is the education that is necessary to meet the new technology challenge. I am not only speaking of the education that is necessary to keep up with new technology. Professor Stranks, Vice-Chancellor of Adelaide University, in a recent article stated:

In technological change it is better to set the pace than to try to keep up. A key factor in setting the pace is the ability of the education system to adapt to the changing technical and skill needs.

Professor Slatyer, President of the Australia and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science Conference, has been outspoken on this subject. He has noted the low levels of participation in education in Australia, questioned the effectiveness of the education children are receiving, and stressed the need for retraining of older people as job demands change. Participation, effectiveness and retraining are each subjects on which I wish to touch in this debate.

The problem of non-participation is striking. Australia has 65.1 per cent of people between 15 and 19 years of age in the work force compared with 34 per cent in Canada, the United States and Japan. Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development figures for 1980 school enrolments between those ages reveal that, of 23 nations, Australia was ranked fourteenth. Certainly we allow our young people to opt out. The compulsory school attainment level in Australia is 15 years of age, in the United States of America 18 years and in Canada 17 years. Non-participation figures for tertiary institutions are equally concerning, particularly as they relate to younger persons. In 1950 about 4 per cent of Australians entering the labour force had tertiary education. In 1980 it was 8 per cent. This could be compared with Japan, which during the same period progressed from less than one per cent to 39 per cent. We are, therefore, not retaining our children at school, nor attracting the same numbers to tertiary education as are our competitors.

With regard to schools, the drop in retention rates is most dramatic in non- government schools. This may suggest an economic rationale. Many are leaving and , as we know, not obtaining employment. If they are leaving to take unemployment benefits, it reflects a very depressing situation. Certainly more financially beneficial unemployment benefits vis-a-vis student support is not encouraging a continuation in the education process. Surveys of children's attitudes to school also paint a depressing picture. The Service to Youth Council in South Australia , my State, carried out surveys and identified problems of school experiences as perceived by children. They were perceived to include disconnection from the real world, continuous negative experiences lessening self-esteem, lack of opportunity to develop social skills, lack of consistency in school rules, needless authority, non-participation in decision-making, poor relationships with teachers and limited career advice. Certainly these would not all be objectively sustainable, but the important thing is that they are children's perceptions; and that is a depressing situation.

The reasons for our failure to keep children at school are obviously complex in themselves. I mention only one identified by a number of academics. Professor R. T. Fitzgerald says that schools are too orientated towards candidates for tertiary institutions. Speaking of students who drop out he said:
They do not consider themselves candidates for higher education and therefore leave.

For those children remaining at school the question is whether the education they are receiving is of a sufficiently high standard. Professor Slatyer reminds us that an inquiry found that more than 30 per cent of 15-year-olds had not mastered the full range of elementary calculating skills needed in everyday living. He said that the same inquiry found that 17 per cent of 15-year-olds could not read well enough to understand simple passages satisfactorily and reminded us that in our future society these people will be just as handicapped as those with physical disabilities were in pre-industrialised society. Of which inquiry he spoke I am unsure because Dr Michael Kurst, Director of the Centre for Educational Research, Stanford University, who tried to do a study of Australian schools, was staggered by the lack of statistics available. We know that for 13 years the United States of America has been monitoring attainment levels in its schools. Surely in the basic fields of literacy and numeracy this should be accepted in Australia.

Teacher quality is something we must also face up to in discussing non- participation and insufficiently high standards. According to Professor Chipman, teacher quality is a crucial question in education and perhaps the one least understood. He is particularly critical of the standard of graduates employed in the New South Wales State Education Department in the 1960s and 1970s. Professor Leonie Kramer is of the opinion that teacher unions pay lip service to education standards but are more concerned with political grandstanding and are obsessed with the idea that money solves all educational problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —And smaller class sizes.

—And class sizes. Certainly quantity has dominated the education debate over quality in recent years. Is there any reason why teachers should not accept ongoing evaluation of their competence, as also is the case in the United States where teachers need to demonstrate competence on a points system to maintain registration? Of course, it is hard to demand high teacher quality when Australians do not place a high value on education. Therefore, the problem is that the wider community attitude needs to be changed. Teachers are not held in particularly high esteem but their community responsibility is enormously high, a situation, one might say, which is somewhat analagous to that of politicians. We should recognise the need to select the best educated into teaching, to provide adequate in-service and preservice programs, and also to encourage out of school work experience for teachers. Then these questions can be asked: Is the school education system adapting to change? Is it sufficiently flexible in promoting broad and continuing education? Is it encouraging students to be initiators and not just reactors, recognising that life will be constant education and training but that such a fact of life should be not depressing but challenging? One wonders about the answers to such questions.

SPEECH.PARA: The question then is whether the post-school education has been sufficiently meeting the challenge. Arguably, universities have been blinkered and too narrow in their approach. Professor Stranks recognises this when he says:
The implications of rapidly changing high technology requires that a solid base education rather than a narrow vocational preparation will become more important .

Furthermore, they have been too slow to adapt to changing demands. Professor Slatyer reminds us that one university in 1981 had a quota on its computer science course that was so small the entry cut-off point was higher than that for medicine. Whilst that situation has existed, Australia has been training several hundred fewer computer programmers each year than the number needed and has had to rely on migration to make up the shortfall. Clearly we must develop greater flexibility in our tertiary institutions and be able to shift resources promptly in response to such signals. There have been worthwhile achievements within technical and further education establishments and colleges of advanced education which unfortunately I have not time to detail, although there is duplication, empire building, and again insufficient flexibility and vision.

Our apprenticeship system needs re-examining. It should include consideration of the length, terms and conditions, and should look to a wider range of occupational areas. Germany is an interesting precedent in that regard. Furthermore, the apprenticeship system tends to perform at the rate which reflects economic conditions. That does not necessarily ensure the skills that will be necessary for Australia's future requirements. Greater institutionalised training may be necessary. Apprentices must appreciate that a trade qualification will not necessarily tie them to that trade. A broader training would seem useful in encouraging flexibility of employment. Industry also must accept its share of the responsibility for our failings. Human resources are more important than ever. In many ways increased technological sophistication has made employers more dependent upon their employees, yet there is still insufficient cross-training and continuing education. One should be reminded of the massive investments made by Japan in industry in developing skills. Mitsubishi heavy industries runs five technical institutions and on the job retraining courses as priorities change and redeployment is required. I cannot understand why the emphasis of union bargaining is not on high skills training rather than on short term wage benefits. That is certainly the advice of Professor Ford who says:
The skills of the work force are as important as wages and unions should start to pay attention to the skills of their members as well as their pay packets.

We must also aim for a less confrontationist approach, with employees being seen as an investment, a human asset to be conserved and developed. This will, of course, also require a certain responsibility on the part of the employees. We are reminded that Australia spends one-tenth of one per cent of its gross domestic product on retaining and job creation and at least 25 times as much on the protection of declining industries. Obviously, government has a responsibility to direct more energy towards the future rather than the past. It is a challenge that we as a nation are not yet addressing adequately. Many other subjects could be addressed in this short speech. The insufficient link between industry and tertiary institutions, insufficient flexibility in teaching hours at some institutions, more effective and complete education in transition from school to work and more flexible teaching methods to allow particularly those more practically oriented to gain sufficient from the school experience come immediately to mind. Some of the problems upon which I have touched today were dealt with in the reports on participation and equity in Australian schools which were tabled yesterday. My first impressions of the two reports are favourable.

In conclusion, serious problems exist for Australia in the failure to retain students in the education process and therefore to give them an adequate grounding in skills required to meet the challenge of a rapidly changing society . They should realise that, as Professor McKinnon has said, the whole base has moved up. The minimum educational level required to keep abreast of other countries has risen. This is a challenge that schools must be prepared to meet. The apprenticeship system needs reviewing. Tertiary and further educational institutions are still not sufficiently meeting their challenge. But probably more than ever the community needs to change its attitude to educational achievements. It needs to have pride in its tertiary institutions yet demand the highest standards. It needs to elevate significantly the status of teachers to reflect more accurately the critical imortance of their role in society. The OECD has proclaimed:

. . . intellectual capital-scientific resources and the aptitude for technological innovation-constitutes the major asset of industrialised nations in the new modes of international competition and inter-dependence.
It is a message we should heed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the presence in the chamber of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) because I wish to discuss a matter that comes within his portfolio. It relates in particular to the Defence Service Homes Corporation. The matter arises from a loan application from Mr and Mrs Morgan of Queensland who have been approved for a defence service home loan. That approval was given in a letter dated 10 January 1983 and they expected to be able to settle this matter probably in January 1984. There has been a number of items of correspondence. The Morgans have now been told that as the house in question is in their names as tenants in common the loan cannot proceed because the Act requires that they be joint tenants of the property. I concede that the small print at the top of the application form discloses that this is a factor but in some ways it is not highlighted as it might have been. The part of the application form that the parties fill in with information does not require them to state that they are joint tenants, and it is something which I think could be overlooked. In any event, that is what has happened. I wish to speak about the consequences of the dilemma. I ask the Minister to give consideration to a change in the Act or the regulations. I appreciate that the property is more secure with two people as joint tenants than as tenants in common, but I suggest that it is not significantly more secure.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we have to acknowledge that in these days many more people who go through the proceedings for divorce and property settlements then enter into a further marriage and take to the marriage money which is part of the settlement from the original marriage. Many people who do that regard that money as money that should go to the children of the first marriage. For that reason, I suggest , there is an increasing tendency for people to enter into purchases as tenants in common and not as joint tenants, as has been more traditional. This may apply to only a few but I wonder whether this option could be made available to people in the situation in which Mr and Mrs Morgan find themselves. Either the husband or the wife putting money into a purchase may wish to retain the ownership as tenants in common to ensure that the money goes back to the children of the first marriage, which is precisely the case in this situation.

I am in no way being critical of the Corporation or of what has occurred. It is a misunderstanding and a mistake that was not noticed for some considerable time after the approval. It is a dilemma for Mr and Mrs Morgan that I ask the Minister to do his best to solve. In particular I ask him to consider an amendment to the Act similar to the one which was passed last year to enable a person who was permanently separated but not divorced to proceed with the settlement. I also welcomed that change in the legislation as recognising some of the changes in the way in which society functions at present. I ask the Minister to pursue this matter and to look into it with a view to finding a solution that may be welcome to a number of other people as well.

I wish also to raise a matter about which I have written to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden). It concerns the adoption of children from Indonesia which I understand has recently been stopped as a result of a decision of the Indonesian Government. No-one can suggest that the Indonesian Government is not entitled to change its rules or change the arrangements for adoptions but I refer to the hardship for the children concerned and certainly for the families, all of whom I think are in South Australia and who are suffering what might almost be described as a sense of bereavement. The proceedings had gone so far that they had photographs of the children. They had, in a sense, got to know the children who were to become parts of their families and suddenly the rules have been changed even for those who had been approved in Indonesia for adoption. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a letter written by the approved adoption agency, ASIAC-the Australian Society for Inter-Country and Children Inc .-to the Ambassador for Indonesia, which sets out more detail than I think is appropriate to read out today. I have not shown the letter to the Minister.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
26.10.83 The Ambassador,
Mr Harirustaman,
Embassy of the Republic of Indonesia,
8 Darwin Ave,
Yarralumla,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600

Dear Sir, The ASIAC (S.A.) organization wishes to formally register with your Government, through you, our disappointment at the passing of legislation for a three year residency period for foreigners adopting Indonesian children. This legislation drastically intrudes on the humanitarian rights of eligible children .

This organization fully supports, and is sympathetic to, the aim of the Indonesian government to prevent mal-practices associated with baby-buying and illegalities in Intercountry adoption, but consider the recent legislation goes far beyond this aim.
Since 1976 the ASIAC organization has placed sixty-six Indonesian children into South Australian families.

(a) ASIAC has worked in co-operation with the Indonesian National Council for Social Welfare for these adoptions, giving details of, and follow-up progress reports on each of the children placed, to the National Council.
(b) Since 1978 ASIAC has placed children only from Indonesian institutions approved of, and affiliated with the National Council.
(c) All South Australian adoptive parents held prior written approval from the South Australian Government welfare authority (Department for Community Welfare) to undertake an adoption.

(d) ASIAC (S.A.) Adoption Agency is licenced annually by the South Australian Department for Community Welfare to assist with adoption placements, and all placements are oversighted by that Department. All monies pertaining to adoptions, outlaid by parents are submitted to ASIAC (S.A.) and the Department for Community Welfare in a sworn statement, and held in confidential records, by the Department for Community Welfare.
(e) Both parents have attended Court hearings and completed all the legal formalities in Indonesia, as per the guidelines set down by the National Council for Social Welfare in Indonesia.
(f) All adoptions through ASIAC (S.A.) have been undertaken in a legal, ethical , responsible manner in the interests of the children whom we serve.

(g) The paperwork associated with each adoption has been duly legalized by the Embassy of the Republic of Indonesia in Canberra, with whom we have liaised on numerous occasions to promote openness and understanding of our work in Indonesia.

The Embassy of the Republic of Indonesia, through Mr I. G. K. N. Sumantera, sought the assistance of ASIAC (S.A.) in August of 1981 in preparing a report to the Government of Indonesia concerning the adoption of Indonesian children into Australia. A representative of our organization travelled to Canberra to assist with this inquiry and to register ASIAC (S.A.) support for the Indonesian Government's attempts to ensure that Inter-country adoption from Indonesia was carried out in an appropriately controlled manner.
Letters were also sent to the South Australian Department for Community Welfare registering our condemnation of illegal adoption practices at that time.

The ASIAC (S.A.) organization adheres to the philosophy that Intercountry adoption is considered as a 'last resort' for children and is deemed necessary only after all other avenues of maintaining the child in his/her natural family, or adoption by Indonesian nationals have been investigated.

As evidence of our adherence to this philosophy ASIAC (S.A.) operates a sponsorship programme in Indonesia, and contributes to the salaries of Social Workers in institutions that promote internal Indonesian adoption, for that purpose. We have observed with satisfaction, the increase in number of Indonesian nationals adopting children through this programme, thus reducing the number of children for whom intercountry adoption is felt to be necessary. In addition, aid projects have been funded in institutions and at a village self- help level.
A number of children placed through the ASIAC organization have had medical disorders which had left their future uncertain, and in jeopardy if they had remained in instructionalized care.
Marlon, abnormal growth and development, poor eyesight. Subsequently diagnosed as epileptic.
Mulyono, mentally slow, diagnosed as epileptic.
Hadiah, perforation of the throat, blood disorder requiring special diet.
Jumadi, mentally, physically and emotionally retarded, diagnosed as profoundly deaf.
Kornelus, suspected heart abnormality.
Deddy, severe emotional retardation.
Rini, severe lactose intolerance causing digestive disorders.
Daniwestri, umbilical hernia.
Sugiarti, severe dental problems.
Budi, severe emotional retardation.
Daniel, intestinal hernia resulting in a failure to gain weight.
Siska, Eye deformality, blindness in one eye.
Daniel, severely perforated eardrum resulting in extreme hearing loss in one ear .
Alberta, suspected hydrocephalous.
Susanti, mental and physical retardation and blindness.

Through intercountry adoption all these children have received optimum medical care and the emotional security of stable family life through the commitment of caring parents. Such facilities and individual care is not possible within institutions.

Our present concern is for seven particular children currently in institutional care in Indonesia who had been allocated to South Australian families prior to the recent legislation. These children have not been adopted because of this organization's endeavours to ensure that all the ethical and legal formalities within Indonesia were strictly adhered to. Consequently, these children, some of whom were cleared for adoption up to ten months ago, cannot be placed in the family environments to which all children are entitled.

The prospective parents have undergone extreme emotional stress during this period of waiting for the adoptions to be finalized. All had made a deep commitment to each of these children over a period of time of preparing for the children to enter the families. Their concern for the future of the children has added to their extreme emotional distress of having to break the emotional commitment that each has made to the individual children.

ASIAC (S.A.) shares the concerns of these parents and children, as well as the ongoing concern for other children for whom the love and security of a family environment is now no longer possible or available.

Whilst we actively support responsible policies to eradicate mal-practice in Intercountry adoption, ASIAC (S.A.) is concerned that the fundamental right of eligible children to a permanent family life which will ensure their physical, mental, emotional and medical needs is being violated.

We urge the Indonesian authorities to create a legal and responsible avenue by which the deserving children can continue to be assisted through Intercountry adoption by responsible social welfare organizations within Indonesia and abroad .
To absolutely prevent all further adoptions, even of the most needy children, is much too drastic a step to take to remove some of the problems caused by the actions of some unscrupulous persons.
With respect,
Yours sincerely,
Pamela Duffy,
Principal Officer, ASIAC (S.A.) Adoption Agency.
Brian Harris,
President,
ASIAC (S.A.) Parent group.
for and on behalf of the ASIAC (S.A.) membership.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not go through the five letters that I have here, but they set out in detail the arrangements which have been made. In all cases the couples concerned had been approved in Australia and Indonesia as adopting parents and had been allocated photographs of the children. One letter stated that all necessary arrangements had been made for passports, injections and travel for the family and their present children to go to Indonesia to collect the baby. Suddenly the rules were changed to apply, one might say, retrospectively. The only things that had not occurred were the actual court proceedings and the final formalities. All the parents were waiting for the date of those proceedings, which were expected to occur quite soon. I have asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs to look into the matter to see whether the adoptions that had been approved could go ahead or at least to obtain from the Indonesian Government some explanation for the problem which has arisen which the parents in Australia would perhaps find acceptable. I telephoned the Indonesian Embassy at the beginning of November and was told that adoptions were possible and that I would be sent the relevant literature. I have not received it and I think that adoptions from Indonesia may in fact have been stopped. To reiterate, I ask that the Indonesian Government give sympathetic consideration to allowing those adoptions that had been approved to continue and to allowing the children concerned to come to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish now to raise the future of the Australian Capital Territory Bush Fire Brigade. The Australian Capital Territory Bushfire Council is an extremely important part of life in the Australian Capital Territory. That certainly was the case last summer with the fires in Gudgenby. It seems that the Minister for Territory and Local Government (Mr Uren) may be considering making some changes but they have not yet been publicised and the people in the Southern Australian Capital Territory Bush Fire Brigade are particularly concerned about the changes that they believe are likely to be made. The appointments to the Council expired on 21 November 1983 and, as I understand it, members have not yet been reappointed. In its letter to the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) of 10 November 1983, the Brigade suggests that the Minister:

Reappoint the existing Council for a period of 12 months from 22nd November 1983, or if you wish to change some or all of the membership of the Council ensure that the current range of interests continue to be represented in the year commencing 22nd November 1983.

Direct that a review of the composition of the Council be undertaken by your Department during the next twelve months, on a basis which will ensure effective consultation with the Council and other interested parties.

The Brigade is concerned that the persons to be reappointed will be drawn exclusively from the government sector and that few of them will have had first hand experience in bushfire prevention and control. It is concerned also that rural interests, which depend so heavily on the effective functioning of the Bush Fire Council, may have no guarantee of future representation. It fears that valuable input from specialist reference organisations such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the Bureau of Meteorology may be lost. There are other changes that the Brigade fears will weaken the effectiveness of bushfire control if the people who are not having an input into it are those with expertise and experience. I ask the Minister to give this matter his early and urgent attention because I believe it is important that in no way should there be any uncertainty about bushfire control during this coming summer. I am sure that all will have noticed the extent to which grass is around at present in Canberra. The matter is important and I ask the Minister to take notice of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to raise what I believe to be a matter of grave concern to this nation. Indeed, I believe it to be of grave concern to the human race. With the Senate to sit only another day and with a large number of Bills and other matters on our minds, it is difficult to be alert to everything happening in the nation. On Tuesday 13 December the State Government of Victoria gave the go-ahead to all forms of in vitro fertilisation. Although the matter relates to the State Government in Victoria, it is of such grave concern that it must be raised in this chamber before the Parliament rises . In the report of the Melbourne Herald it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The decision affects several hundred women on waiting lists for treatment-and is expected to encourage many more to seek it.

The procedure will include the use of donor sperm, ova and embryos. The action of the Government of Victoria follows a report of the Waller Committee of Inquiry on In Vitro Fertilisation. Its report was considered by the State Government and it responded to the report by giving the go-ahead to in vitro fertilisation. I have the greatest sympathy for married couples who are childless. I have sympathy for any married couple unable to have a child because of circumstances of health, physical conditions or other reasons. Notwithstanding my sympathy, I think that in vitro fertilisation as presently engaged in by doctors in Victoria must be looked at from the point of view of sympathy for couples who are unable to have a child. In an article by Aileen Berry in the Age of 12 December it is stated:
The limited response from the general public could easily be interpreted as apathy-a refusal to get involved in anything in which it is not personally involved.
I understand that allegation, although I suspect that the public has failed to get involved because at the moment on questions such as this it is totally leaderless. The article continues:
But it is more likely a tacit acceptance of a scientific medical procedure which, on the surface at least, can only add to the quality of the lives of those who undergo that procedure.

The author of this article looks at the lives of those who undergo that procedure and, in effect, say that those people who want to have a child and who are unable to do so are enabled by this procedure to have that child, and suggests that that is a good thing. If that was all there was to it that would certainly be a good thing. I find it very difficult because I do not want to get involved in the enormous emotional arguments which this matter could raise. There is no doubt that the doctors who are involved in these procedures are, in fact, right on the limits. In many cases they are in effect playing the role of God. They are interfering at the precise moment of fertilisation, with the egg, the embryo and the whole reproductive system. They are interfering in that process. The doctors may be doing it with the highest motives, but the people of this nation must become aware of the problems and consequences which might arise as a result of these experiments. Who will stop the irresponsible? The Age article also reported:

Professor Carl Wood, the head of the Queen Victoria Medical Centre's in vitro team, believes that the original in vitro technique, using an egg from a woman whose husband provided the sperm for fertilisation, was fairly well accepted.

Studies had now shown, he said, that the community attitude towards donated eggs was improving and that opposition to the method tended to come mainly from the elderly and from people with limited formal education.

In that event, I am one of the elderly or, alternatively, I have a limited formal education. Of course, that is nonsense. I am 51 and have a Bachelor of Laws degree from Melbourne University. I am desperately concerned about what is involved in these procedures. As I said, who will stop the irresponsible? We have already had the experience in this generation of the Nazis endeavouring to manipulate the human race in Germany. They called upon the women of Germany to have super children. Many of them, inspired by the rhetoric of Goebbels and Hitler, succumbed to that call to produce the so-called German super race. Who is to say that some future leader may not inspire the women of his or her nation to have some sort of specialist child?
