If some embryo could be established having a particular group of characteristics which the leader of a country sees as desirable, such as simple-minded obedience, superhuman strength and sporting facility, but being limited in intellect and unable to apply the mind to the realities of this world but a simple obedience and mindlessness, who is to say that at some stage in the future another Adolf Hitler may be able to persuade the women of a country to produce children using this technique?

These doctors in Victoria are playing with human life. One of the unfortunate problems in connection with this debate is that we get involved in the question of abortion and in arguments as to whether a foetus constitutes a human life and whether abortion is the killing of a human child. That then gets us involved in all sorts of emotional arguments. Surely the people of this nation must be able to see, even if they do not want to get involved in that argument, that where a doctor is able to take a foetus-because that is what it is-or an unfertilised egg out of the womb of a mother, transplant it into another mother and fertilise it at that stage or fertilise it en route, he is playing with the very basics of this race. It is the human race which is being played with. I find it unbelievable that Victoria has come down with a decision to the effect that these experiments may continue and that all of these arrangements will proceed in accordance with the report of this committee. The possibilities are endless. If doctors can perform these experiments on an embryo, ultimately they will certainly be able to play with the genes within an embryo. They will be able to interfere with the mental and physical capacity of the unborn child, and change the unborn child.

The Government has adopted the section of the report which says that the social parents of a child will be considered the natural parents of the child. That is fine. What will happen if both of those parents are killed in an accident? What will happen to this child? What will happen if the child perhaps becomes concerned about its actual parents? Will the child at the age of 20 be allowed to find the donor of the sperm or the donor of the egg? The problems that this raises are enormous, but they are factual problems. There is also a fundamental moral problem. The creation of a child is, I believe, a matter which ought not to be allowed to be played with by our doctors. I believe that the leaders of our community should take a stand on this matter. It is time for the leaders of the community to call for a halt. I am not a deeply religious person. In fact I suppose many people would say that I am not religious at all, but I say to the religious leaders of this nation: It is time for you to speak up. It is time that we heard from you. I say to the moral leaders of our community: It is time we heard from you. I say to the political leaders of this nation: It is time you stood up and condemned these procedures and called for a halt to them without delay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the opportunity to speak on the first reading of the Radiocommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill and cognate Bills. A first reading debate, of course, enables senators to speak on a variety of topics. I wish once again to bring before the Senate something which Senator Lewis spoke about earlier in the week. I refer to the report concerning a special investigation into the search and rescue activities associated with the ditching of an aircraft in Bass Strait on 17 July of this year. Earlier today I spoke about the difficulties senators have in getting reports and in having time to go through them and to make a comment on them. The other day that was not possible, but since then I have had time to look at the report of the Bureau of Air Safety, and as a Tasmanian who regularly flies across Bass Strait, it causes me grave concern and gives me a lot of worry for all the people who use commercial aircraft in travelling backwards and forwards from Tasmania and the mainland. It seems to me that the history of those involved in search and rescue, particularly with regard to Tasmania, and aircraft or ships which have been lost around Tasmania, has not been good. I think that in 1975 a search and rescue group was trying to find a ship. I cannot remember the name of that ship, but a group of survivors from that ship floated up and down the west and south-west coast of Tasmania for a considerable period before they managed to make it to the shore. All the time they were being looked for, but they were not seen. I believe that part of the provision was that the search and rescue group chose the wrong type of aircraft. The primary thing one needs when looking for people who are on the water is an aircraft from which one can look down easily. I believe that not all of the aircraft that were being used at that time were suitable from that point of view .
—High-wing?

—No. I think they had some Royal Australian Air Force aircraft which have a very sloping windscreen which makes it hard to see out. As I see this instance, there were two stages, the first being when the aircraft was in the air. Let me read to honourable senators the conclusion on page 16 of the report, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The assistance given to the pilot prior to the ditching was adequate in consideration of the short time available.

I would like to have the transcript of just what was said to that pilot. Let me tell honourable senators why. I was once flying across Bass Strait, very nearly in the same area but a little to the east of where this aircraft went into the water. I was flying in a light single-engine aircraft with some passengers when all of a sudden the weather came in from the south-east and became very nasty. It was raining. The clouds were down to a low level, and to maintain visibility I had to descend to quite a low level. I was somewhere near Wonthaggi according to the instruments which were in the aircraft, but I could not get to a beach or a paddock or something of that kind on which to land. So I made the decision to return and land at Flinders Island, even though that meant turning into a head wind of about 30 knots and flying at low level with a lot of cloud very low on the water.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you make it?

—I made it, but not, I must say, due to any help from the Department. Not once was I asked: 'Are you sure that you are heading in the right direction? Have you got any direction-finding equipment that would enable you to make sure you go by the shortest route to Flinders Island?' All that the staff did was to keep questioning me as to what my time of arrival would be, and matters of that nature. It seemed to me that on that day they were very much looking after their own skins in case I went into the water. Not once did they offer any real suggestion. I ask the Minister in charge of this matter about which I am now talking to table in the Senate the transcript of just what was said to that pilot. Was he told anything about changing petrol tanks? Was he told to keep flying as long as he possibly could? As I understand it, that aircraft had plenty of fuel and both engines were operative when it went into the water. Not once was he given any assistance or advice such as: 'Look, you are only a few miles from land; you are only a few miles from fairly large islands. Why do you not try to make it and keep the motors going?' That is not clear in the report. It is covered by one line which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The assistance given to the pilot prior to the ditching was adequate in consideration of the short time available.

Was it? That is a question that the Senate has every right to ask. With the main airlines there would be no doubt about the pilots' ability. Pilots in major airlines do not operate above their ability. I think in this case perhaps the pilot was operating a little above his ability.

What on earth will happen if a big aircraft ditches? I used to think it was a great idea to have life jackets in aircraft because I thought there would be some available procedure if a large aircraft went into Bass Strait. I shall read more from this report:
The SAR--
That is, search and rescue--
system does not require aircraft to be kept on standby. Suitable resources were available at the time of this accident.

The report states 'suitable resources', not 'unsuitable resources'. How can the resources have been suitable when an aircraft was not sent over the area in suitable time? We have to remember that on 17 July the survival time in Bass Strait would have been very limited because of the cold. It is not a matter of having until last light to get a rescue aircraft over the area but getting it there before a person dies of exposure. If one intends people to climb into a raft that may be dropped, one has to get there even more quickly, because it does not take long in the cold of Bass Strait to become so incapacitated as not to be able to climb into a raft without assistance.

I have some very grave questions to put before the Senate. Had the right action been taken in this case, at least one of those people would have survived. Perhaps the Department of Aviation should give some thought to trading in one or two of its aircraft for one that would be suitable for rescue. Some of the pilots, who are paid very high rates, on which I have commented before, could be rostered to be available. The Department need not necessarily pay them during weekends, but it could be one of the requirements of their employment that they be available at all times with a aircraft suitable in case something like this happens. An accident need not happen in Bass Strait. East-West Airlines now flies from Sydney to Hobart-down the coast-and its aircraft are over water for a considerable amount of time. We have to be ready for any necessary rescue action . Paragraph 4.12 on page 17 of the report states:
The deficiencies in performance which occurred were the result of working under pressure.

Surely at a time like this all systems must work, irrespective of the pressure. I hope that no aircraft I travel in goes into Bass Strait. I should be furious with the authorities if I were bobbing around in a lifejacket in the middle of Bass Strait knowing that inefficiency and the lack of a decent system is stopping me from being picked up. Why was a helicopter not thought of first? Why was the usual system not followed? The report states:
All recent Dropmaster training in the Melbourne SRR had been conducted on F27 aircraft. In the event that a GA-
that is, general aviation-
aircraft was required for supply dropping the situation could arise that the pilot had no experience in SAR-
that is, search and rescue-
operations, the Dropmaster was unfamiliar with supply dropping from the aircraft type and the ground crew were unfamiliar with preparing the aircraft for the supply dropping role.

That means that prior to checking out any other aircraft it was decided to get something completely unsuitable because other aircraft did not have any holes through which to drop the rafts. That decision was crazy. On page 10, following on from what I said, the report states:

No approach was made to airline operators at Melbourne Airport in respect of the availability of F27 aircraft for support purposes. The SARMC stated that this decision had been based on his past experience with response times for F27s , both in exercises and actual situations, and on his estimate that the response time would have been too long in this case.
Later advice from the two operators concerned indicated that each had an F27 on the ground at Melbourne at that time. A crew was also immediately available, having signed on at 1445--
a suitable time--
in preparation for a scheduled departure . . .

That would have been all right. The whole system of search and rescue in this country is shown by this report to be faulty. I do not have much more time available in which to comment, but I believe that none of the airline operators would be happy with the search and rescue procedures adopted in this case. I am sure none of the people of Tasmania would want this kind of operation to be in effect if they were involved in an incident in Bass Strait. What is the good of the Department having all its aircraft at millions of dollars expense if there is not to be some system whereby in an emergency at least one of them is available in the areas where these kinds of situations are most likely. I am not at all satisfied with the situation at the moment. I call upon the Department to table in the Senate the transcript of the entire tape recording regarding this incident so that we can form a judgment by ourselves. I also call on the Department to upgrade its search and rescue operations so that they do not become search operations only.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
Mr President, I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1983

This Bill is a companion measure to the Radiocommunications Bill 1983. It provides for certain transitional arrangements and for consequential amendments to a number of other Acts, to bring the general scheme of the Radiocommunications Bill 1983 into operation.

In particular, Clause 5 of the Bill provides that any licences issued under the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905 continue in force after the commencement of the Bill. Such licences cannot be renewed and new licences will have to be taken out under the provisions of the Radiocommunications Bill. The Clause also provides that certificates issued under the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905 can be deemed to be Certificates of Proficiency under the Radiocommunications Bill.
Consequential amendments to other legislation are set out in the schedule to this Bill.

The most significant of these consequential amendments is the creation of a new section 6A in the Broadcasting and Television Act. This is an offence provision prohibiting unauthroised operation of a broadcasting or television station.
Under the existing regime, unlicensed operation of a broadcasting or television station is an offence under the Wireless Telegraphy Act.
The new offence provision is closely modelled on the equivalent offence of operating an unauthorised radiocommunications transmitter under clause 23 of the Radiocommunications Bill.
The effect, therefore, is simply to create two parellel and specific offences where one very wide offence exists at present.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS TAXES COLLECTION BILL 1983

This Bill and the associated Bills which I will introduce shortly will replace the Radiocommunications Licence Fees Act 1982. That Act will be repealed under the provisions of the Radiocommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1982.

Fees for radiocommunications services are presently levied under the Radiocommunications Licence Fees Act. It was necessary for these fees to be levied as taxes under that Act in order to place the fees beyond possible legal challenge. This principle also enables the Government to apply a ''royalty'' concept to radiocommunication licence fees.
Consequently the financial impact of this Bill and the related tax measures will in themselves be no different to the current situation.

A royalty is appropriate because the radio frequency spectrum is a scarce natural resource which is in steadily increasing demand. The cost of using this resource in some cases bears little relation to the value of it to the Licensee. Application of the royalty concept can be used as a pricing mechanism to spread the demand for valuable portions of the spectrum and thus increase the overall efficiency of use of the spectrum.

In replacing the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905, the Radiocommunications Bill will provide for the grant of frequency reservation certificates, receiver licences, temporary permits, test permits and transmitter licences.

The Constitution requires that laws imposing taxation deal solely with the imposition of taxation and only with one subject of taxation. It is therefore necessary that separate Bills authorise the various charges for services provided for by the Radiocommunications Bill.

The purpose of the Bill is to provide for the collection of those charges. The Bill establishes clearly that all users of the spectrum including statutory corporations of the Commonwealth or Territories, will be liable for those charges.
Regulations may be made under this Bill to specify the manner of payment as well as the remission or refund of tax in certain circumstances.

The Government has given consideration to incorporating radiocommunications licence fees in schedules to the minor Acts rather than as regulations as is the current situation. However the Government considers that it is appropriate for fees to continue to be imposed by Regulations because new radiocommunications services are appearing constantly and provision has to be made promptly to authorise the issue of licences and the charging of licence fees for them. To amend the relevant act to cater for this situation would result in needless impositions on the time of the Parliament. Should Parliament have reservations about taxes set by Regulation, I remind the Senate that those Regulations would be subject to disallowance in the usual manner.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (FREQUENCY RESERVATION CERTIFICATE TAX) BILL 1983

The issue of frequency reservation certificates to facilitate forward planning in the use of the radio frequency spectrum is authorised by clause 21 of the Radiocommunications Bill. This Bill imposes a tax on the grant of a frequency reservation certificate. Details of the amount of tax for such certificates are to be prescribed by regulation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (RECEIVER LICENCE TAX) BILL 1983

This Bill imposes a tax on the grant of a radiocommunications receiver licence issued under clause 38 of the Radiocommunications Bill. Details of the amount of tax for specified types of receiver licences are to be prescribed by regulation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (TEMPORARY PERMIT TAX) BILL 1983

This Bill imposes a tax on the grant of a temporary permit issued under clause 35 of the Radiocommunications Bill. Details of the amount of tax for temporary permits are to be prescribed by regulation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (TEST PERMIT TAX) BILL 1983

The issue of test permits for sub-standard transmitters is authorised by clause 10 of the Radiocommunications Bill. This Bill imposes a tax on the grant of a test permit. Details of the amount of tax for test permits are to be prescribed by regulation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (TRANSMITTER LICENCE TAX) BILL 1983
This Bill imposes a tax on the grant of a transmitter licence issued under clause 24 of the Radiocommunications Bill.
Details of the amount of tax for the many classes of transmitter licences are to be prescribed by regulation.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STEEL INDUSTRY AUTHORITY BILL 1983BOUNTY (STEEL MILL PRODUCTS) BILL 1983BOUNTY (HIGH ALLOY STEEL PRODUCTS) BILL 1983

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate was adjourned I made the observation that Senator Button, in his second reading speech, observed that the purpose of an injection of $350m was to provide for the maintenance of a viable and efficient steel industry. How anybody can talk about the maintenance of viability and efficiency by the payment of $350m of taxpayers's money escapes me. If the steel industry were efficient, it would be viable and would not want open-ended assistance from and at the expense of the rest of the community. At least, by providing bounties rather than tariffs, the Government has had the decency, or perhaps indecency, depending on how you look at it, of spreading the cost of the burden of the failings of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd onto all taxpayers and not just end users. Senator Button goes on in his second reading speech to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The domestic demand situation was exacerbated by an excess in world steel making capacity leading to a significant increase in import competition and strong price competition which, in turn, placed further pressures on profitability.

I draw the attention of the Senate to the expression 'significant increase in import competition'. With the exception of high alloy steel goods since 1980-81, imports have increased their share of the market by only two or three percentage points. It ought not to be forgotten that as at December 1982 local producers supplied about 95 per cent of the local market's requirements of hot rolled flat products, bars, rods and structurals and that their share of most other markets was of the order of 80 per cent, or in most cases slightly above this-with, as I said earlier, the exception of high alloy products, in regard to which the local producers' share represented a little under 60 per cent of total domestic demand . In fact, imports represent only a very minor part of domestic market supplies and considerably less than the volume of the same goods that are exported by BHP . While, of course, the price level of imports will have had some influence on BHP's pricing arrangements, and hence profitability, it is not a significant influence on production levels, which themselves normally dictate unit cost, particularly in such industries as the steel industry, which has enormous fixed capital costs.

Besides all the factors relating to its own incompetent performance, the most significant problem for the Australian steel industry is not the levels of imports but the sharp fall in domestic demand. The Industries Assistance Commission report states:

In the six months ended December 1982, aggregate domestic demand for goods under reference was more than 20 per cent below that in the corresponding period of 1981. The importance of this decrease in demand relative to the increase in the volume of imports is highlighted by the fact that, even if there had been a complete embargo on all competitive imports of goods under reference in the six months to the end of December 1982 and all domestic requirements had been satisfied by local producers, local producers output would still have been nearly 13 per cent below the levels achieved in the six months to the end of December 1981.

The reduction in domestic sales can be overwhelmingly attributed to the decline in total domestic demand. For instance, between the periods December 1980 to December 1981, and December 1982 to December 1983, sales of hot rolled products declined by an estimated 28 per cent because of the decline in total demand, whereas the decline attributable to increased import penetration was only an estimated 2 per cent.

The Australian economy seemed to be bubbling along in 1981, with real gross domestic product increasing by about 4 per cent, unemployment falling from 6.2 per cent to 5.3 per cent, inflation dipping from 10.1 per cent to 9.4 per cent and real gross fixed capital expenditure increasing by around 12 per cent. However there were flashing lights on the steel industry horizon which, I would have thought, the local industry should have recognised. If it did recognise them it should have prepared to accommodate the changing circumstances.

Perhaps it is unreasonable in hindsight to be critical of those who did not anticipate the world and domestic events which had such an influence on our mining industry in 1981-82 but there were already ominous signs for the steel industry. Some 31 per cent of the steel making capacity of member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development lay idle in both 1980 and 1981. The European Economic Community was particularly depressed, with about 37 per cent of steel capacity idle at the end of 1981, and little prospect of improvement. Employment and profitability in the steel making industry had been falling. More than a fifth of the EEC's steel making jobs were lost in the five years to 1980. Employment in the French steel industry fell by 40 per cent and in the United Kingdom by 33 per cent. Steel employment in the United States fell by 13 per cent, and in Japan, the third largest and most efficient steel producer, it fell by 16 per cent over the same period. Profitability was also down dramatically. I cannot imagine how the Australian steel industry expected to be insulated from such excess capacity, which would inevitably lead to significantly reduced prices, unless there were a view within the steel industry that it need have no concern for real and free outside commercial influences.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., pursuant to sessional order, I call on questions without notice.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Territories and Local Government. I refer to the recent newspaper report that the General Assembly of the United Nations has approved a request by the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs for a United Nations mission to observe the Cocos (Keeling) Islands vote next year on its political future. What role will the United Nations play in the act? What method will be used to ensure that the result is a true reflection of the wishes of the people, bearing in mind that there are three options from which they will have to choose? What system of voting will be used? When will the act of self-determination take place? Will Mr John Clunies-Ross and his family be excluded from voting? Does the Government plan to allocate funds to promote acceptance of any of the three proposals? If so, which one?

—Senator Reid has raised a number of detailed questions which clearly require specific answers by the Minister for Territories and Local Government whom I represent in this place. Consequently, I will have those matters immediately referred to the Minister if he is in Canberra to see that Senator Reid gets a reply to those questions before the Senate rises.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport aware of the alarmingly high incidence of train derailments in Tasmania and of the estimates by Tasmanian rail unions that there have been 73 such derailments in the last 12 months? Will the Minister undertake to provide figures on the incidence of derailments in Tasmania? Will he seek to determine the primary cause of these accidents and their cost to the community? Can the Minister also confirm whether log trains are disproportionately involved in derailments in Tasmania?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hearn has raised a number of questions about derailments which have taken place in Tasmania over the last 12 months. Yes, I am aware of the fact that statements have been made suggesting an alarming increase in derailments in Tasmania. I understand that the Minister for Transport has already expressed his concern regarding this high and above average incidence of derailments and, in fact, made some reference to the matter when the Australian National Railways Commission Bill was debated in the House of Representatives on 16 November last.

ANSWER.PARA: As the Minister whom I represent in this place indicated, specific provisions in that legislation will give power to the Minister for Transport specifically to require such information from State railway systems, particularly those where the Commonwealth has assumed certain responsibilities as a result of changes in the status of the railway systems in South Australia and Tasmania. The Government will be introducing provisions to strengthen the Minister's authority in these matters.

As to the latter part of the question raised by Senator Hearn, I believe that log trains do cause a disproportionately high number of these derailments. The Minister for Transport will be specifically examining that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Resources and Energy to his reply to Senator Reynolds at Question Time earlier this week regarding the Greenvale nickel mine wherein he informed the Senate of the Government's decision to exempt the Greenvale project from excise on fuel oil to an amount of $1.5m and suggested that the Queensland Government reduce rail freight to the same amount. I ask: Is the Minister aware that in relation to the Greenvale nickel mine the Queensland Government has assisted the initial construction of the project by agreeing to guarantee part of the capital required; has paid to the project's lenders up to the present time $49.6m under the guarantee debt restructuring arrangements and under the same arrangements agreed to enter into a contingent liability of $77m? Is the Minister also aware that the Queensland Government has supported the oil to coal conversion program of the project under which, in the recent profitable period of the project, funds totalling $45m were directed to further capital works and that the Government has provided direct assistance to the company in negotiations--
—Order! A lot of information is being given in the question.

—In view of the fact that the present relief provided by the Federal Government is on an impost imposed by the Federal Government, does not the Minister agree that the concession given is but small bikkies compared with the Queensland Government's contribution?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to the question is no. Unlike some honourable senators, I will give reasons why I am saying no. Some honourable senators do not seem to think they are obliged to give reasons for whatever they do here. I am aware that some guarantees given by the Queensland Government have been called upon because the project has not generated sufficient cash flow to meet its obligations. I am also well aware of the fact-indeed I reported it to the Senate-that some $60m was spent by the company in building the 240 kilometre railway, providing the locomotives and the rolling stock and given as a present to the Queensland State Government railways. I think the amounts that the Queensland Government has underwirtten on behalf of the company and what the company has given to the Queensland State Government railways probably balance out fairly well.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth excise which will now be waived in one way or another, equal to $1 1/2m at present production levels, was a tax. In conceptually the same way , the Queensland Government imposes a tax on the project through the profit component of its rail freight charges. That, according to the estimates supplied to me, amounts to about $1 1/2m. So, the Commonwealth has removed a prospective Commonwealth tax of $1 1/2m. The Government's view is that the Queensland Government ought to do the same thing and remove its hidden rail tax. It just so happens that the amount is about equal.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROPOSED REFERENDUM: FUNDING OF YES CASE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Has the Government received any communications from the Opposition and the Australian Democrats relating to the funding and promotion of the Yes case in the referendum proposed for February 1984.?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only formal communications that the Government has received on these matters are, firstly, a letter of 13 December from Senator Macklin, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, in which he states:

ANSWER.PARA: I have discussed at length with my colleagues the propositions you put to me earlier today.

Our unanimous position is that the funding for advertising campaigns over and above the standard cases prepared by the Electoral Office should be equal for both the 'Yes' campaign and the 'No' campaign.
That means no additional funding or an equal appropriation to either the 'Yes' or 'No' campaign.
That was followed by the statement:
We will be voting in the Senate in accordance with this decision.

That, of course, remains as always to be seen. So far as the Liberal Party of Australia is concerned, on 6 December Mr Hawke received a rather more interesting communication from Mr Peacock, the Leader of the Opposition, which read:
Thank you for your letter of 5 December seeking my assistance in the process of promoting community awareness about the referendums.
To the best of my knowledge and recall joint appearances have not occurred in the past and, after careful consideration, I do not believe they would be of assistance on this occasion.

I am planning to promote such awareness but, as I informed the Attorney-General when he approached me on the matter, I do not intend appearing on joint platforms with Government speakers, nor do I wish my photograph, my signature, or my Party's logo to be associated with whatever form of advertising you or your Government may deem to be appropriate.

I believe that this is indicative of the co-operative attitude and the constructive commitment to constitutional reform which has been brought to this whole process by the Opposition parties since the outset. The real nature of their commitment to constructive, constitutional reform in this country is thus starkly demonstrated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Prime Minister . It concerns support for exporters who wish to exhibit at the Louisiana Exhibition next year. On 29 November I asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister a question without notice on the Government's intention in regard to support for the Louisiana Exhibition to be held from 12 May to 11 November 1984. In view of the pressing need of intending exhibiters-not to mention the host city-to know what the Government's intentions are, will the Minister provide this important information either now or certainly before the Senate rises?

—I do not recall the detail of the previous question. I recall that it was asked. I apologise to Senator Archer for not having provided an answer already. I will seek to do so before the completion of this session of the Parliament which I should indicate to the Senate might be some time in the future.

—My question is to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. Has the Minister seen the National Times coloured supplement promoting health and fitness which features a photo of a naked woman' s bottom on the cover, which cover could be described as an upmarket and expensive promotion of prurience? In the light of the guidelines to the media contained in the booklet 'Fair Exposure', launched by the Minister and Mr Macphee early last week, could the Minister comment on the unnecessary over- exposure of this cover and its blatant sexism in distracting readers from the serious and significant contents inside the supplement?
—I did see the supplement on health and fitness. I think it is important that-
—Go on, show us.

—Not all of my colleagues share Senator Crowley's assessment of the front cover, I have to say. There seems to be considerable enthusiasm for it on my right. I think it is important that these sorts of supplements are published. I think that they do assist in raising the health standards of the community. Generally speaking, I think it is a useful sort of publication. But I agree with Senator Crowley's view that the cover used part of a woman's body in a way that was unnecessary and not related to the subject of the publication. There are obviously a variety of views about the front page of the supplement. But clearly it is the sort of thing that gives offence to some people, at least, in our community. I will make sure that the National Times has received a copy of the media guidelines 'Fair Exposure'.

—My question is to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. I draw the Minister's attention to the Prime Minister's recent statement that the education policy of the Government is the policy which was taken by that Party to the election. Since that policy stated explicitly that moves will be made to phase down and cut out support for some children in some non-government schools, I ask the Minister: Is the education policy of the Government the education policy it took to the election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that Senator Baume would be as familiar by now as I am with the details of Australian Labor Party education policy. It was the policy that we took to the election to achieve some redistribution within the non-government school sector and to fund non-government schools on the basis of need. Our first Budget represented our first steps towards implementing that policy. But it was also the policy that we took to the election, to establish a new way of measuring the needs of non-government schools by getting the Commonwealth Schools Commission to report on a community standard. Once that happens, the needs of all non-government schools will be assessed in the light of that community standard. So it may well be that all existing non-government schools will still be entitled to some form of support under the needs based policy.

ANSWER.PARA: But as Senator Baume well knows, until that new way of measuring the needs of schools is established, there can be no specific indication about further reductions in funding. However, wherever a non-government school of any kind falls below the established community standard, it will continue to justify and receive Commonwealth recurrent grants.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The Minister' s answer did not make the matter clear. Did not the policy which the Labor Party took to the election state explicitly that support for some children would be phased out over several years?

—No, it did not state that. It stated that schools that continued to operate at a certain high level would have their funding phased out; but incorporated into that policy statement was a recognition that schools may change the way in which they operate so as to remain within the community standard and continue to attract Commonwealth grants. So there was a very clear implication in the policy that it would be possible for schools to remain within the community standard and to receive Commonwealth grants accordingly. There was also an implication that if schools continued to choose to operate well above that standard, a phasing out process would continue. But those questions have not been answered. They have not been answered by the schools themselves.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. In the light of a report in this morning's Age to the effect that following the unsuccessful legal action of a Russian family to stay in Australia, the Government is now proposing to expel them, will the Minister explain the current situation in order to reassure the Senate that no action will be taken which would put the family at risk of human rights abuses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the Press articles this morning, I contacted the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, who has provided me with the following information: First, it is important to realise that the Feingold family did not come to Australia from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. They left the USSR in 1980 and settled in Israel, where, under Israeli law, they were entitled to Israeli citizenship. After eight months in Israel, the family moved to Greece. In May 1982 they applied for entry to Australia on both refugee and humanitarian grounds but were refused by the previous Government after full consideration of their claims. Apparently the Feingold family then decided to take matters into their own hands. They arrived on a Singapore Airlines flight on 9 December 1983 with one-way tickets to Noumea but without visas. They sought permission to enter and remain in Australia, but after an opportunity to explain their circumstances further, permission was refused. The Feingolds then availed themselves of recourse to the Federal Court of Australia and subsequently appealed to the Full Federal Court, but their application was dismissed and their departure from Australia has been arranged, as was reported in the Press this morning.

ANSWER.PARA: An important aspect of this case is the serious implications for the orderly management of the migration program and Australia's large scale visitor intake. Having been rejected for entry to Australia, the family deliberately sought to circumvent Australia's immigration procedures. A great deal of pressure has been brought to bear on officials and others, through emotional methods and others which are not central to the matters at hand. The Australian Government, and previous Australian governments, have not allowed people in these circumstances to impose their will on Australia. This view was endorsed by the Full Bench of the Federal Court. They could, for instance, have appealed against the earlier rejection while in Athens and, indeed, if there are additional matters which they wish to have taken into account, the way remains open for them to raise such matters from overseas. But the Australian Government, of whatever persuasion, cannot allow people to circumvent our immigration laws in this way. It is for this reason that following the rejection of the Federal Court appeal, the Government has acted in the way that it has.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Does the Minister recall my asking her a question on Wednesday of last week on the subject of the Australian Film Archive, in which I reminded her that she had made a statement in the Senate on 10 November that a decision by the Government on the future funding and administration arrangements for the Archive was expected shortly? Does the Minister recall that I also asked her whether a decision on this matter had been made and, if not, when it would be finalised, and whether consideration was also being given to similar matters in relation to the sound archives? Does the Minister recall that she said that she would take up the matter urgently with her colleague the Minister and that she hoped to have a reply for the Senate before the end of 'this week', which was last week? Does the Minister have a reply yet?

—I do recall Senator Martin's questions on this matter and my undertakings. I did pursue the matter with the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Unfortunately, I must apologise to Senator Martin because I have not got yet from the Minister the answer she is looking for, that is, a statement about what form the protection of the film and sound archives will take. I am advised by the Minister that at the moment a large number of alternative possibilities are under active consideration. The Minister wishes the Senate to be assured that effective action will be taken to protect the Australian Film Archive and the sound archive. I will continue to endeavour to get a more detailed undertaking than that before the Senate rises. I apologise to Senator Martin that I have not got a more specific statement available yet.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. It has been suggested in Tasmania that wood chip export licences might be extended by the Government without an environmental impact statement being required. Can the Minister assure me that the Government's policy will be strictly adhered to and that we will insist, to the Tasmanian Government and the wood chip industry, on an environmental impact statement before further wood chip export licences are approved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Tasmanian Government has sought the co-operation of the Commonwealth to expedite short term extensions of wood chip export approvals for Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Limited and H. C. Sleigh Limited to assist this important industry in current sales negotiations. Discussions have taken place between the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment and the Minister for Primary Industry and also the Tasmanian Minister for Forests. These discussions have been aimed at ensuring that all factors, including environmental and National Estate issues, are taken into account in reaching decisions on both the long term development of the pulp-wood industry and the short term export arrangements.

ANSWER.PARA: It has been proposed that current APPM and H. C. Sleigh approvals be extended to 1988 and that during 1984 and 1985 a comprehensive examination, including an environmental impact statement, be made of Tasmania's pulpwood industry and associated foresty operations. The environmental impact statement would include consideration of the effect of logging in places listed on the register of the National Estate. This environmental impact statement process would be completed prior to the expiry of the recurrent APPM and H. C. Sleigh licences and would allow recommendations arising from the environmental impact statement to be applied to the renewed approvals if necessary. Ministers from both the Federal and Tasmanian governments are considering this proposal currently, and it is hoped that an announcement can be made soon.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN SECURITY INTELLIGENCE ORGANISATION: PRODUCTION OF DOCUMENTS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney- General to an answer he gave to a question on 8 December about the decision of the High Court of Australia in relation to the Ananda Marga prosecutions. The Attorney-General in his answer said:

QUESTION.PARA: It is not my intention to object to the production of any documents that ASIO may prove to have that bear upon the subject matter of this trial. . . . That has always been my position in relation to the production of documents.

I ask: Why, in these circumstances and in the light of his position, did the Government decide on or about 1 June to withhold from a Mr David Combe certain most decisive documents and allow others to be seen only by his counsel? I ask the Attorney whether he is able to see any double standards in these actions or is it that the Prime Minister holds a different view from that of the Attorney?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is well known that Senator Lewis's aspirations to legal distinction cannot be great and there is further proof of that in the question he has just asked. There is no proper comparison, of course, between a situation where a court hearing and determining an important criminal matter seeks the production of documents and is prepared to order that, and on the other hand a situation where a royal commissioner chooses, in the exercise of his discretion and in the proper conduct of royal commission proceedings, to make certain sensitive documents not available to one of the parties. It is an entirely familiar feature of court practice for the court itself to determine, when sensitive security documents are concerned, who shall have access to them.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the matter of my statement about the production of documents to the High Court, I have made my position perfectly clear. I would not rely upon any threshold absolute refusal either to confirm or deny the existence of security documents and, if asked by the High Court to supply such documents in order that the High Court might determine for itself their relevance to the proceedings and determine in turn itself to whom these documents if relevant should be made available, there is no inconsistency whatsoever between those two situations. I am very surprised that Senator Lewis, even with his minimal degree of legal education, experience and practice, is unable to see that point.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Attorney-General. It refers to today's news that the New Zealand Government has introduced legislation to stop people avoiding parking fines by registering their cars in their dogs' names. Is the Attorney aware of any similar practices in use in Australia? If so, can he advise whether this practice has bitten into the potential revenue of State governments and whether there is any evidence of any discrimination against any particular breed of dog, such as the brown dog? Would such a situation validate the need for legislation here to allow these dogs right of appeal through an animal rights commission which could perhaps be initiated by Senator Chipp? Alternatively, does the Attorney anticipate legislation being introduced in the States to cover this practice, or could that action be seen as barking up the wrong tree?

—I will not emulate one of my less distinguished predecessors in this office and say 'woof, woof' in answer to that question. But what do I say? As I am sure the Select Committee on Animal Welfare will establish, even under Senator Georges's chairmanship, a dog's life in this country is not always a happy one although, of course, from time to time there are some splendid moments when the species does get its own back, as occurred recently, of course, in Kingaroy. I took it that Senator Elstob was in fact proposing anti-discrimination legislation for dogs. That kind of legislation is appropriate for the States traditionally rather than for the Commonwealth although being, as I suppose some honourable senators opposite would describe me , a mad dog centralist I would, of course, be receptive to any suggestion, particularly given the state of affairs Senator Elstob described in New Zealand, of entering into a bilateral treaty in order to acquire power under the external affairs power to pass national legislation of this kind.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is it a fact that with only six working days remaining before the Christmas break, private hospitals have not been notified of their categories under Medicare? Is this information now desperately needed not only by the hospitals but also by their patients? Is the Minister aware that some patients, particularly those insured for the basic table and booked for major operations in private hospitals in early February, are extremely concerned that they could be faced with payments they cannot afford as they have no way of knowing what insurance fund refund or government subsidy will be available for their chosen hospital? Why has the Minister not come to this important decision? Is this an example of the efficiency we can expect in the future under the new Medicare system?

—Yes, I believe that there are six working days until Christmas. I am not aware whether all or any of the private hospitals have been notified of their categories under the Medicare scheme although, four days ago in Launceston , it seemed that a couple of them were aware because they rang me up to make sure that the category they have been notified about was right. I will find out from the Minister for Health what effect that will have on patients if, as Senator Walters stated, the decision has not been made. I think Senator Walters' s statement about patients all around the country being anxious to know about this is typical of her rhetoric. I doubt whether most patients in the country know anything about categorisation or what hospitals they would go into and what category they are likely to be. All I can say is that the category of the vast majority of hospitals at which people will have the sort of surgery about which Senator Walters is undoubtedly talking will be the appropriate category. People will get a return under Medicare and under the voluntary health insurance schemes appropriate to the procedure to be applied.
—I raise a supplementary question, Mr President. Senator Grimes has rather ridiculed the fact that patients are interested. Medicare private has informed one patient that it can do nothing about-
—Order! Can I have a supplementary question?

—It is. The question I am putting to Senator Grimes is that Medicare has already instructed a Tasmanian patient that it is unable to tell him what his return will be for quite a large operation in a private hospital in Melbourne.
—Order! That is not a question.
—Will the Minister please answer the query for this patient?
—If the Minister considers it a supplementary question, he may answer it.

—Senator Walters asked whether I was aware that the Minister had not made a decision or notified hospitals. My answer to that was no. I will find out the answer. I will find out from the Minister how soon the hospitals which have not been notified will be notified. My answer, with a litle bit of hyperbole, to the rhetorical part of Senator Walters's question would not have been necessary if she had not tacked that part on to her question. Of course I treat this matter as a serious one. Of course I will get the answers to Senator Walters as soon as I can.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS: MIDDLE EAST PEACE VOTE

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It concerns a vote that took place at the United Nations. Before I ask the question may I say that I had some difficulty in searching out the information. I rang the United Nations section of the Department of Foreign Affairs and there was no answer on four phones. I trust that the Minister will be able to give me the information that I seek. Did a vote take place at the United Nations on an international conference in search of peace for the Middle East? Is it a fact that four nations voted against the proposition? Was Australia one of those nations? If so, why did Australia vote against such a motion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that, together with Canada, the United States of America and Israel, Australia voted against a United Nations General Assembly resolution calling for an international peace conference on the Middle East to consider further the Palestinian question. Fifteen other countries abstained. The resolution backed the call for a conference exclusively to the Geneva Conference on the question of Palestine, held in August-September this year, without reference to Security Council resolutions 242 and 338. Australia did not participate in the Geneva Conference but attended as an observer.

ANSWER.PARA: The resolution laid down guidelines for an international conference on the Middle East in terms which were quite unbalanced and in effect sought to pre- empt matters which would be discussed at such a conference. It also sought to enable the Palestine Liberation Organisation to participate on the same basis as states. It described the Geneva Conference as having made an important and positive contribution to the peace process and sought to have governments endorse the declaration of that Conference. Honourable senators should be aware that there would be many governments which would have serious reservations about endorsing the declaration.

If there is to be a serious effort to reach a solution to the Middle East dispute through the mechanism of an international conference, it should be obvious that the enabling resolution should not seek itself to dictate the terms of a settlement. Moreover, the initiative to convene a conference should, in the view of the Government, be supported by all the major parties. In this case it was quite clear that Israel and the United States did not support the resolution in the General Assembly. For these reasons, which indicated that the proposal as formulated in the resolution would not be helpful towards negotiation of a Middle East settlement, the Australian delegation voted against the resolution.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Social Security. It follows the information that he provided to the Senate yesterday after Question Time. During Estimates committee hearings this year did the Minister make it quite clear that special funds for expenditure in relation to Government programs were to be used, at the direction of the Minister for Finance, to pay for the recruitment and training of staff required for the proposed assets test? How is it that at least 369 new recruits, all of whom are from Victoria, are being paid from the principal salaries appropriation of the Department? Can the Minister explain why payments were not effected in the manner he outlined at the Estimates committee?

—Like previous Ministers for Social Security in this place, I do not attempt to keep a daily or weekly tab on just what appropriation what money comes out of. But I appreciate that the question is an important one and I will attempt as soon as possible to get for the honourable senator, from the appropriate section of my Department and probably from the Minister for Finance, the reasons for the allocation of that amount of money from that vote.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NORTH WEST SHELF NATURAL GAS PROJECT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to comments in the Age editorial of Monday, 12 December, suggesting that new foreign ownership and control arrangements proposed for the North West Shelf natural gas project should be accepted by the Commonwealth Government? Have these new equity arrangements been discussed with the Commonwealth by the project joint venturers ? Can the Minister advise the Senate of the Government's attitude towards these proposed arrangements?

—Yes, I have seen the report in the Age newspaper. The second question asks whether the proposal has been discussed with the Commonwealth. In a formal sense it has not but notice of intention, or of the likelihood of proceedings in this way, has been given in discussions with me and I assume in discussions with the Treasurer, as well. Some of the joint venturers have previously discussed with me the possibility of this happening. As to the Government's attitude, that of course is, as Senator Childs suggested by directing the question to me as Minister representing the Treasurer, primarily a matter for the Treasurer to decide but I expect that in a project as important as this the Treasurer will take it to Cabinet anyway. That has not yet been done so I cannot forecast with any certainty what the Government is likely to do. However, given the importance of this project, its size and the likely difficulties of attracting sufficient Australian capital to build up the 33 per cent Australian equity if the proposed restructuring goes ahead and the capital required to build that up to 50 per cent, I think it can be safely stated that the proposal will be viewed very sympathetically by the Government and probably agreed to by it although naturally we would prefer, if sufficient capital could be obtained locally, to have a higher Australian equity in the project. My expectation is that if there seems to be no way that can be achieved the Government will approve the proposal outlined in the Age a couple of days ago. I stress that this is to be taken as my opinion and not as a firm statement of Government policy.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the undertaking by the Minister for Foreign Affairs to supply to the Victoria Police the names of 12 Australian Secret Intelligence Service agents who took part in the bungled training exercise at the Melbourne Sheraton Hotel two weeks ago. I ask the Minister, firstly, why has his undertaking not been carried out so that the police can interview those involved and take any necessary action against them if it is shown that there are breaches of the law; secondly, has the Foreign Minister now imposed or proposed some unacceptable and improper conditions on the delivery of such information to the Victorian Government and the Victoria Police; and thirdly, has the Hawke Government now abandoned the long-standing principle that there should be equality before the law and will now provide special privileges for some wrong-doers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs instructed the Director- General of ASIS yesterday to provide to the Victoria Police the names they are seeking of those involved in the Sheraton Hotel incident. In conveying the names to the Victoria Police, the Director-General was asked to refer to Mr Hayden's request that the names be handled by the police on a confidential basis and to the undertaking made in a communication from the Victorian Premier that the names would not be revealed for any purpose other than to enable the police to pursue investigations and to consider charges. I add that there are excellent national security reasons for that confidentiality condition being imposed in those terms, which ought not to inhibit the effectiveness of the law enforcement process. It is not the desire of this Government to inhibit that process in any way.

ANSWER.PARA: After this instruction was given yesterday, but before it was carried out, legal advice was apparently received by the individuals in question to the effect that persons whose names were to be revealed to the police should be given 24 hours notice of the intention to disclose their identities. Legal advice of that kind was given to them and, I understand, to Mr Hayden. This would allow the persons concerned to exercise such rights as they might have under the law to seek a suppression order in relation to the initial giving of the names to the police. I do not make any comment as to whether such an application for a suppression order would be likely to succeed. Accordingly, in response to that request made on behalf of the individuals concerned, that they have this time to seek an injunction should they be minded to do so, action to convey the names to the Victoria Police has been suspended for 24 hours as from 8.30 this morning. The Chief Commissioner of the Victoria Police has been informed of this position by the Director-General of ASIS.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen a report in yesterday's Age newspaper that international reserves reached a record level in November; further, that exports rose by $124m last month and that the improvement came from manufactured exports? Would the Minister agree that those figures indicate quite clearly that the success of the Government's economic policies are not due solely to the breaking of the drought?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen that report in the Age. I also have some other figures which have been extracted from the original Australian Bureau of Statistics bulletin. The report certainly shows, as the final part of Senator Coleman's question suggested, that the recovery in Australia is much more broadly based than that which has occurred in the agricultural sector; although, on the most recent estimates I saw, if I remember correctly, the agricultural sector alone is likely to add about 2 per cent to total real gross domestic product. But it now seems that real GDP growth-this is on a year on year basis- in the non-farm sector as well is likely to be in excess of 2 per cent. But the only area, on the information available so far, in which a recovery has not yet taken place appears to be private investment. That is not unexpected. Indeed, if history is a guide, it is entirely predictable that private investment will lag behind other indicators of economic recovery and economic growth.

ANSWER.PARA: Many people will find particularly pleasing the figures in relation to the manufacturing sector, to which Senator Coleman referred. In that sector-these are the figures for the four months from July to October 1983, compared with the same four months in 1982-the value of exports has increased from $1,435m to $1, 721m. That is an increase of almost 20 per cent. Given that it is spread over a four-month period and not just a single month, there is little likelihood of a serious seasonal distortion being involved in that, or one-off events. It is particularly gratifying to see that there has been--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Can the Minister either be offered resuscitation or be asked to speak in a louder voice? We really cannot hear what he is saying.
—The Minister might keep that in mind.

—I am sorry. I was just saying that the value of manufactured exports for the first four months of the current financial year, compared with the same four months of the previous financial year, has increased from $1,435m to $1,721m. That represents an increase of almost 20 per cent over quite a prolonged period. That indicates a very strong recovery in the manufacturing sector as well, which is something that the Government and I am sure Senator Coleman and the community in general will find particularly good news.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Yesterday I asked the Minister whether investigators of the Commonwealth Department of Health were involved in certain timekeeping activities in the waiting rooms of doctors' surgeries in Launceston. Senator Grimes replied at the end of Question Time yesterday that no Health Department officer had entered a doctor's surgery in any way or behaved in any way in the manner alleged. I now ask the Minister whether the person who is alleged to have carried out those activities was a member, representative or agent of the Australian Federal Police.

—I sought information concerning the matter raised by Senator Watson. I was informed, and my brief was, that in fact the investigation was conducted by officers of the Australian Department of Health; that no other Department was involved. In the light of Senator Watson's question I will seek further information and check that. If I find that any officer of the Australian Federal Police, or anyone else other than someone from the Department of Health, was involved I will certainly have something to say not only to Senator Watson but also to someone else. But it is my information that in fact the investigation was conducted by officers of the Department of Health and that no other department was involved, but I will certainly check that.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. I refer the Minister to the frequent liquidations of travel agencies and to the consequent loss to and disruption of the holidays of many consumers. I ask: Has the Government received a proposition from the Australian Federation of Travel Agents advocating the inception of a travel industry fund to be available to consumers in these instances? Can the Minister indicate what the Government's response is to this proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague, Mr Brown, has informed me that there has been considerable effort at both Commonwealth and State level to ensure early implementation of the Government's travel agents policy, which in essence is to encourage the States to introduce uniform legislation for the registration of all travel agents in Australia. This has involved consultations between Commonwealth and State tourism and consumer affairs authorities and the formation of a joint Commonwealth-State working group to propose draft provisions which could be adapted by States or Territories for any proposed travel agent licensing legislation. A discussion paper which was widely circulated by the working group in September proposes uniform State and Territory legislation for the licensing of travel agents with administration being undertaken at the State or territorial level. The Commonwealth would legislate for a national compensation fund to compensate consumers suffering losses as a result of travel agents failing to account.

ANSWER.PARA: The working group met in Sydney from 5 to 7 December to consider the responses to the discussion paper. Discussions were held between the working group and interested parties, including the Australian Federation of Travel Agents, on 6 December. At the meeting AFTA submitted two proposals which would ensure that the AFTA travellers protection scheme could be up and running and could either function in parallel to a Commonwealth scheme or be adopted by the Commonwealth either in its present or in an amended form and be incorporated into a national scheme. I am informed that the working group has studied these proposals very closely and I understand that officials are continuing to consult on these and other proposals put forward by interested parties and expect to be in a position , within the next few weeks, to finalise a report to Commonwealth and State tourism and consumer affairs Ministers which would include draft legislative provisions. The working group is required to report to these Ministers by 31 December 1983. The Government will be in a better position to evaluate fully the AFTA proposals when the working group's report becomes available.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Button in his capacity as Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister representing the Prime Minister. Will the Minister agree that there is absolutely no requirement whatsoever for the Government even to contemplate holding a general election for the House of Representatives until early 1986? The Government will most probably avoid the referenda because it knows it will not be able to trick the public with its proposals. However, that still does not alter the fact set out in the first part of my question. Will the Minister also agree that if Mr Hawke does not clear the air about this matter now, once and for all, it could destabilise and unsettle the very fragile recovery that is taking place in this country, which would be to the detriment of all Australians? If an election is held in November next year, it will be a premature and cynical election that could easily lead to Mr Hawke becoming a discredited former Prime Minister. Finally, if an election is held in November, it will importantly allow the Government to increase the number of members of the House of Representatives 15 months earlier than otherwise and that, with all the other bits and pieces, would cost about $ 10m a year.
—Order! Will the honourable senator ask his question?
—That is something that no voter would want. It removes the only excuse the Prime Minister could have to hold a cynical election.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose I should begin by congratulating Senator Townley on his speech. I should also like to congratulate him on the fact that this is the first time in eight years that I have seen him overcome and concerned by a rash of principles, because in the entire period of the previous Government, even years, he expressed no such concern. In fact, I strongly resent the suggestion that this Government would trick the public or indulge in a cynical exercise about this matter. In fact, it was only two days ago in an article in the Australian that the honourable senator's leader in the Senate accused this Government of what he called 'disarming candour'. The suggestion that we should also be guilty of cynicism, coming so close upon the heels of the Leader of the Opposition's suggestion that we were guilty of candour, surprises and disappoints me.

ANSWER.PARA: I agree on behalf of the Prime Minister that as at this date, 15 December 1983, there is clearly no requirement for us to fix an election in November or December 1984, but I am sure I cannot bind the Prime Minister in any answer I give to every date beyond 15 November 1983 and prevent him, as well as everybody else, contemplating that issue. I am sure, however, that if I convey to the Prime Minister Senator Townley's passionate concern about the destabilising of the recovery and so on he will take it into account in any deliberations which he makes about the question of an early or late election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question and I will be very brief. The Minister did not answer the last part of my question. Does he not agree that an early election would enable the House of Representatives to be enlarged at a great cost to this country?

—I agree that an early election would, in certain circumstances, enable the House of Representatives to be enlarged. Whether it is at a great cost to this country is very much a matter of subjective judgment. I do not see any particular point in offering my judgment any more than I would see any particular point in Senator Townley articulating his.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and concerns the bomb attacks that have taken place recently in Kuwait. Is the Government concerned that these bombings are part of an attempt by pro-Iranian elements to destabilise the Gulf States and therefore threaten a substantial section of the world's oil supplies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators will be all too well aware, a number of bomb attacks did occur in Kuwait three days ago, including attacks on the United States and French embassies. They were similar in execution to the terrorist attacks which occurred in Beirut in October. Reports indicate that at least two people were killed and 43 injured in the latest bombings. I have no information whether those responsible were pro-Iranian forces but will seek such further information as the Minister is able to provide.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government, of course, deplores terrorist attacks wherever they occur and expresses its horror at the intent of terrorists whose purpose is cold bloodedly to inflict damage, injury and loss of life on a massive scale. These acts can be described only as thoroughly and utterly repugnant. The Government is deeply concerned at the escalation and the spread of attacks of this nature in the Middle East. As Senator Sibraa indicated, they can serve only to undermine the peace and security of an already volatile region.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Attorney- General recall a question I asked him last Friday regarding a Federal Court of Australia decision relating to computer program copyrights, or the lack thereof apparently, in Australia? Does he recall that, as part of his answer, he pointed out that where in Australia protection is left to the patents and designs Acts-not very adequately at that-in the United States the Federal Appeals Court has recently held that all computer programs be copyrighted under the current United States law even if they are an integral part of the computer's circuitry? Does he further recall that he promised that his Department was examining the matter in consultation with the Patent Trade Marks and Designs Office and with affected interests? Given his assertion last Friday that everything done in his Department is treated as a matter of urgency and given the enormous ramifications of the recent Federal Court decision regarding computer programs, can the Attorney-General say what action he or his Department will be taking and when that action will be taken?

—I well recall Senator Haines's contribution to the subject of the Apple and Wombat litigation and the implications deriving from it for the protection of computer software. It is an important matter. It is hardly one that has been sprung suddenly upon us, however, notwithstanding the anxiety which Senator Haines expresses on this matter because there has been for some considerable time concern that the present law may not be adequate to protect computer software. I have no further information at this point from my Department; but, of course, I sought such further information in the light of Senator Haines's question last Friday. I assure her that delays in my Department are not yet, as a result of this one instance, stretching out to Durack-like dimensions. I am well aware of the problem and I will do my best to see what we are able to do to expedite a solution early in the New Year.

—Is the Attorney-General aware of reported inhumane treatment of prisoners at Brisbane Prison where some 35 prisoners are locked in cells all day with only 15 minutes exercise daily? It is reported that this treatment is occurring in cells which have no water or toilet facilities. Makeshift provisions have had to be made which appear to constitute a serious health hazard as prisoners are forced to live and eat in cells which do not have appropriate facilities. As a number of these prisoners have not yet been charged with offences connected with the November rioting at the prison, is the Queensland Government in breach of the United Nations standard minimum rules for the treatment of prisoners to which Australia is a signatory? What action can the Attorney-General suggest to ensure that this treatment is investigated so that prisoners are guaranteed fundamental human rights?

—The standard minimum rules for the treatment of prisoners were adopted by resolution of the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations in 1957. Although the rules do not have the status of a binding international instrument, the resolution invited all governments to give favourable consideration to their adoption and application. Australia, of course , supports these rules. It has done and will continue to do all that it can to ensure compliance with them. The rules provide comprehensive guidelines for the treatment of prisoners including provisions dealing with hygiene and daily exercise. All Australian jurisdictions are aware of the rules. I am advised that the Prisons Department in Queensland subscribes to the principles in the rules. The question in practice, of course, may well be somewhat different.
—I can vouch for that.

—Senator Georges may be in a position to testify. Until Australia has a national Bill of rights, which I hope will be the case relatively early next year, complaints relating to the treatment of prisoners in State prison systems will have to be determined in accordance with State laws and procedures. The Commonwealth is simply not in a position to directly intervene. I will, however, take up the matter raised by Senator Reynolds with the appropriate Queensland authorities.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Is it a fact that the Chairman of the Australian National Line has given notice that it will be advising that it will withdraw the services of the vessel Townsville Trader from the Darwin run by 21 January next year unless a subsidy is forthcoming? While it will be agreed that the Townsville Trader can never be economically viable because it is patently obvious it is the wrong vessel for the job, will the Government give consideration to making up the losses for a period to enable arrangements to be made to procure a suitable vessel that will operate economically?
—I will draw that question to the attention of the Minister for Transport and get an early answer to the honourable senator.

—I direct a question to the Attorney-General. It follows the question that Senator Haines asked last week and the question she asked earlier today.
