I ask: Has the Attorney-General's attention been drawn to a call in the media by the President of the Australian Computer Society Inc. for copyright legislation to protect persons who develop computer software? Has the Australian Computer Society made formal representations to the Government on this matter?

—Yes, my attention has been drawn to that matter. I believe that such formal representations either have been made or are about to be made although I have not yet seen them come across my desk. I do take note of the point that Senator Colston is making as indeed I did of that made by Senator Haines earlier on. I can assure both honourable senators and the Senate generally that action will be taken as soon as an appropriate strategy can be resolved balancing out the interests of all relevant parties to ensure that there is proper protection in this area because I am sure every honourable senator would acknowledge the desirability of that being the case.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: IMPORTATION OF NEW ZEALAND FRESH POTATOES

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 December 1983 Senator Hamer addressed a very detailed question to me about the importation of New Zealand fresh potatoes. I have obtained an answer for Senator Hamer on that topic from the Minister for Health. I seek leave to have the text of that answer incorporated in Hansard.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Australian potatoes are not free of serious diseases but there are certainly serious diseases in other countries, including New Zealand, which do not occur in Australia. It is for this reason that quarantine action is taken to regulate any importations to ensure they do not constitute a serious pest and disease threat to the Australian potato industry.
The golden nematode is one such exotic disease of potatoes which occurs in New Zealand.

As a consequence New Zealand potatoes may only be imported for processing under strict quarantine control. The potatoes are permitted only from areas free from golden nematode and other exotic diseases and quarantine supervision is exercised over their transportation, storage and processing. Containers are also cleaned and wastes disposed of under quarantine supervision.

New Zealand Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries officials have made approaches to Australian plant quarantine to relax conditions to permit the importation of potatoes for retail sale from designated disease-free areas.
However the conditions will not be relaxed unless there are adequate safeguards to ensure the potatoes do not constitute a serious quarantine risk.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 September last Senator Haines asked me as the Minister representing the Minister for Health a question without notice concerning the payment of medical benefits for health screening to prostitutes. I have obtained the following information from the Minister for Health. I apologise to the Senate for the delay.

QUESTION.PARA: Medical benefits are not payable for the regular routine screening of prostitutes for the detection of sexually transmitted diseases. The primary purpose of the medical benefits scheme is to meet expenses reasonably necessary for a patient's medical care. It is considered that preventive public health measures are more effectively and economically carried out by State public health authorities. Only recently the States have expressed concern to the Commonwealth that all pathology investigations relating to infectious diseases such as sexually transmitted diseases should be performed by State laboratories to ensure effective control over the spread of such diseases. The Australian Medical Association has recently raised the question of the level and availability of sexually transmitted disease services in public clinics and the current policy of non-payment of medical benefits for routine screening for such services if carried out by private practitioners. The Department of Health has asked State health authorities to provide information on their facilities for handling examinations and investigations for sexually transmitted diseases. Their replies are awaited.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 December Senator Missen asked a question about Australia's response to the drought in Africa. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following additional information. In response to the continuing very difficult food situation in Africa the Prime Minister announced at the New Delhi Commonwealth Heads of Government meeting that additional wheat food aid allocations would be made as follows: Zimbabwe, 9,000 tonnes; Tanzania, 12,000 tonnes and Zambia, 6,000 tonnes. All three shipments are to be freight paid to the relevant African coast ports. This donation will make the total Australian food aid allocation to Africa in the current financial year 164,000 tonnes. The total value of this food aid is $38.2m. In addition, Australia has provided humanitarian and relief aid to African countries through non-government organisations and the United Nations Children's Fund, UNICEF, to the value of $ 744,316 to date in the current financial year.

—On 9 December Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle asked me, representing the Minister for Defence Support, a question about tenders for the rework of the air traffic control towers at Richmond in New South Wales and East Sale in Victoria. The Minister for Defence Support has provided the following answer to the honourable sentor's question: Request for tender for the refurbishment of air traffic control facilities at Richmond and East Sale was issued on 25 October 1983 and was due to close on 20 January 1984. Following requests from prospective tenderers for extension of the closing date in view of the holiday shut down the client authority, the Royal Australian Air Force, has agreed to a two week extension of the closing date. Tenders will now close on 3 February 1984.

—Today in Question Time Senator Messner asked me a question about an apparent conflict between answers I gave at the Senate Estimates Committee proceedings regarding the appropriation of funds for the payment of salaries to staff hired to administer the assets test. I am informed by the Department that salary payments for staff engaged on assets tests are being recorded against the Department's salary appropriation division 560.1.01 which will be reimbursed by funds drawn from division 312 which is the special provision from the Minister for Finance. This is akin to the procedures applying for the use of money from the Advance to the Minister for Finance as foreshadowed during the Estimates committee proceedings.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation as I have been misrepresented. In this morning's Press I was misrepresented in relation to the reason that I gave, as recorded in Hansard, relating to the vote in respect of section 3 (12) of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act 1982. In respect of this matter I have always maintained a consistent approach based on the principles of certainty before the law and fairness. I indicate that it is one thing to vote against the incorporation for the first time of a measure and a different matter altogether, after that right has been established for 12 months, to vote against that particular provision. I place on record that it was unfair 12 months later to deny to taxpayers their right to relief which under the law they are entitled to expect. I reiterate for the sake of the Press what I said yesterday, as recorded in Hansard on pages 3772 and 3773:

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I voted against it this time is simply that the omission of section 3 (12) has a retrospective effect in that taxpayers who would be entitled to relief under that sub-section and who have requested that it be applied by the Commissioner of Taxation will now have that right removed and face recoupment tax liability.

DEBATE.TITLE: STEEL INDUSTRY AUTHORITY BILL 1983BOUNTY (STEEL MILL PRODUCTS) BILL 1983BOUNTY (HIGH ALLOY STEEL PRODUCTS) BILL 1983

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to note that in 1981, while the overseas steel industry was almost without exception shedding labour, the steel industry in Australia was actually increasing its labour force. Of course, from 1982 onwards there was a major shedding of labour in Australia. However, it was much too late to absorb the dramatic downturn in steel demand. Australia was one of only four Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development countries in which the 1981 employment level was higher than the level in 1974. One can make observations about what appears to be excess labour in Australian industry but perhaps it is more relevant to make comparisons with steel production per person employed. In so doing it has to be noted that it is not easy to draw clear or relevant comparisons. The production figures will be distorted by the varying hours worked in each country, but more particularly by the level of technology and the type of goods being produced.

SPEECH.PARA: The Industries Assistance Commission report provides a table outlining crude steel production per person employed. That table shows Australia's production per person employed to be less than half that of the Japanese worker and in fact less than that of almost all major steel producers. It is considerably less than that in the United States of America and below that recorded for the European Economic Community countries other than the United Kingdom, and for all OECD countries in aggregate. Of further considerable concern is the fact that the level of productivity in Australia per worker is below that of 1974, for instance when it appears to have been contrary to the trends in productivity in the OECD area as a whole. A number of factors will influence the level of productivity of individual workers, but all other factors are equal, not the least being the staffing levels, work days lost though disputes and, of course, the personal endeavours and good will of members of the work force towards their task and their employers.

The Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd in giving evidence to the IAC stated that it had been hindered in its attempts to reduce manning levels by the number and complexity of industrial relations issues involved and the fact that some manning provisions are written into awards. The company added that industrial relations matters further influenced productivity through the effect on output of industrial disputes originating from both within and outside the steel industry. For example, in 1979-80 industrial action at BHP's steel making centres resulted in the loss of over 1.1 million man hours of production, or some 2 per cent of total man hours worked. In addition, BHP stated that small stoppages or interruptions in other parts of the production chain, for example in coal mining or shipping, could cause substantial disruptions and lost output in the remaining sections of the industry. It is estimated that industrial disputes accounted for 500,000 tonnes of lost production in the year ended May 1982. BHP added that, in order to cushion the impact of industrial disputes, it must carry a high level of in-process stocks and this can effect its output of finished product and therefore its measured productivity.

BHP also stated that decline in output as a result of industrial disputes occurred at a more rapid rate than that at which the company was able to reduce its manning levels, resulting in a fall in labour productivity. The company also said that the position was exacerbated by the recruitment of over 3,500 employees between 1978 and 1981 to accommodate the increased production levels forecast for the early 1980s. Those levels did not eventuate, as I said earlier. These very employees who significantly reduced the productivity and capability of the company, who reduced its capacity to compete and sell its commodities at an attractive level, and who in many respects must be held in part responsible for the present plight of BHP's steel section are now calling for more taxpayers ' money to be consumed by them, not only in direct funding to their employer but also through unemployment programs amounting to over $100m.

How many companies can carry 1.1 million man hours of production loss in any one year and expect to provide a product which is not only competitive but is also attractive to domestic consumers? The very people who contributed to the demise of the company and themselves are now to receive relief from their sins through a contribution from all other taxpayers' funds. As I said earlier, their part of the bargain for now receiving these funds is to abide by the prices and incomes accord to which they have already pledged their support. Their further contribution seems to amount to nought. In my view, the steel industry companies cannot stand blameless or be exonerated from fault for the wage blowout of their employees. The 1981 metals industry award of a 38-hour week, accompanied by a significant wages increase, has had serious ramifications for the steel industry . It seems to have been an agreement which employers need never have conceded. For BHP's steel division as a whole, the average cost to produce a tonne of steel increased by over 80 per cent from $203.31 to $367.44 between 1978-79 and 1981-82. As the IAC points out, this increase was well in excess of both BHP's average increase in products prices, approximately 53 per cent, and the increase in the consumer price index over the same period of 34 per cent.

It is often claimed that Korea and Japan are the two countries in particular which have significant wage advantages over Australian producers. However, it ought to be acknowledged that Korea's real advantage over Australia is its man- hour productivity. Wages in Japan grew dramatically in the 1970s and that variation no longer plays the significant role it once did. What is more material is the growth of our wages at the expense of profits and productivity. In BHP's case most of the increases in cost within the steel division between 1978-79 and 1981-82 can be explained by increased wage rates and increased inputs. BHP stated that the rise in cost of labour was the major component of the cost increase. Between 1978-79 and 1981-82, hourly earnings of steelworks labour increased by 47 per cent and labour accounted for a little under half, 46 per cent, of the total increase in input prices. If labour costs had moved in line with the CPI, the increase in total costs between 1978-79 and 1981-82 would have been 10 percentage points less than the actual increase.

I turn now to the question of technological quality and the state of the art in the steel industry in Australia. I make the observation that BHP has an integrated industry with ownership of energy, iron ore and transport. One would normally assume that with a skilled work force those components would make for an economic and efficient industry. The truth of the matter is that the price of BHP's domestic steel is the highest in the western world, excepting the United States of America. It has been claimed that the cost is even higher than that of United States of America steel, which can be obtained more cheaply at discount. Very few overseas producers enjoy the domestic dominance of BHP. Canada has three major steel producers, Japan five, and the United States of America eight. Only some United States of America and Canadian companies approach the high degree of backward integration that, as I previously mentioned, is enjoyed by BHP. The Japanese certainly have no such integration. In fact, as we all know, they have to buy their iron ore and coal from Australia, produce their iron and steel and ship it back to Australia, yet they are able to do that at a price more than competitive with BHP's steel.

It is true that BHP had in recent years invested considerable money in updating and improving the efficiency and productivity of its steel factories. However, it is considerably behind many overseas companies. During the crucial period of the early 1970s when investment should have been undertaken, the directors, fearing, by their own admission, what the Prices Justification Tribunal might do to their increased prices, and at a time of perceived downturn in the industry, withheld new capital expenditure. Much of the evidence given to the Industries Assistance Commission was critical of the size, age and technical efficiency of BHP's plant. It is suggested that these factors were important in explaining the apparent deterioration in the company's competitiveness. The IAC stated:

BHP conceded that some of its existing technology is in some ways deficient, the principal shortcomings including the preparation of raw materials and the relatively limited use of continuous casting. For example, BHP estimated that in 1983 some 20% of its output would be produced by the continuous casting process, whereas in many other countries up to 70% of output is produced by this method, with some mills producing up to 100% of total output by the continuous casting process.

BHP concede that recent investments have concentrated on rehabilitating or rounding off existing facilities, saving energy and improving product quality and productivity rather than adding to capacity or replacing obsolete facilities .
BHP further conceded that throughout the recent period, market conditions and cost factors were such that the replacement of some of the company's older facilities were not economically justifiable.

These comments sounded to me very much like the symptoms of a company which has no ambition to make a profit and remains satisfied and warm in the knowledge that it is protected from real overseas competition. Mr Deputy President, a number of end users of BHP products commented on the quality of its goods and made reference in a number of cases to the superiority of overseas products. I do not propose to go through them all. In fact, they gave evidence to the effect that they were purchasing overseas products because of the poor quality or the comparably poor quality of BHP's products, and in some cases because they were not able to get the range of products, which is something for which one cannot blame BHP, but it is a contributing factor towards increasing the importation levels.

I am of the view that the assistance which the steel industry in Australia needs, if it is to be given, will not be short term but will be required well into the 1990s, particularly given the enormous world wide excess capacity. Nothing in the steel industry in Australia gives me reason to believe that it will be either efficient or viable, as the Government would have it be. My view is that this assistance will become open-ended and permanent. Nothing in the package or on present or future indicators suggests that the industry will be able to stand on its own feet and be competitive in the near future, short of its having to make harsh commercial decisions, with the directors using shareholders funds for a change.

This leads me to the merits of the massive assistance which will be given to the industry by this legislation and to the effect that the assistance will have upon the community, particularly the export industry. One might well ask what benefit is to be achieved from the massive financial support to be given to the steel industry, primarily by way of bounties. If it is to be accepted that the demise in the domestic steel industry is fundamentally as a result of lack of domestic demand, and I have sought to demonstrate that, will the bounty stimulate domestic demand? I am sure that the answer to that has to be no. While the price of steel sold in Australia does and will have some influence on demand , essentially demand is down because of the fall-away in economic growth, primarily due to the world recession. A very modest lowering of the domestic price of steel, which is the most, I suspect, that could be hoped for, will not stimulate demand significantly. It may be argued that the Australian industry will capture a greater share of the import market. In as much as import penetration will have-

TALK.START.PARA: —The export market.
—No, imports, primarily.
—The Australian industry will capture a greater share of the import market?

—I mean the present imports coming into Australia. In other words the industry will get a greater share of what is ultimately domestic consumption. Inasmuch as import penetration has had little impact on the Australian industries' share of the domestic market, I cannot see that having a great influence on profit. Perhaps at best it may increase volume to a small extent and so reduce unit cost, but with Australia's present levels of efficiency we have a long way to go before we begin to be competitive. I should have thought that perhaps the only benefit the Government's contribution can have is to guarantee a steel industry in Australia which I suspect was never really at risk even without taxpayers' funds. With this, of course, go all the inevitable distortions to the economy which accompany such tariff and bounty decisions. We will see the continuing misallocation of resources of both money and manpower.
—What tariff decisions are you talking about?
—The decision to give $350m.
—Tariff decisions, I said.

—I am not talking about the present tariff decisions but prior decisions. Any tariff decision or any bounty decision will have the same influences we are about to see suffered by the community; that is, the misallocation of resources both of a financial and manpower nature. We will see a continuing cost to exporters and to the economy generally. I conclude by quoting the Commission's report of 1975-76 which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is little case for the provision of temporary assistance for individual industries if their difficulties are due to economy-wide problems such as cost inflation or a general downturn in the economy, since such assistance is at the expense of other industries including those facing similar difficulties. Considerations of equity and resource use efficiency seem to require that general economic problems should be dealt with by general measures (such as fiscal, monetary and exchange rate adjustments) that do not discriminate between industries.
To selectively assist some industries in a period of recession could worsen the problems of other industries not similarly assisted, contribute to inflationary pressures and inhibit general recovery.

Nobody denies that Australia needs a steel industry. There are fundamental arguments that one might put forward in respect of defence, technology and reliability of supply, but it seems to me that by continuing to prop up the industry with taxpayers' money as we have done over the years by way of tariffs and quotas and now by way of bounties that is a rather inadequate and very expensive way of ensuring that industry. I should have thought that to lavish taxpayers' money, which can be ill afforded at present, will add very significantly to the Budget deficit. The Government could have been more enthusiastic about trying to make the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd more economic rather than having it stand over the Government and say: 'If you do not give us money we will close the steel industry down'. That is precisely what it said. It was huffing and puffing. Of course it had no intention of closing the industry. The Government came along and gave it $350m.

The real solution for BHP is to separate its oil and gas component from its steel component so that the shareholders and directors can take greater notice of the return on their investment in the steel industry which in recent years has been as low as one per cent. We have now seen net losses by BHP. We ought to look at different directions other than continuing to write out taxpayers' cheques to support the shareholders and employees of BHP.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess that one of the great Australian sports is pulling down tall poppies. The Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd is the tallest, the largest and, in its own terminology, the biggest Australian poppy. Therefore it gets more than its share of criticism. It earns some of that criticism. I believe it is entitled to it. But it is also entitled to some credit because it is not only a monopoly power but also a great pioneer in this country. For many years it was perceived by most Australians as a backbone industry, as a vital industry and as a very fundamental industry of Australia. I think therefore that the people who helped to build it over the years are entitled to some recognition and some credit for the great industry that they have built. The people I am talking about are not just the directors, not just the managers and executives; they are also, of course, the workers, the people who have been in there with the picks and shovels and tools, helping to create this great Australian enterprise. But, as previous speakers have indicated, for some time BHP has been given a fair bit of assistance by all Australians, through our taxation, tariff and quota systems. It was perhaps inevitable that one day BHP would come to the Australian Government and say: ' Even that is not enough. We are still suffering because of a number of factors, both international and local. We need even more help'. This package of legislation represents that 'more help' that BHP has sought.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that disenchants many people is that BHP came to this new Government and held a gun at its head. I do not believe that anybody could deny that. It was evident in the way that straw promises were advanced of billions to be spent by BHP and threats were made that the alternative, if support were denied by the Government, was that it would simply fold up its camp and walk away, leaving the Government to pick up the tab for the massive unemployment and disruption of industry that would follow. So there was no question that BHP was able to apply extreme pressure to the Government to reach the agreement which has resulted in these Bills.

The measures themselves teach us something about the so-called virtues of protection in this country. My understanding, and I believe that of most people, is that the principle of protection is one of helping an industry to become established. One perhaps helps it, particularly if it is a pioneering industry, to grow up. One helps it to grow through the infant stages so that ultimately it will be able to compete on the world scene, in international markets. BHP has grown up and it is time that it stood on its own feet. It is a big boy now but still seems to need help to walk. As a result, the Australian taxpayers will be paying out some $70m per annum-because of the inability on the part of BHP management to create a product that can compete on world markets. We do not blame the Government for giving the proposed assistance. We do not believe that it had an option, given the threat of job losses at a time of massive unemployment, but we believe that it should recognise that, just as BHP had Australia by the short and curlies, the Government also had a weapon in its hand when these negotiations took place. We do not believe that it used that weapon to extract enough control on BHP's future actions, enough guarantees and assurances concerning its future activities in this country.

Certain problems arise from this package. They include the inherent contradiction involved in giving protection to an industry in order to make it more efficient. It is not impossible to resolve that contradiction. The Japanese experience should teach us that government assistance can help to initiate industries which ultimately will become efficient and competitive, which do end up contributing to increased employment, economic growth and higher living standards. We can take a leaf out of that book. Unfortunately, however, Australia seems to have become saddled with a series of industries such as BHP which continue to be a drain upon it, which ultimately contribute to the economy as would a cross between a leech and an albatross. I think the Australian Financial Review put this extremely well in an editorial on Friday, 12 August:
But can we be certain that it-
the reference was to the agreement--
will guarantee the radical restructuring of our steel industry so desperately required?
It went on:

Indeed, how can this occur if BHP continues to be sheltered from the winds of international competition? For decades we have heard the argument that continuing aid is required to enable Australian companies to get to a grown up stage. BHP . . . is still having trouble walking.

Another problem that arises from this agreement which has been reached with BHP is the need for the Government to be prepared sensibly and accurately to monitor BHP's affairs and books. I believe that it will be essential that the Government have access to all of that information, in the same way as does a director or shareholder of any company. Let us face the fact that this Government is in no less a position in regard to funding than is any manager or shareholder of BHP and should be entitled to the same substantial privileges as they, or a director , would enjoy.

A third problem that needs to be addressed is that, through the Steel Industry Authority, the Government will have to ensure that productivity gains are made and that they are real gains. The benefit of this payout to BHP should be the creation of an efficient and internationally competitive industry, not just the pouring down the drain of more money for purposes of bare survival. We want to see BHP right up there amongst the world leaders in the steel industry, not begging for handouts year after year for the next 10 or 20 years. The formula that is provided in the legislation does give some incentive. It does provide the Government with the opportunity to reduce its contribution to BHP. Therefore , there is certainly an incentive for the Government to ensure that BHP prospers under the formula.

Workers and unions are often blamed for Australia's poor general economic performance and our relative inability to sell manufactured products overseas. It is fair to suggest that when we look at the steel industry management must take some of the blame. A contrast can be drawn between the domestic iron ore industry's performance over the last couple of decades and that of the steel industry, which represents the next stage in the process. While the iron ore industry has grown and blossomed, has been thriving, the steel industry has suffered as a result of the actions and decisions taken by its captains, which have helped to scuttle the boat. The legislation before us is simply a means of helping that boat to stay afloat. However, the Australian Democrats hope that it will provide an example of how government assistance can help to make an industry efficient. We hope that the Government will keep BHP under the microscope. We believe that it should play a bigger role in the planning of the whole Australian economy, particularly in key industries such as the steel industry. But the assistance that the Government gives should be in the form of helping to phase in these industries where that will be beneficial to the Australian economy and helping to phase other industries out. Over the next five years the steel industry must be closely monitored, must be kept under the microscope to ensure that it is a growth industry and not a potential phase-out industry. If it is a phase-out industry, the crunch decision must be made before it bleeds Australia dry. We do not believe that the market mechanism should reign supreme, but neither should we endlessly support industries that can make no long term contribution to increasing our communal wealth.

I would like to conclude by posing a couple of questions to the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button). I am a little uncertain, from reading the Bills, whether the Steel Industry Authority will have the power to control or influence imports of steel. We think that is a vital question, not just for BHP but for all steel users in Australia. What sorts of powers are to be given? What sort of ultimate control and influence in regard to steel imports whether direct or indirect, will the Steel Industry Authority have? Secondly, will the bounty formula result in the Government reducing imports with the object of increasing BHP's productivity and thus, of course, reducing the bounties that the Government must contribute to BHP? That again would obviously be in the Government's interest but certainly may not be in the interests of the steel users of Australia. If the Minister would answer those two questions-he was absent momentarily when I asked the first question, which was will the steel industry--

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard it.

—He got that. In general, let me make it quite clear that the Australian Democrats support these Bills. They are an inevitable development in this industry. We see that the Government has no alternative but to bring forward these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senators who have contributed to this debate in such tones of fulsome praise. One or two questions were addressed to me in the course of the discussion and I want to advert to those just briefly. Senator Crichton-Browne's speech was, if I might use this expression, larded liberally with quotations from submissions to the Industries Assistance Commission. The IAC report on the steel industry was one of the matters the Government took into account in arriving at the steel industry plan. I do not propose to canvass that ground. I suppose Senator Crichton-Browne will go on doing that for a long period, but it is not strictly relevant to the circumstances which prevail today.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the burden of Senator Chaney's speech was to indicate that the Opposition did not oppose the package but that it had some concerns about it. I want to deal with those concerns briefly. Senator Chaney, in fact, suggested that the proposals of the Government do not amount to a complete solution of the steel industry's problems. Of course they do not. I have never pretended that they do. The Government has never pretended that this package is a complete solution to the steel industry's problems. Associated with that was a series of questions as to what disciplinary action the Government intended should be taken if the parties to the steel industry agreement do not honour their obligations. Firstly, of course, that is one of the tasks of the Steel Industry Authority-to monitor the performance of the respective parties to the steel plan in respect of the obligations they have entered into. From this Government's point of view the Steel Industry Authority will be reporting regularly to the Government. Those reports will be made public. The purpose of that is that if a party or any parties do not honour their obligations to the steel industry plan and it fails the people of Australia will know why. That is to say, if Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd does not honour its investment obligations and the unions do not honour their obligations in relation to industrial relations matters and productivity, there will be a public accountability in relation to those matters .

Secondly, in relation to that let me simply say that it is this Government's view that if the steel industry plan does not work that may well be the end of the steel industry in this country. That is not a result we want to see. But we have made commitments. If those commitments are not respected and the commitments made by other parties are not honoured, the steel industry will be on its own as far as we are concerned. Senator Crichton-Browne said, of course, that that should have been the position from the beginning. I do not know what inside information he has, but I assure honourable senators that wherever he got it from it is substantially incorrect about decisions which were likely to be taken in relation to the steel industry if the Government had not acted in the way it did.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry; I am not talking about inside information. I was saying that, if it-
—The honourable senator has had his say.
—If it had taken commercial decisions at an earlier time you would not be forking out taxpayers' money now.
—That is right. That is an interesting piece of anecdotal history .
—It is a fact of life which has been ignored by successive governments.

—Yes, it is a fact of life. Senator Crichton-Browne is on the Hansard record now as saying that if everything had been right in the world in previous years we would not have had all these problems today-a very constructive contribution.
—No, don't try to simplify it. That is not what--

—That is what it is; that is what it amounts to. It is a piece of academic nonsense in the situation of this debate. Senator Chaney asked me some specific questions. The first were the questions of honouring obligations to the steel industry plan. I have already answered those three questions. I think Senator Chaney may have been locked in conversation at the time but the answers will appear in Hansard. The other specific questions he asked me were about the fast track dumping mechanism. That is being developed between the Steel Industry Authority and the Department of Industry and Commerce. The Steel Industry Authority will assist in the collation and provision of information to assist the Department to assess correctly whether there is a prima facie case of injury resulting from imports at dumped prices. That will mean that much less time will be taken in dealing with a dumping complaint. The Steel Industry Authority will be monitoring imports, and through contacts with overseas industries, will be able to supply information much more quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: I should also draw attention to the fact that on 7 November this year the Government announced a review of dumping procedures which will greatly speed up the mechanisms for dealing with dumping complaints. Such procedures include a time limit of 45 days from acceptance of a complaint for the Department to arrive at a preliminary finding and so on. Those are matters of record to which I referred in my statement of 7 November. They will greatly speed up the process of dealing with dumping complaints.

Senator Chaney also asked about the relationship between the Steel Industry Authority and the Prices Surveillance Authority. The Steel Industry Authority will be focusing on all aspects of the steel industry, including prices. Steel is not amongst those matters to be dealt with by the Prices Surveillance Authority but it is envisaged that the Steel Industry Authority should work in close consultation with the Prices Surveillance Authority in relation to steel industry matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —BHP will not have to deal with both, will it?

—No, not at all. It will deal with the Steel Industry Authority. But in relation to general criteria and guidelines the two authorities will work in co-operation. I think those were the major matters addressed to me by Senator Chaney. In relation to Senator Jack Evans's comments, it was very difficult to determine who was holding the gun at whose head in the course of negotations with BHP and the other parties involved in relation to the steel industry. Let me say that BHP wanted much more than it got from the Government. The Government wanted more than it got from BHP. But the investment program BHP has foreshadowed for the next five years is larger than the investment program foreshadowed under the 10-year plan BHP put to the IAC. The IAC investment program over 10 years was larger in the latter half. In respect of the first five years there is more investment than there would have been under the plan put to the IAC in respect of which the company asked for a lot more assistance than it is getting.
—What certainty to the industry did BHP offer after the 10-year period?

—The company made commitments to the IAC in terms of investment. But in return for that it sought a much larger market share. It sought larger financial assistance from the Government and a number of other things which it did not get. Senator Evans asked me two questions. He asked whether the Steel Industry Authority has power to control or influence imports of steel. In a strict sense the answer to that is no. The steel industry plan provides that if the steel producers' market share falls below a particular level a mechanism will be activated whereby the Steel Industry Authority reports to the Government and the Government determines whether any further assistance should be provided to the industry. Under the plan, if the share of the market, by product categories, rises above 90 per cent the Authority again reports to the Government which in that circumstance will determine whether the amount of assistance currently available should be reduced. In respect of the question of whether the bounty formula will reduce imports, it is not the intention that that be so. The bounty formula and the import control formula are separate and distinct. I do not think that it is intended that there be any direct relationship between those two.

SPEECH.PARA: The steel industry in Australia is currently determined to make a success of this plan. It is the only industry in the world which at the moment is in relatively optimistic and good shape. In the United States of America steel workers are currently taking reductions in pay, as Senator Chaney pointed out, of $25 a week. It is expected that some 40,000 will be sacked from the German steel industry in the next few months. This sort of pattern exists around the world. It is not an easy time to be involved in the steel industry. The Government was concerned about two major things: Firstly, that the industry should survive because of its importance to Australia and, secondly, that it should produce steel at the lowest possible cost in respect of down-stream users . The plan is fundamentally directed towards those two purposes. I commend the Bills to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a question of the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button). I did not think his response was very helpful to the debate. We are in the process of appropriating $350m of taxpayers' funds. What I said was that by further contributing taxpayers' funds we were exacerbating a problem which had been perpetuated for years and years by successive governments. I was not saying that everything in the world was perfect and that we would have a perfect world. I was simply saying we were adding to that dimension. I asked Senator Button whether he accepted that the problems the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd faced were primarily due to a downturn in domestic demand and not to a major penetration of importations. I asked: How will the bounty stimulate demand if one accepts that the downturn in demand is due to a world recession, not something that is isolated to Australia's problems? While the bounty may give BHP a capacity to reduce its general costs perhaps in some respect it will attract part of the import market into Australia, which will allow it to produce a greater volume of goods and therefore be able to reduce unit costs. I do not see how that in a material sense is going to stimulate demand. I simply ask: How does the Minister see the bounty assisting BHP other than simply by topping up its books given that there is, as the Minister says, an enormous excess capacity in the world at the present time? The projections are that this may well go through into the 1990s and there is no likelihood of the excess capacity in Australia being taken up. How will the bounty stimulate demand or will it simply make sure that the industry ticks over for another 20 years?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bounty is not designed to make sure the industry ticks over for another 20 years. Firstly, a number of factors have contributed to the misfortunes of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd of which the world economic recession and the Australian recession were very substantial factors, but not by any means exclusive factors. Secondly, Senator Crichton-Browne asked: Will the bounty stimulate demand? I do not think it will stimulate demand by itself. The honourable senator should remember that BHP manufactures not only for the domestic market but also for the export market. The first thing I would say about it is that lower prices will in some ways have an effect on demand when people are selecting between various products or various materials. The fact that steel is cheaper will have an effect on the selection of steel rather than some other products in certain areas and so on. The fact that there is an export market is also relevant to that question.

SPEECH.PARA: The other fact I should point out to Senator Crichton-Browne which seems to be missing from his equation, if I can put it that way, is that the steel plan is predicated on the assumption that we will have a smaller steel industry than we have had in the past. Neither the Government nor the industry has any illusions about that. We are looking for a smaller, more efficient, steel industry. I will make a very obvious point about some of the factors that were absent from the performance of the steel producers in Australia in previous years. Since the steel plan was announced there has been an enormous upturn in the performance of BHP in terms of marketing and in terms of dealing with complaints about quality and quality control. There is no doubt about that. If honourable senators take the trouble to check with any steel users they will make that comment. That is one example of some of the things which were lacking and which are now there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. We are at the Committee stage of this Bill. If I recall correctly, you put the question and after the question was put Senator Crichton-Browne spoke. Certain latitude is allowed but surely we are not now going to continue on in the Committee stage when that decision has been made. If we are, I think Senator Crichton-Browne ought to refer to the clause in the Bill to which he is referring otherwise we will be here till midnight.
—There is no point of order because I have not put the question that the Bills be agreed to. I call Senator Crichton- Browne.

—I will say very little else except in response to the point of order that was raised. It is interesting that we can spend 18 hours talking about sex discrimination legislation which will not be passed through the Parliament this session and spend less than an hour talking about spending $350m of taxpayers' money.
—Well, stay within the Standing Orders.

—I am; keep your eye on the ball. With enormous excess capacity overseas, notwithstanding that the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd may be able to reduce its prices in a very modest way, surely the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) is not suggesting that it is likely that we will be able to increase the size of our export market when the price of overseas steel is so low. I cannot see any way in which it is likely that we will increase our quantity of exports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australian steel exports are very much on a window-of-opportunity basis. For example, take Whyalla. The vast majority of Whyalla's current production is exported. That is certainly true of some of John Lysaght (Aust) Ltd products as well. It is a matter of finding niches in the world market. The more the steel companies can do that the better.

SPEECH.PARA: Bills agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Button) read a third time.
AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL RAILWAYS COMMISSION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1983]
Debate resumed from 3 November 1983, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the Senate that the Bill be debated cognately? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak to each of the Bills before the Senate; that is, the two Bills covering the Australian National Railways Commission-the Australian National Railways Commission Bill 1983 and the Australian National Railways Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill- and the Australian Shipping Commission Amendment Bill 1983 and the Inter-State Commission Amendment Bill 1983. The Opposition does not oppose any of these Bills. But in respect of both the Australian Shipping Commission Amendment Bill and the Australian National Railways Commission Bill amendments will be proposed calling for an improved level of accountability. In the other chamber, objections were raised to presentations and publication of commercially valuable information. On this occasion, the amendments have been worded to remove that danger. We require that these two major instrumentalities be thoroughly accountable to the community and to the Parliament. I will move those amendments at a later stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I am grateful to have the opportunity to speak for the Opposition because, by any standard, the effects and application of the legislation covered in these Bills can do more to determine the whole economic future not only of my State but also of the Commonwealth than any legislation likely to come before this chamber now or in the future. While to most members of this chamber these Bills are not of great personal interest, I can assure honourable senators that nationally they should be. To my own State they certainly are. Of all the matters involved in this area the transporting of both people and goods regularly, economically and safely counts above everything. We hope that this legislation will do quite a lot to assist with that objective.

Firstly, I will deal with the Australian National Railways Commission Bill. The major provisions of that Bill are to put the Australian Shipping Commission on a more commercial basis of operation. My own State exports 3.1 million tonnes of cargo a year. About a million tonnes of that is non-bulk cargo. It is of vital concern that these goods be shipped as economically and expeditiously as possible. By any standards, Bass Strait is one of the most expensive pieces of water in the world. What is necessary and what I hope we can achieve by this legislation is to free up the market forces. If the legislation does that, it will certainly have my support.

The Bill aims to improve the management performance of the ANL. I think that in the past we had no arguments that there was not room for that. The Government has already made a significant injection of funds to the ANL which hopefully will improve its productivity and its efficiency. The signs are there. I am very pleased that the signs are that the ANL will become more commercial and that greater attention will be given to seeing that it operates in a truly commercial way. At present the ANL operates in separate divisions. I would like to see separate financial targets set for each of those operating areas so that we can see how each one is going.

Bass Strait, of course, is the national highway for Tasmania. It is important that the use of Bass Strait be as uncomplicated and as economical as possible. The fact that the Tasmanian transport question is complicated is only part of the difficulty. The advantages to Tasmania of being an island State are in many respects certainly countermanded by the problems that it creates in matters such as this. The diversification of population, towns and ports-to say nothing of airports-has saved large amounts of money, considering the costs inherent in centralisation. But it has been achieved at a cost to these other items.

Dependability of shipping is the keystone. It must be regular; it must be economical, and it has to be strike-free. Over and over again, industries fail in Tasmania or leave Tasmania because of these very factors. It is just too difficult to operate because of the hazards of Bass Strait. I am in no doubt that the monopoly or near monopoly situation that the ANL has operated under in many cases has failed to serve Tasmania well. It has not required hard-nosed competitive decisions or consideration of what may be best for the user as much as what may be best for the server. I am very hopeful that, as a result of this new legislation, some of these elements may change. If it does not, I for one will certainly be following it up very closely.

I think everybody is very pleased to see that Mr Bolitho has taken the position of Chairman of the Australian Shipping Commission. I certainly join those who wish him well. I hope that he will be very successful in his job. I quote briefly from a statement attributed to him, dated 10 November. He said:
You may expect us for our part to adopt the first position-pay us what it is worth including return on capital and a fair proportion of overheads or we will not do it . . .
Subsidised operations are but one of the thousand cuts from which we are bleeding . . .
The line has over-manned ships, over-manned terminals and over-manned offices . . .
It entered areas of business for prestigious and perhaps political reasons other than profit, and perhaps it lacked government interest and support-it certainly lacked equity input.
It has to be much more vigorous in its commercial approach than in the past.
It means negotiating harder, it means being tougher with customers.

I can but say thank you to Mr Bolitho for taking that attitude. I can assure him that for my part it has my support and, I hope, has the support of users and parliamentarians throughout Australia. The question of finance is important. The financial backing that has now been given to the Australian National Line, we are told, will make quite a lot of difference to its operation. We will certainly be keeping an eye on that aspect to ensure that next year's report does, in fact, reflect the advantages that come from this improved capitalisation.

I turn now to the Inter-State Commission Amendment Bill. Firstly, I think I need to say that the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) has done little, if anything, to clear up the lack of understanding that is so rife in the community and in the transport sector in particular. The Minister, in the distributed copy of his second reading speech, gave great hope to us. On the first page, he states:
We see the ISC as an important vehicle for promoting the rational development of national transport policies
On page 3 of that same document, he said:

Users of transport have no single entity in Australia to which they can take any problems they encounter with anomalies, discriminations and inequalities that exist in our national transport system. At present they can only appeal to operator controlled organisations (both government and private) whose own interests are generally paramount.
On page 4, he says:
It will have a significant role in keeping each transport system 'honest' . . .
But regrettably, in the next paragraph, he goes on to put the biggest proviso of all and says that excluded are:
. . . matters covered by the new 1981 Airlines Agreement and the related Independent Air Fares Committee Act.
I think that everyone in Australia would feel that these are the areas which should be opened up for a total investigation now.
The Parliamentary Library produced a document on the Bill in which it made a couple of very significant comments which I should like to raise. On page 4 it said:

There is no provision for investigation into other areas under the more general heading of trade and commerce. The terms of reference have also been narrowed to exclude investigation into overseas transport services.
On the next page, it said:

This paragraph curtails considerably the investigations of the Commission into domestic air transport, thus leaving only the modes of roads, rail, coastal shipping and pipeline transport for its consideration.
It then said:

There is no authority given to the Commission to initiate its own investigations nor to make orders upon the recommendations stemming from its investigations. The Commission is empowered only to investigate those matters specified by the Minister in a notice presented to the Commission. Where several matters are to be investigated, the order in which the Commission is to investigate those matters may also be determined by ministerial direction. Upon completion of an investigation, 'the Commission shall furnish to the Minister a report setting out any findings made by the Commission . . . and any recommendations that the Commission thinks fit to make in consequences of those findings'. As a result of these provisions, the Commission is not permitted nor empowered to arbitrate on matters, nor to be requested by persons or States to arbitrate on matters within its terms of reference.
With all the things that the Commission holds, it still has these massive gaps in the things that are really important, as we would see it.

We have not really been told why the Commission has been regurgitated at this particular time. It has been announced that an investigation into the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme is its first job. It would be desirable for me to mention the fact that that certainly needs to be examined. But if the intention is to put Tasmania in a position no worse than that in which she would be were it not for the lack of alternative transport, there are other considerations than just how cheaply similar goods can be moved by road over similar distances on the mainland. In the past we have had all sorts of formulae on how it is possible to shift timber from one place to another in Victoria, or from Wodonga or other places, and they have always taken into account factors that are not appropriate and not available in Tasmania. Sometimes taken into account were matters involving weekend running, back-loading and all sorts of things that are totally inappropriate.

Bass Strait shipping is not like that. The people who have to use it suffer from the constraints that they must ship when the shipping is there. They have to ship within a whole lot of constraints which, if this investigation is to be worth a crumpet, will have to be taken into account. There are too many other factors than just the cost of some alternative, of some route on the mainland. This has never been fully understood in the past. If the Inter-State Commission is to get any credibility, it will have to start by doing a good job on this and seeing that the freight factors between Tasmania and the mainland, in particular , are adequately compensated. If it is to consider the relativity of Tasmania's disadvantages compared with the other States and to see that it is properly provided for, all well and good. But if it is just a way to look at how it can get away with chiselling Tasmania a little more and paying it a little less, I can assure honourable senators that there is likely to be a certain amount of trouble.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not fair, is it?

—It is certainly not fair, because Tasmania has always been chiselled in regard to what has been due to it in matters of transport. I just want to see that in future it gets what it should have. There is a figure involved in this matter which speaks volumes in itself. As I have said, transport across Bass Strait is extremely expensive. The current rate for carrying a 20-foot container from Victoria to northern Tasmania is $1,017.60. This compares with a contract rate for carrying an equivalent container from Victoria to Europe, via a non-conference vessel, of $1,200. That is absolutely ridiculous. It has arisen, regrettably, probably only because of freight equalisation. It is a means by which we have been able to subsidise to the limit of the maximum inefficiency.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the understanding of the Bill, I have also noticed that Mr Webber, for instance, of Mayne Nickless Ltd is not convinced that it will act in the manner laid down and believes that it will only encourage an increase of costs. Even though the Minister has suggested that Mr Webber has sought deliberately to misunderstand the Bill, I feel sure that he admits that Mayne Nickless are the front line troops of the transport business and that it is Mayne Nickless that has to see that the goods get shifted. In regard to the miners, I notice that Mr Hugh Morgan is also less than convinced about the future. Anyway, I am sure that the Minister will be able to give us some more information on that matter, and to give it to some of the people about whom I had intended to speak at greater length had time permitted. But I notice again that the Minister said in a media statement of 2 November:

The Commission will investigate and advise Government on allegations of discriminatory practices, inefficiencies and anomalies in inter-state transport. The Commission, when conducting its investigations, will consult with and seek submissions and evidence from private citizens, unions, business, the community, employees, transport users and suppliers and Government.

That is very good, but we still do not know what that is to cover or why the Minister is likely to set that up. There is nothing in anything that has been produced by the Government at this stage which clears up any of that. On 26 September, Transport Australia put out a fact sheet. Under the heading 'Powers of the Commission', it said:

The Commission has Royal Commission type powers to carry out inquiries into issues relating to inter-state transport. It will operate by investigation, consultation, publication and recommendation. It does not have any judicial or regulatory powers.

So it goes on. There is a lot of information which does not get down to the real detail of just exactly what the Commission is to do. When I came to look back over the history of the Inter-State Commission, I found that it was set up in the first Parliament. Over a period, it has started and stopped and been revived and lapsed eight times. I have looked at the things that it has done. It makes me wonder why it has foundered so often. I guess that it is simply because it has not fulfilled the expectations that were originally held for it. It makes me wonder now whether it will be given work to do or whether it will be used for some sort of political purpose and then allowed to gather dust once again. I hope that it can be shown to be a useful instrumentality. I hope that it is able to achieve things. I hope that it will not be used by this Government or any other government just as a means of having a whipping boy that one can blame for decisions that will be electorally unpopular.

I come now to the railways. The main feature of the railway Bills is similar to the shipping Bills; that is, to add a bit of ginger to their operation on a commercial basis. The purpose of the Australian National Railways Commission Bill is to repeal the present Australian National Railways Act 1917 and to replace it with modern legislation more appropriate to the Commission's role as a commercial business undertaking. It removes various of the constraints and minimises ministerial intervention, and so on. Again, if it does the things that it sets out to do, it will be quite useful; if it does not do them, there may well be various of us, probably in both Houses, who will be looking to see why that has not happened.

People generally are very much inclined to complain a lot about railways. I certainly do not. I see railways as an integral part of the development of the nation. I believe that we have to get a change of mind in relation to the railways. They are not just sinks for public funds. Railways should perform a purpose. They should perform that purpose as quickly and as economically as possible.

I note that the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills raised a question concerning the exemption of the Commission from providing fencing, which has been a traditional practice. The Committee also recommended that a further clause be left in the legislation. It transferred the liability to the adjoining owners so that, for instance, livestock on the railway line was a major problem for them. The onus of the liability was transferred. I believe that we need some clarification of how quickly this will be enforced and whether there will be any preclusions. While I have the opportunity, I would like to mention that as from 1 March 1978 the Australian National Railways took over the shambles that had been the Tasmanian Railways for many years. I give great credit to the Australian National Railways for the fact that the operation of the railways in Tasmania has improved tremendously in that time. The way the operation is heading at present, it appears that it will be making a profit by about 1988-89. If that can be achieved it will be a great credit to many people involved-the employees, Mr Alistair Maddock, who is the Assistant General Manager in Tasmania and management generally. I think they have done a tremendous job.

The Australian National Railways has done a lot to get the old government railways in Tasmania away from the Public Service oriented attitude and to treat the operation far more as a commercial entity. The Australian National Railways has gone a long way to meeting its customers' demands. It has been innovative and responsive in a whole variety of ways. It has learnt to be competitive and it has been able to convince the users of the advantages of the line haul system . It has also disposed of the minor areas of business that were costing a lot of money. It has been able to transfer this business to freight carriers in a very effective way. Tracks and rolling stock have been upgraded tremendously. Australian National Railways has closed 84 stations in Tasmania which is very commendable. It is still working on achieving a reduction in staff. In 1978 the number of staff employed was 1,786. It is now 1,180 and it is still working on reducing this figure to about 650. I think we have to give credit to the way in which it has worked. It is a change to be able to give credit to the railways for the way in which they have operated.

I regret very much that, as usual, Bills of this magnitude which deal with a couple of the largest businesses in Australia are being rushed through the Senate at this late stage of the parliamentary sitting. We have spent hours and hours and days and days on absolute trivia. When we come to deal with the important matters we find that the number of speakers is limited. There is nothing in Australia that is as important as transport. In the transport area, there is nothing as important as the operations of ANL and ANR. I foreshadow that the Opposition will be moving two amendments at the Committee stage. One amendment relates to the Australian National Railways Commission and the other relates to the Australian Shipping Commission. They will add to the accountability to the Parliament of the two organisations concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on this group of four transport Bills. I will focus most of my remarks on the legislation to give effect to the development of the Inter-State Commission. This Bill gives effect to an Act which was passed more than eight years ago by this Parliament and which has had no life to this day. The Bill before us today fulfils the election commitment of the Australian Labor Party. It will enable the establishment of the Inter-State Commission early in 1984. In doing so, it will enable Australia to have a body which will help to give a rational, efficient national transportation system.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very relevant to note that the Inter-State Commission is explicitly provided for in the Australian Constitution. Section 101 refers to the Inter- State Commission having powers of adjudication and administration to execute and maintain provisions of the Constitution relating to trade and commerce. Sections 102 to 104 also relate to the Inter-State Commission. The concept of the Commission to look at trade between the States is linked, of course, with section 92 of the Constitution which provides for freedom of trade between the Australian States. The Inter-State Commission was first established by an Act of parliament in 1912. It existed during the period 1913 to 1920. It was wound up in 1920, effectively as a result of the 1915 so-called 'wheat case' instituted by New South Wales. Re-establishment of the Inter-State Commission was recommended in the 1959 report of the Joint Committee on Constitutional Review. It has also been recommended by at least two committees of inquiry into freight arrangements to and from Tasmania. After a gap of some 64 years the Inter-State Commission, as provided for in the Australian Constitution, is to be re- established. The particular Act to recreate the Commission was passed by this Parliament in 1975 under the Whitlam Government after a long debate. The Act, as finally approved by the Parliament, provided much narrower powers for the Commission than under the Constitution and in the original Bill drafted by the Labor Government.

It is a strange phenomenon indeed for political conservatives of this country to resist adoption of specific provisions of the Australian Constitution because usually they are the first to invoke the provisions of the Constitution to justify their position. In this particular case the conservatives actually supported a concept narrower than that provided for in that document. Powers over trade and commerce for the Inter-State Commission were explicitly provided for in the Constitution. However, the 1975 Act gives power only in respect of transport, specifically interstate transport.

The Commission cannot look at commerce and its various ramifications. It does not have the power of adjudication as provided for in the Constitution. It has no regulatory power and no powers to enforce its finding. Basically, the Inter- State Commission will be an investigatory body with powers of advice to the Government. It can investigate only those matters referred to it by the Government. Its powers will be along the lines of a royal commission to investigate and call evidence. Effectively, it will be a standing royal commission in this transport area. I think that those powers will enable it to gather more information on transport than could be gathered by the current bodies in the field such as the Bureau of Transport Economics which does excellent work. The powers of the Inter-State Commission, as provided, enable it to look at rail transport, road transport, coastal shipping, pipelines and air freight. Of course, many transport problems in Australia are very evident. We have a small and dispersed population and good and efficient transport is vital to the health of our economy. Yet with those factors being well known to the Australian people, for seven years the Fraser Government took no action to proclaim the Inter-State Commission Act to enable us to have an expert body to look into the weaknesses in our transport system and to recommend solutions to them.

I believe that interstate transport in Australia is in need of a major overhaul . In fact, interstate transport activity is such that I believe it cannot even be dignified by calling it a transport system. It is really just a collection of transport industries and transport modes. It is high time there was more integration of these modes. Transport costs are a key element of manufacturing costs in this country, and we already have great problems in manufacturing industry because of our small markets. We cannot get the economies of scale that are achievable in other countries. The transport modes in this country compound that problem, and they compound the tyranny of distance which Australia faces.

If we look at the costs of manufactured goods in Australia I imagine that the transport cost element is perhaps the highest proportion in the world. In the less populous States of Australia transport costs are extremely significant. The cost of transport of manufactured products to the major markets of this country in New South Wales and Victoria constitutes a major element of the cost of products. That was very evident to me in my former occupation in South Australia . On so many occasions there were plant closures in our State on the ground that the cost of transporting goods to Sydney and Melbourne was too high and the firms were relocating adjacent to those centres. The poor transport system in this country really leads to a centralisation of economic activity and acts against decentralisation.

Something must be done about the interstate transport system, and I believe that having an expert body such as the Inter-State Commission will enable us to come to grips with many of these problems. To make the system more efficient we need rational development of transport policies in this country and we need far more co-ordination of our transport modes. I believe that the Inter-State Commission will help to ensure that these much needed improvements occur. The Commission will be an expert body with real investigative powers. It will be independent. It will help to reduce the number of specific or ad hoc transport inquiries that we have in Australia. It is possible to list a great many of those that have been convened in recent years at great expense. I hope the Inter -State Commission will no be an ad hoc body but will exist for a long time so that the expertise gathered in investigating transport matters will not be lost when inquiries finish, as is the case in Australia at the moment. I believe the Commission will help to identify interstate transport weaknesses, that it will lift the efficiency of the system, and that can only benefit the development of interstate transport in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak on the Australian Shipping Commission Amendment Bill 1983. This Bill enshrines a five-point plan by the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) for the Australian Shipping Commission, which operates under the pseudonym of the Australian National Line. The first point in the Minister's program aims to put the Australian National Line on a proper financial footing. To achieve this, $60m of loan funds were converted to equity in Appropriation Bill (No. 6) and at the same time $30m of new capital was injected into the enterprise and losses are being capitalised. If some action like this had not been taken the ANL would have been bankrupt by the end of this financial year, so I suppose it is reasonable to support this measure. However, it brings up the question of why the Government is or should be in the shipping business at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Government-run enterprises constantly seem to run into this problem of bankruptcy whereas comparable commercial organisations do not. I have never been persuaded of the desirability of a high cost Australian shipping industry run by the Government being involved in our overseas trade when there is plenty of competitive foreign shipping available to carry our trade at economic rates. Economic rates are of great importance to a trading nation such as Australia. Just in case honourable senators are misled by the profit figures in the last report of the ANL, I point out to the Senate that the ANL made an overall profit in 1981-82 of $2.5m. When we read the fine print, there was at least a $7.2m profit on coastal operations, which means the overseas operations incurred a loss of at least $4.7m. Just to hand today, too late to be debated, is the latest report from the ANL. The news is not good, and I think I should read out to honourable senators a couple of the items contained in the report. At page 4 it states:
The result for year was a loss of $26.2m.
What did the report state about coastal shipping? At page 10 it states:
There was a 25% reduction in coastal bulk cargo.
At page 12 it states:

Coastal liner trading has experienced a period of severe competition and reduced loadings since late 1982 brought about by the depressed level of economic activity and the resultant surplus capacity in road, rail and coastal shipping.

Even before this alarming report, coastal shipping was not in a healthy state. Let us look at what has actually happened to our coastal trade. In 1949 there were 190 vessels in the Australian coastal fleet, but in 1980 there were only 84 , of which 61 sailed between States and 23 were in the intrastate trade. This coastal fleet is dominated by a small number of large single role or specialised ships, mainly tankers and bulk carriers. General cargo ships have declined in number. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the number and types of vessels in the Australian coastal trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill proposes a restructing of the Australian Shipping Commission and allows for a part time chairman and a chief executive officer. The latter, the chief executive officer, is the crucial appointment because he will be the head of the executive and a member of the Commission. SPEECH.PARA: The third point in the five-point plan is aimed at improving the industrial relations climate. ANL ships are still grossly over-manned. On any given vessel the ANL would have the biggest crews in the world. What is more, these larger crews do less work than the smaller crews on comparable overseas vessesl. A typical example is an identical ship manned on Australian scales, British scales and Scandinavian scales. There would be 37 crew members on the ANL ship, 33 on the British ship and 28 on the Scandinavian ship. I repeat: The larger Australian crews do less work than the smaller crews on the Scandinavian ships and, therefore, more has to be done by dockyard repair people. Not only are the wages high on the Australian ships and there are what are called 'more generous working conditions', which means crews do less work and the work they do not do has to be done by someone else, but also most Australian ships work a two-crew system whereby crews work 26 weeks a year, that is, six months on and six months off. A typical Scandinavian ship operates on a two-voyage on, one-voyage off system so that crews work 34 to 35 weeks a year. I do not think that anyone can say that the working conditions on Scandinavian ships are unreasonable. All this results in greater requirements of personnel.
