TALK.START.PARA: —One of my worries about the Crawford report when it was tabled last year was that people tended to talk in crew numbers as if that was the only problem. What we must look at is total crew costs including the two items I have just mentioned-how much or how little work crews do, shipboard maintenance and so on-and how many crews are needed to run a ship throughout the year. We seem to be moving with glacial slowness towards some reduction in the numbers of crew members on board each ship, but the problems of having six unions and demarcation disputes and skill limitations because of the separate unions make this a very slow process. For instance, there are eight cooks, stewards and crew attendants for a crew of 37. The reduction in any or all of the crew categories depends on negotiations and agreements by all of the unions involved. I have said here before and I repeat it now that there is an urgent need for an amalgamation of those six unions so that more sensible and economic crew arrangements and cross training of crew members might be developed in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I do not think that we want to get too carried away with how much crew reduction will save in overall freight costs. We might be able to make savings of perhaps 20 per cent in our crew costs, but it will take some time for this to be reflected in the decreased capital costs of new ships and the effects on running costs overall will be of the order of only 4 per cent or 5 per cent. This is still a saving worth making because shippers, and ultimately the community, pay this increased cost. It will not make a permanent turnaround in the economic efficiency of our coastal shipping.

The fourth point in the Minister's plan is to make ANL more commercial by freeing it from bureaucratic interference in its day to day running. I agree with this, although the way to make ANL truly commercial is for the Government to sell it. But while it remains the property of the Government we must see that there is proper reporting to the owners, that is, the people of Australia and this Parliament as their representatives. The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations has done a great deal of work in this area. But I do not think it would claim that the arrangements are at all satisfactory for the parliamentary supervision of government commercial bodies. The Opposition's amendment to be moved at the Committee stage-my colleague Senator Archer mentioned it-makes for better reporting from the ANL to the Parliament. I support this amendment although it is a second best to the Government getting out of this sort of operation which it is peculiarly ill-fitted to conduct.

The fifth point in the Minister's plan is to have a conducive climate for further growth in shipping. I am all for this as long as the growth is economic growth and not forced uneconomic growth. I have discussed already the problem of crew costs as opposed to crew numbers. I know that there will be further legislation to give effect to the recommendations for the accelerated depreciation allowance contained in the Crawford report. I will reserve judgment on that issue until I see what the legislation entails. If we are looking to our shipping as a means of improving transport within Australia, we have to be very clear what the economic benefits would be to the whole of Australian business and industry. If we are looking at overseas trade we have to be very clear we are not imposing a cost on the whole of the Australian community through increased depreciation allowances merely to featherbed a badly run industry.

I turn now to the decline in the Australian coastal shipping trade. Even in the subsidised Tasmanian trade, the most astonishing things seem to be transported by air because of the inefficiency of our coastal shipping. The first point we must consider is the competitiveness of coastal liner shipping with other forms of transport. I leave bulk carriers out of the discussions. Bulk goods will continue to be moved by sea as the only sensible way to move them. But for coastal liner services there are some serious problems in improving the competitiveness of our shipping. Road and rail transport services are at least 100 times more frequent than the shipping services. The road and rail services are faster. The shippers can identify their cargo much more clearly with the road or rail carrier who is conveying it. Shippers believe there is a much higher reliability of goods reaching their destination.

Road transport provides a shipper with a door to door service whereas sea transport involves other forms of transport as well as ships. Every time the cargo changes its mode of transport there are additional costs and the possibility of loss and pilfering. If these disadvantages are not offset there will not be any coastal liner business. It has already diminished considerably this year as the latest report shows. The advantages of road and rail-I have mentioned matters such as the reliability and the identification of cargo and the avoidance of change of mode of transport-could and should be offset by ships being able to move goods more economically. But do they as far as the Australian coastal trade is concerned? Is our coastal liner shipping economic at present?

I have mentioned already the increased costs through overmanning. I should mention also the very high costs of our inefficient ports which will have to be made at least adequate if we want to have a viable coastal shipping system. There is also the question of better depreciation allowances for the capital involved in coastal shipping to consider. Those two factors alone-reducing the crew costs and improving depreciation allowances-do not seem likely to reduce the cost of coastal shipping by more than about 10 per cent. Would such a reduction of 10 per cent in shipping costs be enough to improve the competitiveness of our coastal shipping in view of the disadvantages of using ships as compared to road or rail? I suspect not. That certainly seems to be the view of shippers. The cost advantage of coastal liner shipping just is not sufficient to overcome the other disadvantages.

Perhaps we should look instead to see whether the cost competition between the various transport modes is fair. Are not subsidies built into road and rail transport while sea transport is required to pay its full costs? I think it is fair to say that cost recovery from shipping is 100 per cent; that is, the services provided by the Government-lighthouses, port facilities and so on-are fully recovered from the people who ship their cargoes by sea, with the exception of course of the overt and deliberate subsidy for services to Tasmania and Darwin. I am leaving these out of the discussion for the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the subsidies on services to Tasmania?

—I will come to the subsidy to Tasmania in a moment. Although there is full cost recovery for shipping services, this full cost recovery is certainly not true for rail transport, which has a heavy built-in Government subsidy. TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Australian National Railways Bills cognately with this Bill and I will leave further comments on railways to my colleagues. Full cost recovery for governments is also not true for road transport. The annual expenditure on roads in recent years has exceeded the yield from fuel taxes, vehicle registration and drivers licence fees by 30 per cent. Damage to road surfaces accelerates with heavy axle loads. Cars and other light vehicles do virtually no damage to road surfaces but heavy vehicles do damage well beyond the proportion of higher fees the heavy road transport vehicles pay. It would seem that a rational pricing policy for transport should result in an increase of about 18 per cent in road freights and over 40 per cent in rail freights. Whether such increases would be politically feasible is another question. I am sure we all remember the 1979 truck operators blockade. One would also have to examine the effect on the whole Australian economy of this kind of attempt at rationalisation, making the various modes of transport compete on fair bases, bearing in mind the other objections of shippers to using the coastal trade reliability of service, costs of changing from ship to truck or rail, pilfering and so on. Those objections that they have to using the shipping service are not entirely connected with price.

SPEECH.PARA: I have left out of this discussion the question of defence, because I have argued before that the present size of our commercial shipping fleet is well in excess of any foreseeable defence requirements. Therefore, I do not consider defence a relevant argument for special subsidies for coastal shipping.

Would there be any advantage in eliminating cabotage which effectively excludes foreign ships from the Australian coastal trade? Cabotage was achieved by the 1912 Navigation Act which reserved coastal shipping for vessels licensed by the Australian Government. Licences are granted only for vessels with Australian crew levels and wage and accommodation levels. As no foreign vessels are crazy enough to do this, coastal trade is effectively reserved for Australian flag ships. There is one exception to cabotage. Single voyage permits may be given by the Department of Transport to foreign vessels where there is no suitable Australian vessel available. For example, foreign liquefied petroleum gas ships were used before there was a suitable Australian carrier. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing single voyage permits in the Australian coastal trade in recent years.

Low cost shipping subsidies by foreign governments, using cheaper labour with shorter holidays, would clearly make shipping more competitive and cheaper but I do not believe that such a proposal is possible, for political and industrial reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I want to talk about the costs to the Government of subsidising Australian coastal shipping. I accept, but I deplore, that it may be necessary for us to continue to subsidise shipping for Tasmania and Darwin, although I think that we should be working to eliminating the problems which make these subsidies necessary. Let me explain briefly why subsidies exist for Tasmania and Darwin. The ANL offers the only regular service between Darwin and the east coast ports. It used to operate monthly sailings in the ingeniously designed Darwin Trader. Nowadays that ship operates in the trans-Tasman trade and the Townsville Trader operates in and out of Darwin. In 1979 the then Minister was advised by the ANL to remove the service from Darwin because it was uneconomic. In 1980, temporary-I stress temporary-federal financial assistance was provided for this service to cover losses. Since then the temporary assistance has continued and has even increased. TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will observe from this table that the subsidy has increased in this financial year to $2m. From the annual report of the Australian National Line tabled today, it will be clear that this subsidy will not go very far towards covering the losses incurred in the Darwin service. It suggests that the loss will be about $2.5m. Why should this service continue at such enormous cost? The only answer is a political one. There is no economic reason why the Government should continue to subsidise the Darwin shipping trade to the tune of $2m. The service is intrinsically unprofitable. The ANL would like to withdraw its service; only the subsidy restrains it.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of Tasmania, the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme was introduced by the Commonwealth Government in 1976 because there were no, and obviously cannot be, road or rail links between Tasmania and the mainland. The report of the Nimmo Commission of Inquiry into Transport to and from Tasmania recommended that a maritime route to Tasmania be equated with a similar distance land route on the mainland and a subsidy provided which had the effect of equalising the sea route with a comparable land route. That sounds very fine in principle but there are a number of problems with the scheme and some very serious criticisms have been levelled at it, which I am sure most of my colleagues from Tasmania would accept.

First, sea routes are not the same as land routes. The unit cost of travel by sea falls sharply with distance so that longer hauls from Tasmania to Adelaide or Sydney are, in fact, over-subsidised. Secondly, the scheme provides no incentive to shipping companies to become more efficient and reduce their costs. The scheme reduces their expenses but provides no incentive to improve profits. Thirdly, Tasmanian shipping is expensive because there are too many ports, and Tasmania continues to support all these ports because anyone who recommends a premier port is quickly outvoted by the others. Fourthly, subsidies seem to invite scandals. One scandal involved peas which were shipped on a discount rate but the subsidy was paid on the full freight rate. The ANL seems to charge excessively because it has a monopoly of the trade and rips off the shippers between Tasmania and the mainland. Fifthly, as a result of the freight subsidy there is excess capacity on the Tasmanian route. There are 11 ships operating on the route whereas it is possible for all Tasmanian trade to be efficiently accommodated in a two ship service. All of this, in my view, confirms my earlier statement: The Government should not be in the business of shipping. Our coastal trade was profitable up to this year, but only with heavy government subsidies. It would be run more economically and more effectively and at less cost to the consumer if the Government got right out of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support the Australian Shipping Commission Amendment Bill, the Inter-State Commission Amendment Bill, the Australian National Railways Commission Bill and the Australian National Railways Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill. Despite the fact that we do have some reservations in certain areas, we see them as being a very worthwhile step forward in giving not only autonomy but, far more importantly, much more responsibility, to the respective bodies in the planning and conduct of the national rail and national shipping areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Taking the Bills individually, the Bill concerning the Railways Commission has a couple of problem areas for us. We acknowledge that the Commission will have additional autonomy. It will report to the Minister for Transport on its operations or on any other information that the Minister requires. I understand that in turn it will report through the Minister to the Parliament in the normal course of events. As a statutory body, it is my understanding that that is a requirement. The Committee on which I serve-the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations-investigates any facets of the reports of statutory bodies after, of course, they have been perused and commented on by the Senate as well as the House of Representatives. The setting of targets by each of these bodies is a desirable move. I am sure that in the past they have worked to some sort of short term and long term plan. But the setting of and agreeing on financial targets, general management targets, is an interesting aspect introduced into the legislation, which ensures that they work to proper managerial requirements. The Parliament, as a result of this measure, does not necessarily control the National Railways Commission in the direct sense in its day to day operations. In fact, it tends to minimise ministerial interference. But the Minister still has the power and the authority to direct the Commission, with his reasons for direction being placed before the Parliament.

One of the things that create a little uncertainty, the Prices Surveillance Authority Bill having now been passed, is the fact that the Minister may determine the principles for charge setting. This may clash with the authority of the PSA, particularly if one assumes that being a major price factor in this country's economy, the Treasurer might feel inclined to keep the railways' operations under constant surveillance. We are not sure what will be the effect of two Ministers directing their respective authorities to survey the pricing principles that are being set or being used. We see potential problems in that regard. It would help if the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) were to give us an indication of what would happen in the event of both Ministers wanting to poke their fingers into this area. I think it is important, if the Australian National Railways Commission is to function as a competitive body-it is competing, if not with other railways, certainly with other modes of transport-for it to have a greater degree of autonomy over its pricing and for it to answer not only to its own Minister, but to a prices surveillance authority which is more of a market-place authority than that controlled by the Minister who has responsibility for the profitability of the enterprise. A difficulty that we are experiencing-it is interesting to note that it has been raised in another area-concerns clause 74 of the Bill which reads:
Notwithstanding any law of a State or Territory to the contrary, the Commission is not required to fence, or to maintain any fence erected in connection with, any railway operated by it.
This clause replaces the previous section 87 of the Act, which read:
The Commission shall not, unless the Minister so directs, be required to fence any portion of the railways, but it may erect and maintain such fences in connection therewith as it thinks proper.

I suppose it may depend on the reading of the new clause. But my reading of it indicates that from now on it will not be the responsibility of the Commission to erect or maintain fences alongside any railway line operated by the Commission. If that is the case, it will create havoc across Australia wherever the Commission has railway lines, because suddenly there will be no responsibility for existing fences or for newly required fences. If I have misinterpreted that clause, I believe it is important for the Senate to have an interpretation, an assurance or whatever we can glean from the Minister, that the Commission is not precluded from erecting or maintaining fences under this new lgislation. It was not precluded under the previous legislation and we can see no reason for its being precluded from erecting or maintaining fences under the new legislation.

I turn to the Australian National Line, the shipping area. Again, it is a good step forward in ensuring that under this legislation corporate planning will be effected, will be responsible to the Minister, and that the Australian Shipping Commission will develop its policies and report to the Minister every 12 months on those policies. I would like to have an assurance from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs who is at the table, that the reporting to the Minister will be followed by the tabling of that report in the Parliament in the normal way and that the Parliament will have an opportunity each year to review the activities of ANL. Again, I think that as this body is being established more and more as an independent, more autonomous and more competitive organisation, it is important that the Parliament be informed, but not necessarily be in direct control; nor should the Minister be in direct day to day control. The officers of the Commission should get on with the job and if they are not capable of doing so, they should be replaced by those who are capable of competing profitably in an open market. Price setting again comes into that category. If they are to compete, they need to have the ability-given certain guidelines-to control prices, to set prices and, as I said earlier in talking about the Railways Commission, to have the overview, if it is needed, of the Prices Surveillance Authority.

I turn my attention now to the Inter-State Commission, which has had a very chequered history since 1912 when it first commenced to operate. It is interesting to note, as has been mentioned earlier, that it is a requirement of the Constitution-certainly, it is embraced and suggested by the Constitution- that there be such an Inter-State Commission. When it was introduced legislatively in 1912 it operated for three years. But a High Court challenge in 1915 to the exercise of the judicial powers of the ISC meant that it was then allowed to lapse until in 1975 an Act was passed in this Parliament, but not proclaimed until 27 September this year. This Bill picks up the principles of that legislation and ensures that we have an effective Inter-State Commission. It will still be left to the Government to give it the tasks and to ensure that it does play a role in ensuring that we do have free and open trade, that we do not have the sorts of problems that are created by those, particularly at a State level, who would interfere with the free trade between the States and who would interfere with the ability of organisations to operate internationally on the best possible terms.

One of the difficulties that we envisage as a result of this legislation is that there is potential for duplication with the Bureau of Transport Economics, with the Transport Industries Advisory Council, with the Industries Assistance Commission and with the Trade Practices Commission. But I guess there will be a settling down process, and if there is overlapping nature will take its path and the role for the Inter-State Commission will ultimately be more accurately defined. It has only an advisory capacity and that is a safeguard. It means it will not be rampaging around the country upsetting State Premiers and others and its recommendations would need to be put into legislation if they were acceptable to this Parliament. Of course, there is the safeguard of the Constitution to prevent the Parliament from going overboard.

The Commission may function just from time to time, but it certainly has the potential for an ongoing role. I think it would be helpful if the Minister could indicate whether he sees it having an ongoing role and whether he believes it would be better for it to have such a role rather than be an ad hoc operation. I think one of the things the Commission would need to be concerned with is the tendency towards increasing centralisation. It is to be hoped that that is not going to be one of its objectives. In our view, its objective is to smooth the path for easy co-operation rather than to increase centralisation.

The role of the Inter-State Commission in investigating the causes and effects of industrial disputes is something that I would like to see it take on board. I think that for far too long the Commonwealth Government has turned its back on industrial disputes which affect States other than the State in which the dispute arises. For instance, it is all very well for the airline pilots to say 'Let's close down Canberra and sort out these politicians', but that does have an effect on other States, not just on the people of the Australian Capital Territory. I think one of the potential functions of this body will be to look at that sort of dispute, to look at the effects a local flare-up in the New South Wales railways could have across the Australian mainland, and try to judge whether there are alternative methods of ensuring, where practicable, that such disputes do not arise to the point that they affect States other than the State which is directly concerned with the dispute in question.

In general, the Australian Democrats, as I indicated earlier, support this package of Bills. We believe that it is a step in the direction of making the bodies more autonomous, more responsible and therefore giving them not only the right and the power but also the requirement to plan and to function as corporate bodies would function under similar circumstances. We commend the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words about the Inter- State Commission Amendment Bill 1983, which amends the Inter-State Commission Act 1975. I appreciate that we are not able to canvass the provisions of the principal Act, although in reality we are debating the matter a second time. The principal Act was passed in this Parliament in 1975; however, it came into operation on only 27 September of this year. So this gives us, in this chamber, an opportunity of expressing a view about what is not a potential operation of the Inter-State Commission but what is likely to be an actual operation of the Commission. Because the Government has indicated that the first task of the Commission will be the investigation of transport to and from Tasmania as it relates to the freight equalisation scheme, of course it is important for honourable senators from Tasmania to be aware of the possibility of problems which the Commission may confront and which may result from its work. Let us hope it can recommend the tidying up of certain of the anomalies and problems that are being experienced in the freight equalisation scheme. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes), in his second reading speech, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission we shall establish will in fact investigate and advise government on allegations of discriminatory practices, inequalities, inefficiencies and anomalies in interstate transport.
Later on he said:
The . . . Commission will be required to carry out wide ranging investigations covering economic, social, institutional and legal-constitutional issues affecting interstate transport.

Mr Deputy President, in your contribution you referred to shipping to and from Tasmania, which of course is all part and parcel of a consideration of freight equalisation. You mentioned the existence of a number of ports in Tasmania. It may be that the Inter-State Commission could suggest that in its terms, as listed by the Minister, this an inefficiency. But it also has the responsibility to carry out wide ranging investigations covering the economic, social, institutional and legal-constitutional issues affecting interstate transport.

Clearly, a number of people in Tasmania consider that the existence of viable ports throughout the length and breath of the State is a matter of considerable social concern for the State of Tasmania. How much weight, for example, will the Inter-State Commission give to that view? How will it balance that against its possible consideration of the inefficiencies that may derive from the fact that there are these viable ports in various parts of Tasmania? What weight will the Commission give to the desire amongst many Tasmanians to see decentralisation in practice. What weight will it give to the principle of subsidiarity? These are all questions which have not been answered. Perhaps they have not been addressed or asked until this stage. Maybe it is not possible for the Minister to answer them. Maybe that is what the establishment of the Inter-State Commission is all about. If that is so, it is very important to ensure that the final balanced judgment is made by the elected representatives of the people.

I notice that this Bill does not seek to amend the principal Act in a way that I believe it should, and that is to give more say to a State parliament and a State government in respect of decisions that may flow from considerations undertaken by the Inter-State Commission. I would have thought it would have been in the interests of the upkeep of constitutional responsibility for reports of the Inter-State Commission to be forwarded, immediately on receipt by the Commonwealth Minister for Transport, to the relevant State Ministers for Transport for tabling in the relevant State parliaments. After all, we are dealing with a commission which was envisaged and provided for in the Constitution.

Senator Evans mentioned a moment ago that perhaps the Commission might give consideration to questions of industrial disputes which have effect beyond the borders of one State. This is a matter on which, of course, the Commission would have to tread very warily. After all, the provisions of section 51 (xxxv) of the Constitution are clear. They provide for the establishment of machinery for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes extending beyond the limits of any one State. The Parliament has determined that that machinery will be established in the form of, for example, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. So just how far is it intended that the Inter-State Commission will cut across the powers and the responsibilities of bodies such as the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the State industrial tribunals, the Industries Assistance Commission, the National Companies and Securities Commission and the price surveillance and trade practices areas? These are questions that, in my view at least, really have not been adequately addressed in the second reading speech of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes ). It may well be that we will have some clarification from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) when he responds at the end of the second reading stage or during the Committee stage.

The other aspect, of course, is the question of exclusions. The exclusions contained in the Bill include matters relating to the former Airlines Agreement, the new 1981 Airlines Agreement and the related Independent Air Fares Committee Act. However, the Minister says that as domestic air freight is no longer regulated through the Airlines Agreement it will now come within the ambit of the Inter-State Commission. It is going to be pretty awkward for the Inter-State Commission to consider what is justifiable and what is not justifiable in the carriage of air freight when it cannot see the picture as a whole. I know, and those who were on the Senate Select Committee on Passenger Fares and Services to and from Tasmania know, that a large volume of freight is carried on regular airline passenger services to and from Tasmania.

It is all very well for me to pick holes in something that has been prepared with thought and recommendations have been made. I do not want to be negative about this because it may well be that the Inter-State Commission is the body that is required to have the ongoing responsibility for surveillance of all of these matters. My worry, however, is that this arrangement could become a bureaucratic nightmare, not only to transporters but also to manufacturers, miners and business generally. In particular it could be somewhat of a nightmare to those who are charged with responsibilities in the various States for areas that are likely to be covered by the Inter-State Commission. Therefore, I would like to know from the Government what steps have been taken to ensure that the Commission has appointed to it people who not only have the expertise that is mentioned in Part II of the principal Act to investigate such things as the freight equalisation scheme but also have empathy with and understanding of the geographical areas that are under consideration. Mr Deputy President, I will not canvass the other matters that have been raised, in particular those raised by your good self, because that can remain for a later time-probably the occasion of the presentation to the Parliament of the first report of the Inter-State Commission will be that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The four Bills that the Senate is debating are part of the Government's total approach to the transport problems that exist in this country. The Government is looking to see that our transport industry not only is commercially viable and efficient but also is able to carry out in a cost effective way its basic role in a modern economy. Of course, to do that effectively we need and we recognise the role that has to be played by both the public and private sectors. The Government believes that this package of Bills will have the effect of meeting those objectives. We are confident that the passage of the Bills through the Senate will enable a great improvement to be made to the efficiency of our transport industries throughout Australia, not in a dictatorial, bureaucratic or authoritarian way but through consultation with the States. That is where the responsibility lies for a big portion of the public transport sector. Other publicly owned transport instrumentalities are associated with the Commonwealth. So we are looking for co-operation, consultation and some understanding of the role that needs to be played by the two sectors.

SPEECH.PARA: It has to be accepted that transport has come a long way since Federation. At the time when the Constitution was written people could never have envisaged the great changes that would come across the transport system or the role that private transportation would play in a modern economy. We did not envisage and could not have envisaged the national highway system which we now have and which we are still trying to improve. The purpose of the legislation is to take all these matters into account in a system based on co-operation and consultation with all the authorities, the State governments, the private sector entrepreneurs and the instrumentalities that have been established at the Commonwealth level over the years. It was suggested that I should sum up in about 10 minutes the Government's position. In the wide-ranging debate that has taken place that is rather a tall order. I am required to answer a number of questions which I believe flow from some confusion about what is the Government' s intention in the legislation.

I remind the Senate that the Inter-State Commission has been around for a very long number of years. In the years that have elapsed since the Constitution was written it has not been effective. There are probably good reasons for that, such as the occurrence of World War II. We should look at the various ideological trends that exist within Australian political thought. Conservative governments have tried on at least two occasions to resuscitate and make more effective the Inter-State Commission. A royal commission looked at transport problems in 1929 and called for the reintroduction of the Commission. In 1959 a joint parliamentary committee saw the need to reactivate the Inter-State Commission. The need for such an investigatory body was seen by all shades of political opinion in the Parliament. The Nimmo Commission of Inquiry into Transport to and from Tasmania, as Tasmanian senators have said, inquired into the basic problems of transportation in regard to that State. A Senate standing committee also suggested the reconstitution of the ISC. There is an abundance of empirical evidence to show that the Government is not on some wild capricious enterprise but that rather it is taking into account all the non-partisan evidence of the need to reactivate and reconstitute this body and give it new vigour.

Similarly, the Government has, in its few brief months in office, injected funds into the Australian National Line. It considered that the under- capitalisation of that organisation was affecting its efficiency and its competitive role, which was referred to in the debate. The important role that the Australian National Railways plays in our modern transport system has also been referred to in debates in times past. The Government has the concept that the legislation will allow it in consultation, not confrontation, to reach a rational decision on all aspects of the transport industry. That, of course, includes transport costs. We hear a great deal in debates in the Parliament about the need to reduce unit costs of production. Rarely is the need to reduce the cost of services referred to and transport, of course, assumes an important role in that respect. So the Government, whilst not denying the need to have a more efficient industry, industrial and commercial based, also recognises the need to apply the same principles to transportation. In a country as large and as diverse as Australia, in a country in which we have public and private competition and regulation, it must surely be accepted that we do not necessarily have a cost effective transport industry. The role of the Inter- State Commission is not to impose its will-it was never intended that it would have that role-but rather to have an investigatory, advisory and consultative role to highlight some of the deficiencies that clearly exist in the transport system in Australia.

I am sure that honourable senators who have indicated general support for the Australian Shipping Commission Amendment Bill will be aware that the Bill is an essential ingredient in the decision of the Government not only to make funds available but also to establish a five-point plan to arrest the decline that has been apparent in the ANL for some time. It will provide the Commission with more commercial freedom, allow it to become more market oriented and free it from bureaucratic restraints. One would expect, therefore, that honourable senators in the Opposition would be highly delighted with that approach because it is part of the Opposition's day to day rhetoric that we hear in debates in the Parliament. With the injection of $90m in capital the Government is putting its money where its mouth is. It has undertaken initiatives to seek the co-operation of the seagoing unions and the Commission has generally accepted the brief to establish a more efficient organisation based on productivity and competitiveness. We believe the legislation we are asking the Senate to approve will see a revitalisation of the Commission itself. That is our confidence, our hope and our objective. Obviously, these are only the first steps to improving the Commission's fortunes. Continued co-operation, therefore, will be sought from all those interested in the future of the Commission. We believe the Commission will be well placed to take advantage of any improvement in world trading. Of course, it has a role, as has been suggested in the debate, in that respect.

I now turn to the Australian National Railways Commission Bill. The Federal Government, quite clearly, has a major interest in improving the efficiency of railways in Australia's national transport system. We think the performance of our railways can be improved by the introduction of a more flexible and commercial management system and a more consistent national transport policy, which the Government believes is inherent in the legislation that is being debated. It provides the Commonwealth Railways-Australian National-with the flexibility to operate as a commercial organisation while retaining proper accountability to Parliament. Who would challenge that concept? Of course, it must be said that we desire, at all times, to have these instrumentalities accountable to Parliament. The new legislation provides Australian National with a modern legislative charter which clearly defines its powers and removes many of the anachronisms. The legislation naturally flows from learning from the deficiencies of yesterday. At the same time, the Government expects Australian National to be dynamic and expansive in its approach and to look for new traffic in extending its business operations. We need to take a national view of Australian railways because with such adequate investment and improved efficiency we believe the Australian railways will play an essential role in the development of Australia for the rest of this century and beyond.

The Government sees the Inter-State Commission as an important step in fulfilling an election commitment. We believe that it will be a significant instrument in the Government's policy for developing a rational, efficient, national transport system and will provide a means of investigating discriminatory practices-I do not think any honourable senator can deny that-and preferential practices that do exist in the conduct of interstate transport. But , as I pointed out, it has no regulatory or judicial powers and will not interfere in matters unrelated to interstate transport. But, certainly, it will have a role to play in looking at interstate transport. No existing permanent body is empowered to conduct the breadth of investigation required to assist the Government in its national transport goals. The provision for such a body is made quite explicit in our Constitution. Therefore, we see the ISC as part of our Federal system. It is not a dominant part, but part of a system which is based on co-operative federalism-a phrase that we have heard at great length over the years. It will have the authority and the independence necessary to perform this vital role.

In the few moments that I have left, I will deal with some of the points that we raised in the debate. Senator Archer understandably raised a number of points that he felt needed some clarification. He pointed out that he saw the ISC as being very limited in its charter. He was critical of the fact that the airlines agreement was not to receive attention, that the ISC could not initiate its own inquiries and could not look into overseas transport. The honourable senator also said that in doing his homework on the Inter-State Commission Amendment Bill he found in the Press release of the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) and the Department's information sheets that there was very little detail of what the ISC was going to do. He drew attention to what clearly is a disadvantage which exists in Tasmania with transport. I remind Senator Archer that the very powers that he mentioned as being deficient in the legislation were the powers that were removed from the Inter-State Commission Amendment Bill 1975 by the very same coalition Government which is responsible for the contribution of members of the Opposition today. The honourbale senator must be reminded that once legislaton is passed, the ISC is established and reference is made to the Commission, details will then be made available. I assure the honourable senator that all the different parties that I have referred to in the debate will be consulted.

Senator Archer has foreshadowed amendments that he will move in the Committee of the Whole. I might as well deal with this matter now to save dealing with it later. It has to be said that the Government cannot accept the amendments even though I can appreciate that there has been some change in the wording of the amendments proposed to be moved in the Senate compared with the amendments which were moved in the House of Representatives. The honourable senator must appreciate that to make information available to the Parliament, which has been suggested in the amendments, would be commercially very damaging to the Australian National Line. If that information is left out of the information which is provided to the Parliament, I am advised that it would not be of much value. It is not just a question of the Minister having the power to delete certain portions of that information. The document would become fairly unimportant and unintelligible if the deletions were made and if it were just left to the whim of the Minister of the day.

I point out to the Senate also that, if we were to adopt the amendments, it would have the effect of delaying the legislation certainly until the last week in February. I am advised that this would be very detrimental to the operations of the ANL, would be very detrimental to the establishment of the ISC and certainly will not assist the aims of government, which are to get on with the job concerning transport costs and transport efficiencies. For those reasons, we will oppose the amendments in the Committee of the Whole.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to what the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) has had to say, but I will still proceed with my amendments. These amendments were moved in another form in the other chamber. The objection was only on the basis that the disclosure of certain items may have an adverse effect on the financial interests of the Inter-State Commission, that is, on intimate operating matters. I believe that my amendment to this Bill takes that into account quite adequately. I believe it should attract support not only from the Government but also from the Commission. I think it would be quite right for the Commission to appreciate the assistance that this could give it, as it should give assistance to the Government at the same time.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been advised in the speeches that have been made and in the provisions of the Inter-State Commission Bill that the organisation is to become more professional and more commercial. I believe that the production of commercial information is not unreasonable. I will not be looking for further information than what we obtain from other commercial organisations. I believe that it is desirable to have better figures and better trading and operating information than is currently available. The Commission, with its new commercial image, will be able to perform any role and will welcome an addition to the program it has at the moment. Therefore, I move:
Page 13, sub-clause 8 (1), at end of proposed new section 19B, add the following sub-sections:

'(6) The Minister shall cause a copy of every report furnished to him by the commission under sub-section (3) to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the report is received by him.

(7) Notwithstanding sub-section (6), if the Minister is of the opinion that a report furnished to him by the Commission under sub-section (3) contains a matter the disclosure of which would have a substantial adverse effect on the financial interests of the Commission, the Minister shall cause the report to be amended to exclude the matter, and shall cause to be laid before each House of the Parliament, within 15 sitting days of that House after the report is received by him, the report as amended, together with a statement that the report has been amended in accordance with this sub-section.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I indicated in the second reading debate that the Government will oppose this amendment. We believe that we are dealing with a commercial enterprise which is accountable to the Parliament; it is also accountable to the Minister. It would be regressive to put it into a disadvantaged position by adopting the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave an undertaking to a constitutent to raise two questions. Both of these questions have been raised in other forums. The constituent is Mr Partridge from Launceston who has taken quite an interest in Australian National. He asked that separate statistics be included in the annual report on a State basis and as to cause and, secondly, whether it would be possible to have separate accounting for the various activities of Australian National.

—It would be inopportune if we let this occasion go by without saying that all those who have referred to Australian National today could well receive nasty letters from a certain ex-senator from South Australia who would not have approved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt). He may now have had an opportunity to compare the old legislation, the Commonwealth National Railways Act, with the new legislation, the Australian National Railways Commission Bill which we are now considering. Section 87 of the old Act says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commissioner shall not, unless the Minister so directs, be required to fence any portion of the railways, but he may erect and maintain such fences in connection therewith as he thinks proper.
The Bill before us simply says:
Notwithstanding any law of a State or Territory to the contrary, the Commission is not required to fence, or to maintain any fence erected in connection with, any railway operated by it.

There is a serious omission in the new Bill. It implies not only that there is no requirement but also that there is no ability to fence railways under the control of the Australian National Railways Commission. I would appreciate an explanation from the Minister as to the reason for that change if that is a change which is about to be implemented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to Senator Jack Evans for not answering, but I was under some constraints with respect to time. I am advised that nothing in the legislation would prevent the fencing of railways, except the cost involved as most of our railways pass through remote areas. I suppose that Australian National and the Government would take the view, as I hope the Parliament would, that fencing is not needed in those areas which are largely in very remote parts of the Commonwealth. However, where railways run through urban areas, I am advised, Australian National does have a policy of maintaining its fencing. Australian National is prepared to discuss difficulties which arise with particular land owners and, where appropriate, contribute to the cost of maintaining such fencing.

SPEECH.PARA: In the earlier debate the honourable senator referred to clause 78. I am told that that clause, which concerns penalties for endangering safety, will be invoked only if deliberate action is taken which endangers safety. So, there is an appreciation of the problems which exist. I understand that the legal advice given to Australian National is that a person would not be in contravention of this clause by taking no action. I give the example of a land owner who does not fence a particular property. Whilst we appreciate the honourable senator's concern, the matter has to be looked at from the point of view of cost. If a problem affects a particular area or land owner, that is a matter for negotiation and consultation between the appropriate parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I get a little more clarification because the Minister's remarks as they will appear in Hansard will record existing policy before the Bill is passed? The House of Representatives returns to the Senate the Bill entituled A Bill for an Act to amend the 'Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Act 1906', and acquaints the Senate that the House of Representatives has agreed to Amendments Nos. 1 to 3 and 5 to 12 made by the Senate, and has disagreed to Amendment No. 4 , set forth in the annexed Schedule, and for the Reasons shown therein.
The House of Representatives desires the reconsideration by the Senate of the Bill in respect of the amendment disagreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Committee does not insist on the amendment of the Senate to which the House of Representatives has disagreed.

If the Committee defeats this motion and if it insists accordingly on the amendment being retained, the effect will be to deny the Government the capacity to spend any money on promoting the referendum campaign; that is, any money over and above the $5m already being allocated for the preparation and distribution of the even-handed Yes and No cases required under the electoral legislation. The effect of defeating this motion would also be, of course, to require the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Amendment Bill to go back to the House of Representatives which does not propose to meet again until after the proposed referendum date, 25 February.

The Government has made it clear that for a variety of reasons it and those supporting the Yes case must be able to spend a substantial sum which we have estimated to be $1.25m on the promotion of the Yes case if the referendum is to be worth pursuing. Those reasons are partially set out in the message sent to us from the House of Representatives. They have also been spelt out in some considerable detail in public discussions on this matter over the past few days. I will not burden the Senate with wearisome repetition because the arguments are well known. However, they are essentially as follows: First, the general point is that the No case in that referendum campaign starts with a general advantage when one takes into account the inevitable complexity of the matters and the inevitable degree of apathy so far as voters are concerned on matters which they do not perceive to be immediately and directly related to the government of the country. The way in which voters traditionally respond to any degree of controversy in matters of public life when referendums are concerned tends to be in the form of a No vote.

The second point-a more specific one-is that in the context of this referendum campaign the No case has a particular advantage because of the very overtly expressed willingness of Mr Bjelke-Petersen in Queensland to run it as a full election style campaign and the very precisely stated intention of Mr Gray in Tasmania to spend taxpayers money in that State to support the No case, whatever the rationale of the No case may be. There is no doubt that, whether derived solely from Mr Bjelke-Petersen and Mr Gray or whether from other familiar sources in Western Australia, there will be massive No case expenditure in the pivotal State of Western Australia in particular. It is equally the case that unless money is forthcoming from the Federal Treasury to counter that massive expenditure on the No case, targeted particularly as it will no doubt be in Western Australia, there will be no other funds available of the necessary significant scale.

The third point is that the particular justification for the Yes campaign expenditure and this case lies in the extraordinarily, by referendum history standards, consensual character of the proposals that are being put forward. As I have said on innumerable occasions, they represent the product of either substantial majority or unanimous support at successive meetings of the Australian Constitutional Convention over the whole period since 1973. They also reflect massive support in this Parliament. It may be that in the case of the Australian Democrats, as they have continually sought to make clear, that in some instances that support for the conduct of a referendum is not to be construed as support for the particular substantive content of the proposal in question. Notwithstanding that, there has been, as the figures amply demonstrate , an overwhelming preponderance of parliamentary support for these proposals. The No case proponents by contrast represent little more than a raggle-taggle rump of the whole body of parliamentarians in this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what has got you into trouble so far, Senator Evans, and it will continue to get you into trouble.
—To make that point perfectly clear, had I thought that any more decorous an approach to Senator Crichton-Browne would produce any more rational response, I would be a model of charm and grace.
—You pompous drip.
—Pompous what?
—Pompous drip!
—That is better than what I thought the honourable senator said. I thought it was a little more alliterative, but never mind. I cannot, accordingly, ask the honourable senator to withdraw.
—It is better than a spoonerism you once used.
—A shining wit, as Dr Spooner might have said.
—I think that is unfortunate, Mr Chairman.

—Senator Baume asked for that contribution. I noticed Senator Chipp's description of him the other day as a ball of fire in this place . I revert to the point I was making. The nature and the quality of the opposition is not revealed by the statistics but certainly the quantity is.
