TALK.START.PARA: —The final point to be made is simply that the amount of expenditure involved, $1.25m, in absolute terms is quite small and in relative terms, by comparison with the cost of referendum conduct itself-$21m-is again very small. Nonetheless, small as it may be, the amount in question is absolutely crucial in our judgment to match the kind of opposition expenditure one can expect from the No case supporters, given in particular the selective way in which that expenditure will undoubtedly be targeted.
—Why do you not spend the money on something else instead?

—I hear the sound of the nightingale but I shall not respond. Against this background the Government decided and yesterday announced the following decision which, of course, has received a certain degree of notoriety in the public prints since that time. The Government's decision was to the following effect: If, when this matter goes to the vote, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats-I do not want to exclude Senator Harradine from this but the decision was in these terms-continue to insist first that the Government can spend nothing on promoting the Yes case or, secondly, that the Government must spend an equal amount on promoting both the Yes and No cases over and above the $5m which the Government is already committed to spending on preparing and distributing the statutory Yes-No pamphlet, the proposed referendums will not proceed on 25 February. That remains the Government's position. There is still time, of course, for a majority of the members of the Senate to accept the Government's position and to appreciate and acknowledge the force and, I hope, the genuineness of the arguments which we are advancing. There is perhaps still time for some kind of compromise proposal to emerge. Many such proposals have been floated in discussions around this place in the last week or so. I believe that at least one was seriously floated as recently as last night. It appears however on the information available to me a few moments ago that there is simply no mood for the accommodation elsewhere in this chamber, certainly not among the Liberal and National parties and, apparently, not now so far as the Australian Democrats are concerned. Finally, more genuinely with sorrow than anger at this stage, I say that if that is so, let the responsibility for the failure of these referendums to proceed at this stage rest squarely upon the shoulders of those who have demonstrated their commitment to constitutional reform in this country as being, notwithstanding a great deal of rhetoric to the contrary, paper thin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is opposed to the motion that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has moved. The Opposition insists on the amendment which I moved and which the Opposition, the Democrats and Senator Harradine supported last week. The Attorney-General and the Government are asking us to abandon the principle which is stated in that amendment with the rather strange threat that Senator Evans has been conveying to us on behalf of the Government for the last 24 hours or so. But the Opposition is committed to the principle that no money should be expended by the Commonwealth in respect of presentation of the argument either for or against a proposed law other than through the provisions that already exist in the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Act or in respect of the matters which have been mentioned in the amendment which specifically excludes the travelling expenses and accommodation expenses of members of parliament who engage in the campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: For a long time the position under the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Act has been that there is to be an even-handed expenditure by the Commonwealth Government in respect of referendums. Under that Act, the Government has the obligation to fund the Yes and No cases. The funding is not based upon any percentage of support for the Yes or No case in the Parliament or anywhere else. It is a fundamental principle. It is a perfectly correct and fair principle that there ought to be equal expenditure of government moneys so that the arguments for and against a proposed change to the Constitution should be available to the electors. This Attorney-General persuaded the Government, in his utter overweaning enthusiasm for his program of constitutional reform, to commit-

TALK.START.PARA: —Obsession.

—Yes, perhaps that may be so as well. He has persuaded the Government to commit an additional $1.25m to the presentation of the Yes case only and not for the No case. The principle of the Act on which referendum campaigns have been conducted by governments in the past would be subverted by this proposal without any authority of this Parliament and without the funds being included, as they could well have been, in the Appropriation Bills. Had they been so included, the Parliament could at least have had discussions on the matter. That is the point we are discussing, and the Opposition is opposed to any further government funds, other than those that are provided for under the Act and those which parliamentarians will expend if they take part in this campaign, being spent on a referendum campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: We have not suggested that funds should be provided or that the $1.25m should be equally divided between the Yes and No cases or divided in any other way. Our amendment is confined to the principle that there should not be these sorts of government expenditures. We insist on that amendment and hope that the Senate will insist on it. These sorts of expenditures on presentation of the case in the media are for those who will promote the Yes case-the Party organisations, other organisations, members or others who are concerned in promoting either the Yes case or the No case. The Government's expenditure should be confined as it is in the existing legislation to the Yes and No cases in an even-handed way. The Attorney-General has said that this expenditure is justified because the Yes case would start from scratch and therefore there has to be expenditure of a large sum of money to equalise the chances. I suggest that that is an absurd argument. In fact, there have been successful referendums in the past. As recently as 1977, three out of the four proposals were passed without any government expenditure of this kind promoting them. Indeed, the fourth proposal which was not passed, as Senator Evans told us earlier today, attracted 62 per cent of the total vote. It is really quite absurd and an insult to the Australian electors to suggest that they cannot understand a Yes and No case which is presented to them. They can and they do vote for proposals that they see to be worthwhile.

In 1977 the electors accepted three out of the four proposals and 62 per cent supported the fourth proposal. Therefore, all the proposals were supported by a majority of the people; so they can quite well understand. It was not only in 1977 that this occurred. In 1967 the referendum to give this Parliament the power to pass laws with respect to Aboriginal people was passed. That referendum was passed with the overwhelming support of the Australian people. So the Attorney's argument is absurd and is completely refuted by experience of the facts. That is the only argument the Attorney-General uses to justify this totally unjustifiable expenditure of public moneys in a totally unfair way. For those reasons, the Opposition will maintain its views and principles in regard to this matter. If the Government then wants to act like a spoilt child and say, 'Well, we are not going to go on playing the game any longer because we cannot get our way', the responsibility for calling off these referendums is fairly and squarely on the Government and the Attorney-General's head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment which has been returned from the House of Representatives deals with a proposition which we discussed last time the Bill was before us. It relates to this Senate's requirement that no money over and above the amount set aside formally be expended. I indicated on behalf of the Democrats at that time that if the Government wished to expend additional moneys we would support it, provided those moneys were spent in an even-handed fashion. The reason for taking that view is that there is a reasonable case for saying that the presentation of these propositions, or any proposition to change the Constitution, ought to be able to use the most up to date media services. When this legislation was first drafted television did not exist. It seems to me perfectly reasonable to suggest that there should be some television advertising but that that ought to be done in an even-handed fashion. There has been quite a deal of comment in the media in relation to this, most of which has been directed at the Australian Democrats for one reason or another. I will outline why we will support the Opposition's amendment and our basis for supporting it. I think there is some rather interesting material floating around that is based upon the notion-I do not know whether the Attorney has put it out, but it was picked up by one newspaper-that the Attorney can be compared to Sisyphus--
—He did it himself.
—Give me credit for it.

—I would refer the Minister to the book by Camus, The Myth of Sisyphus, which doubtless he has read. The myth which has been propagated by the media and probably by the Attorney-General himself is that in this package we have great constitutional reforms. The first two reforms came from Mr Fraser. I would draw the attention of the Attorney-General to a very interesting speech he made in this House last year in which he thoroughly bucketed the previous Prime Minister. He did a very good hatchet job on him and on the notion that he was a constitutional reformer. He is now touting around the two things which Mr Fraser put up. The simultaneous election proposal is nothing more than an attempt to give the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) additional powers. Why one would see a four- year term rather than a three-year term as a great advance I do not know. At least when Mr Wran did this, he reduced the length of time of the Upper House. The Attorney-General proposes to increase the term of the Upper House. I would like to hear his explanation as to why that is a great breakthrough in electoral , political or constitutional reform.

SPEECH.PARA: The other three schemes the Attorney thought up all by himself. These are really very interesting in terms of constitutional reforms. The first one will do nothing more than allow the referral of powers from one State to the Commonwealth or back again, if they so desire. Section 51 of the Constitution already allows State governments to refer powers to the Federal Parliament. If anybody is interested, every State has done so and the States are listed. If the Federal Government wants the States to do anything it finds it very easy to persuade them by providing the financial resources. The rest are not likely to effect anybody in this country one way or another. Certainly, none of the electors will be terribly interested in whether they are passed or not because they will not effect them.

The next reform is to allow the High Court to make judgment on a Bill of the Parliament before it receives royal assent rather than after. Presumably that will be terribly important to the electorate. The last reform means that every time the Constitution is printed we will use less paper. That is all it means. It proposes to remove outmoded clauses. The reason I mention these five questions is because the Attorney said they had to be put in lieu of some other reforms which could have been put. He said other reforms could not be put because we had these five reforms. Another reform I could mention relates to fixed terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which he voted against.

—The Attorney-General voted against it. That would be a massive constitutional reform if put to the people. It would be a good constitutional reform, and the Attorney-General voted in this place against it going to the people.
—What about giving us some of your private views which you have retailed to me in the last few days instead of this party line?

—The Attorney has a chance to do it and I will retail some of his. The next reform that I propose in this House, and which the Government supported, related to breaking the nexus. That proposal could have been put in in place of the last one. Whether one agreed with it or not, it would be a significant reform. The last reform was moved by Senator Mason on a number of occasions. I refer to the citizens initiative. Whether one agreed with it or not , if it were put to the people it would be a significant reform as distinct from the whole package which has been put by the Attorney-General. This is not, I repeat, a package of amazing constitutional reforms.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to raise a separate issue now and that is the way in which the whole debate has been conducted. If the Attorney-General had not wished to win every brownie point, to paste people in corners and to have the last word, we may very well be in a different situation now. I would like to read an interesting bit of history. I refer to something which happened yesterday. I issued a Press release which said:

Senator Michael Macklin (Democrat Queensland) today drew attention to a section of the Constitution that the Attorney-General may have overlooked in his willingness to drop the referenda scheduled for February 1984. Section 128 of the Constitution reads, in part:
''This Constitution shall not be altered except in the following manner:

The proposed law for the alteration thereof must be passed by an absolute majority of each House of Parliament, and not less than two nor more than six months after its passage through both Houses the proposed law shall be submitted in each State and Territory to the electors . . .
I went on to say:

Given that the five referenda proposals were passed by an absolute majority of each House of Parliament, how does the Government propose to avoid the implied obligation in the words ''shall be submitted''?.

With these Bills being passed by both Houses on November 17, 1983 they would have to be submitted prior to May 17, 1984 otherwise the Bills would have to be presented to parliament again before they could be submitted to the people . . .
I thought that was a reasonable approach and it raised a question. The Attorney' s Press release in response to my statement was:

1. If the referendums scheduled for February 1984 are dropped, it will be because of the intransigence of the Australian Democrats and the coalition parties in the Senate, and not because of any willingness on my or the Government's part to abandon them.
2. Section 128 of the Constitution serves one function and one function only: to lay down a set of requirements which must be complied with if a valid referendum is to be held . . .
3. Senator Macklin's understanding of the Constitution is clearly as slight as his commitment to allowing the people to have a say in modernising the Constitution.

That may seem funny, but I go back to 9 March 1966, when the question of the application of section 128 was discussed. Mr Calwell asked a question in the other place of the then Prime Minister, Mr Harold Holt. He asked:

I ask a question of the Prime Minister. Does not section 128 of the Commonwealth Constitution provide that a proposed law for the alteration of the Constitution shall be submitted to the electors in each State not less than two nor more than six months after its passage through both Houses of the Parliament ? Is not the Government, in abandoning the referendum to have been held on 28th May, flouting not only the mandatory provisions of the Constitution but the clearly expressed wish of both Houses?
Those were the words of the Leader of the Australian Labor Party at that time. I think that my proposal was slightly more moderate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read out the answer. What was the answer?
—I will now read the response of the then Prime Minister to that question and honourable senators might compare it with the Attorney's response. The then Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government examined the legal position very closely before coming to the decision that was recommended by me to the House last night and to which public reference was made some time ago. I can assure the honourable gentleman that the advice of our own legal authorities was to the effect that it was within the competence of the Government to refrain from the issue of the writ.

In other words, he gave a reasonable and straightforward answer to a question. We could have got one also from the Attorney-General. I refer the Attorney- General to The Constitution of the Commonweatlh of Australia Annotated by Lumb and Ryan, with whom I know the Attorney disagrees. Nevertheless, they are two reasonably eminent constitutional lawyers. Their comment on the 1966 action was:
The propriety of the earlier non-submission is open to criticism.

In other words, they saw at least a doubt there. The Attorney, wanting to engage in his childish operations, would not even address himself to the issues which are genuinely raised by this debate. We have before us a relatively simple proposition which, if put in other than these terms, may not find favour even with Labor Party supporters. I think that essentially the existing proposal illustrates the paternalism of the approach which has to be taken to get this operation to ride. The Attorney-General and possibly the editors of the Australian Financial Review and of the Age, and others who join with the Attorney, believe that the electorate consists of numbskulls who do not know what they are doing when they vote on a constitutional matter. To fix that problem the Attorney-General proposes that we should, by a series of operations, spend a great deal of money to bludgeon the electorate into accepting that he is correct. It is a technique which doubtless goes down well in the Caucus but I suggest it is a paternalistic operation in regard to the electorate. The electorate is quite able to make up its own mind, as it has done on many occasions. I believe it is an impertinence and paternalistic to say that the Attorney-General is the only one who is right on this issue and that therefore he ought to be allowed to spend the extra money becuase everybody else is wrong and they have to be taught their lessons.

The propositions should be put in the way in which every government has ever put a referendum to the people since Federation, that is, even-handedly. It is not, in terms of the article in the Australian Financial Review, a pathetic argument. I admit there is an argument and one can argue whether it is right or wrong. But to argue as the editor of that paper did that it is a pathetic argument suggests that he knows nothing about what has happened since Federation . Every government which has ever put a referendum to the people has done so even-handedly. That seems to me to be a reasonable argument. One can then go on to argue whether it is right or wrong but at least it is a reasonable argument. I believe it is a fair and reasonable way of conducting ourselves in relation to questions put to the Australian public.

I hoped that these questions would be put. I believe, as does my Party, that additional moneys should be evenly spent on this issue. It is unfortunate that the Attorney-General has decided not to put them. I do not believe that if the referendum were held on 25 February all the questions would have been carried. However, for what it is worth, I believe that at least three or four questions could very well have been carried in an even-handed way, in a reasonable debate and in a genuine attempt to change the Constitution. The Government is responsible for taking these questions away. It is in its hands to put the questions or not as it will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make one or two comments following what the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) said earlier in the debate. One thing that annoyed those of us who voted against one or more of the proposals was the arrogance with which the Attorney-General approached the matter of constitutional change.
—It even annoyed those of us who voted for it.

—Exactly. He referred to those of us who voted against the proposals as the parliamentary rump. He said that the overwhelming majority of the Parliament was in favour of the propositions that he so vehemently put forward. I can assure the Attorney-General that many people in the Opposition parties who tacitly went along with the Yes proposition assured me that they would campaign very strongly against the proposals. There are some of us who recognise the importance of the ability of people in this place to say no to the propositions put forward so arrogantly by the now discredited Attorney-General. Not everyone in the community realises that unless someone in the Parliament goes against the proposition there would be no opportunity to present the No case. That would make the Attorney-General's life very much happier.

SPEECH.PARA: I was incensed, when I read of the Attorney-General launching the Yes campaign in Sydney and subsequently in Canberra, to learn that $1.25m had already been appropriated-I like to think it was misappropriated-from the Advance to the Minister for Finance, that Advance supposedly being for urgent and unforeseen purposes. Those of us who listened to, and studied, the Governor-General's Speech in April know that these propositions were foreshadowed, that the Government had in mind bringing down legislation for constitutional change, so there is no way in which the appropriation of $1.25m for the exclusive promotion of the Yes case would be an urgent and unforeseen matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the dates were not settled; be fair.

—I am being very fair to the Attorney-General but he has a paranoid attitude to constitutional change. He became so obsessed with it that he wanted to snow the electorate by appropriating taxpayers' funds for an exclusive additional provision with which to put before the people the Yes case. He had the confounded impertinence-actually I thought it was quite amusing-to say that the Government was getting a little bit cold on the idea of conducting the referenda because-perhaps I had better quote what, according to today's Australian, he said on the subject because it made interesting reading:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans said State Labor premiers and the Labor Party machine in the States had been unable to step in to bridge the gap that would have been left by the defeat of the extra funding.

He went on to say that the Queensland Premier intended to conduct a campaign against the proposals. I think he insinuated that the Premier intended spending Queensland's money on it. That has never been his intention. Certainly he will campaign, as he should, being the Premier of a small State, when the States House is placed under some threat by propositions advanced by this Labor Government. I am very pleased to say that the Liberal Party and the National Party Opposition in the Parliament recognise the unfairness of what is proposed and, with urging from those of us who supported the No campaign, have offered the amendment that we are now discussing. I think it is a very fair amendment. Certainly the Australian Democrats realise its fairness. I am really amazed that the Attorney-General can suggest that a mere rump of members and senators is involved. I believe that 21 members of the Senate and House of Representatives certainly do not constitute a Parliamentary rump. One must also regard the Liberal Party organisation in Western Australia as being substantially against the propositions. The Liberal Party in Queensland is totally opposed to them, as is, of course, the Party in Tasmania. I suggest that the majority of Liberal Party and Country Party supporters in South Australia would be equally opposed. I just wanted to put on record my appreciation, with that of my colleagues who are vehemently opposed to these propositions.

I might say that I started by being opposed mainly to the simultaneous elections question, because it is a furphy. The question involves not having simultaneous elections-one can have them anyway-but half the Senate being dissolved by the will of the Prime Minister, whether he happens to be a Labor Prime Minister or a Liberal Prime Minister. That is what simultaneous elections- that deceptive title-are all about. It is a matter of the Prime Minister of the day being able to dissolve half the Senate at a time which is electorally favourable to him in order to gain control of the upper House. That is what it is all about. I object to that. I objected to politicising the judiciary by asking its advice on laws before they pass through this Parliament. The Chief Justice and all the judges-even Justice Murphy-are opposed to that. It is politicising the High Court of Australia. I am very much opposed to that.

I have talked quietly about the interchange of powers. I have had my doubts. I am now totally opposed to that. I am also totally opposed to the proposition of four-year parliaments. The style of address to the electors is: 'Do you believe we ought to have four-year parliaments?'. That is great, but the Government does not mention the eight-year term for senators. The Government wants to put a snare and delusion before the electors of Australia-even on the outmoded provisions. It might be trite to say that every country's Constitution is an historical document and that there is no harm in leaving it as such. People without a history and a heritage are people without a future, so I am opposed to that. Honourable senators opposite can call me a troglodyte if they want to. None of the propositions would make an iota of difference to the running of this country. The sooner we kick out this Government the better. The sooner we get back a Liberal-National Party government the better. I repeat: None of the propositions would make an iota of difference to the running of this country.

I am glad to see that we have persuaded the Government not to proceed with the referendum. Senator Durack said quite correctly that this business is the responsibility of the Government and the Government should not try to hive off that responsiblity to anybody else. I suggest that the Attorney-General is largely responsible for the whole fiasco and charade that has been carried on over the last few weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will confine my remarks to the message from the House of Representatives in respect of the disagreement the House has with our amendment relating to finance. I want to say very simply that the attempt of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) to use public moneys to pay for an unprecedented glossy media campaign in favour of only the Yes side of the referendum was, and he admits it, a calculated attempt to sabotage-
—Do you condemn Robin Gray for spending taxpayers' money in Tasmania?
—Robin Gray does not consult me.
—Do you condemn him in this chamber?
—I would say that his premature statement was an embarrassment to the No campaign at that stage.
—Do you condemn him for that?
—No, I do not. I do not deny the right of a State to determine what attitude it might take in respect of the matter.
—That is not a double standard?

—No, because it is a matter of constitutional powers and of the powers of the Commonwealth versus the powers of the State. I suggest to the Attorney that if Mr Burke in Western Australia felt strongly enough about the Yes campaign he might well have considered campaigning with the support of the Western Australian State Parliament. I am talking about the State Parliament. As far as Tasmania is concerned, I believe Mr Gray ought to get the approval of the State Parliament. I believe it is not a matter for the Government to determine. We are not talking, are we, about a referendum-led recovery for Western Australia? What we are talking about is an amendment which we made but which the House of Representatives refused to accept. All of this has been brought about by the Attorney-General's attempt to use public moneys to pay for the unprecedented glossy media campaign for the Yes case. That was a calculated sabotage-
—To get constitutional reform, which has been agreed upon for 10 years. Come on! Be honest about it.

—I am trying to stick to the point. That was a calculated sabotage of the careful balance given to the Yes and No cases under Commonwealth legislation dealing with referendums. On 22 November, the very day the Attorney- General made his statement, I branded it as a mockery of the fairness provisions in the legislation and suggested that the Parliament hold up the Representation Bill 1983, the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill 1983 or the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Amendment Bill to ensure that that principle of equality and fairness were upheld. Senator Evans's plan has now exploded and hopefully has sabotaged for the next 10 years any prospects of having those referendums adopted by the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise the matter of the expenditure of the money. I am amazed at the attitude of some sections of the media towards the Government's stance on this matter. I do not refer to the Australian Financial Review because I never make a practice of reading it.
—But you did this morning.

—No, I did not read it this morning. I would far prefer to read the Illawarra Mercury any day if I am looking for standards of journalism and fact in terms of politics. I refer to those responsible people in the Press gallery and the responsible journalists of this country who are not outraged by this preposterous proposition to put all the money towards one case and nothing towards the other, that is; of the extra money that is being spent. I do not know of many more outrageous suggestions put by a politician in my 23 years in politics than that put by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evens) and supported by the Government. It has been said that the Press, the media, is the Fourth Estate, the protectors of the people. It offers the kind of protection that a repressed or oppressed people can look to in the face of oppressive governments, governments that want to ride roughshod over the wishes of the people. We have a situation in which a government is putting forward a proposition to change the very document which governs our existence, the Constitution. The Government says that it will spend $1 1/4m extra on the Yes case.
—To balance up the books, which you concede is a good idea.

—I wonder what Senator Evans would say if I put to him an analogy which I think is fair. Let us assume that a State government decides to fluoridate its water supply and that it is necessary to change the constitution of that State for that to be done. Let us assume that all politicians of all parties in that State agree that the water should be fluoridated.
—And they would be right.

—Senator Evans says-I thank him for walking into the trap-'and they would be right'. Senator Evans ascribes to politicians a monopoly on wisdom that I do not. On many occasions politicians have been wrong on fundamental issues and ordinary people have been absolutely right. If he thinks that simply because there is substantial agreement among politicians in this place, that simply because they voted to have a referendum, that justifies spending none of the extra money on a No case, that is a rather queer sense of humour and logic. To use the analogy I gave, what would he say if the State of Victoria spent $10m on the Yes case to fluoridate the water supply and said: 'We will not allow any money to be spent on the No case'. What would happen?
—You would probably need to do that to beat the fruit cake brigade on fluoride. You really would.

—There we are. A judgment has been made that anybody who disagrees with the fluoridation of water is in the fruit cake class. Why are they in the fruit cake class? Because Senator Evans says they are. I wonder why the media does not grasp hold of the outrageous concept that is being put forward-as my friend, Senator Macklin, says-for the first time since Federation. Let us assume that we needed a referendum to approve the export of our uranium. Let us assume that all political parties in this place agreed that uranium should be exported. Would Senator Evans then say that therefore there is no need for money to be spent on the No case? That is a logical extension of his judgment. As it happens now, the Australian Democrats-I will not canvass the argument about uranium now- is the only political party in this whole Parliament that opposes the export of uranium. If one takes Senator Evans's point, it means that five members out of 180-odd members of this Parliament oppose the export of uranium. Following Senator Evans's most generous concession, if $20m were to be spent on the referendum about exporting uranium, only five one-hundred-and-eightieths of that money could be devoted to the No case because the politicians, in whom there seems to reside a monopoly on wisdom, according to Senator Evans, have said so and that makes it right. What an outrageous, preposterous suggestion he makes.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to changing the Constitution, I take a rather absurd example, but one that might strike home to some people. Let us assume that we needed a change in the Constitution to make the salaries of politicians exempt from taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —There would be unanimous support for that here.

—Senator Lewis helps me by suggesting that there would be almost unanimous support for that concept among politicians. Would that make it right? If we were to go to the people with a referendum on that basis, would that mean that we should give no money to the No case?

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude with the fact of the hypocrisy of this Government. Who was it who, during the election campaign and before it, talked about real constitutional reform? It was Senator Evans. Who was it who denounced Malcolm Fraser on the several occasions when he called early elections for his own opportunistic ends? It was Senator Evans and Bob Hawke. Look what has happened. We had a very responsible, respectable, attractive package for constitutional reform. Senator Evans talks about the committee for constitutional change of which I am pleased to be a member and a patron together with Senator Evans, which proposed that package. We said it was time we stopped politicians politicking for their own political parties' ends by calling elections when it suited them. Therefore, the package called for fixed terms of Parliament of four years; a good idea.

Who voted against fixed terms as constitutional reform? Senator Evans voted against fixed terms. Now he comes into this place and says that we are not interested in constitutional reform. I just wonder about the bounds of hypocrisy to which this Government will go. After it denounced Malcolm Fraser for going to the people prematurely, we now have Senator Evans and Mr Bob Hawke on radio and television and calling Press conferences, saying: 'Now the Democrats and the Liberal Party have caused an early election'. This Government has not been in office for a year yet, and Senator Evans is talking about an early election, putting the whole economy into instability. Senator Evans thinks that he sees a cheap, nasty little issue upon which to go to the people and he cannot wait to get to a microphone or a camera and say: 'Unless we get our way on this particular thing, there will be an early election'. What does he think that does to every small business in the country, or to big business which is trying to recover from a recession?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is fantasy. I have said nothing of the kind.

—Senator Evans should listen to his Prime Minister, on every radio session that he has been on today, talking about fixed terms. On the one hand, they berate us for saying that parliaments should last for four years, but they have been in power for eight months and they are talking about an election next November. I will let the people judge what sorts of double standards come from the Government side of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the Committee for long. We have heard a couple of vintage grandstanding performances from the Australian Democrats this evening. One of the first things that Senator Macklin did was to taunt the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) by saying that he is not a great constitutional reformer. That is typical of the Democrats. Whilst probably the Opposition and the Australian Labor Party recognise politics as the art of the compromise, for the Democrats politics is the art of cuckoo-land: What they pretend may occur will occur. They have a sort of childish belief in the way in which politics can develop in the future. They had better look at why we had to ditch four-year fixed terms, or fixed terms as such. The reason is historical: One cannot get through a referendum proposal in this country when more than one of the major political parties oppose it. That is the reality. In 1977 three of the referendum proposals went through when all major parties supported them. In 1973, when the parties were split, the referendum proposals went down the drain. Again, in 1967, even with both parties supporting both referendum proposals, only one proposal got up.

SPEECH.PARA: There are not many people on the Government side of the chamber who oppose philosophically fixed terms of parliament, so honourable senators opposite should not come here bleating that we are going to the people early, or something else. The reason that we had to ditch the fixed term proposal is the intransigence of those opposite. Honourable senators opposite, in general, do not support any reform. They believed that they would rule for ever, and they wanted to be able to manipulate the election date for ever. That is the reason why we had to give it away.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you doing now? Exactly that.

—We are not going to spend $20m on a proposal that will go down straight off, and Senator Chipp knows that. He says that he has been in the Parliament for 23 years. I wonder what he has learnt in those 23 years. He must have sat here and learnt nothing from history. Senator Macklin says that we should go on fixed terms. I have explained why we cannot do that. Others, such as Senator Jessop, say that eight-year terms are wrong for the Senate. There is not much disagreement on this side of the chamber about that, because what we would prefer is four-year terms, and that both chambers come out at the same time. But the moment that one suggests that, what do honourable senators opposite do? They run a mile away from it, and then try to shoot down those proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: We had some interesting constitutional debates here a few weeks ago in which the Liberal Party gave lip service to support for these referendums. We all know that the Liberal Party is badly divided on every issue, including referendum issues. The Liberals cannot carry their own party on any of these proposals. They are a divided rabble. The Liberals on the other side of the chamber are leaderless. They cannot agree on anything. They would have gone into the referendum campaign with half the Liberals giving lip service support, the other 49 per cent opposing and Senator Withers going on a holiday. He was not going to at all. That is the situation we were facing. There is a lot of talk here about the enormous amount of money involved-$1.25m. I would not have thought that that was enormous compared with the cost of most election campaigns. Most election campaigns cost in the order of $10m. So $1.25m is not an enormous amount.

Senator Chipp went on to say that he was rather disappointed with media reaction to the position adopted by the Australian Democrats. I would have thought, first of all, that he should have been pleased that he got some coverage at last, albeit bad. The Australian Labor Party has been the victim right through the 1960s and 1970s of bad editorials. Senator Chipp knows that. The Australian Democrats have just to cop it. It is no use Senator Chipp getting up here and whinging about it. He should stick to reading the Illawarra Mercury or whatever else gives him pleasure. It is not much use coming into this chamber with made up examples of fluoride or made up examples of some other trendy issue that are just red herrings. We are addressing ourselves to whether we can improve the Constitution to make parliamentary democracy work better. Parliamentary democracy would work much better indeed--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Robert Ray from Victoria says that uranium is a trendy issue.
—Order! Senator Chipp will cease interjecting. I call Senator Robert Ray.
—Lying bastard.
—The point I am making, and I am not responding to anyone, Mr Chairman, is that--
—Mr Chairman, I ask that that remark be withdrawn.
—I ask Senator Chipp to withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw it.

—The point I am making is that democracy will be served in this country by proper constitutional reform. Senator Chipp might listen to this : The one thing on which I agree with him is that the constant speculation about whether there will be an election does this country no good in the future. But we were not responsible for putting elections for the Houses out of kilter. We were not responsible for calling an early election on 5 March this year. We did not go to the people prematurely in 1977 requiring the Houses now to be brought back into kilter. We did not go to an early election in 1975. Has Senator Chipp forgotten that? We were thrown out by the stooges opposite. The fact is that in 1963 Menzies took these two chambers out of simultaneous elections. There is no example of the Australian Labor Party being responsible for making the Senate and House of Representatives elections go out of kilter. We are going to spend $ 20m of public money on these referendums. I might point out to those listening that that includes $2 1/2m for the No case. If we are going out and facing people like Premier Gray and others who are spending public money, we believe we are entitled to spend that amount of money which is not a large amount of money.

SPEECH.PARA: In summing up, I say this about the future of referendums: Unless we can get a far greater bipartisan attitude to referendums we might be right in that we are facing no changes in the next 10 years. That may suit certain people but we do not accept the blame if we are forced to an early election next year because we cannot get simultaneous elections then. We do not necessarily want to go to an early election. But I think most people would concede that if elections for the Houses get out of kilter, we should take action. The Australian Democrats are not talking about $1.25m; they are talking about four half Senate elections held by themselves in the next 10 years and the costs associated with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —At a cost of $68m.

—The Attorney has indicated to me that at current day prices the cost would be $68m. There is no doubt that anything else which we say tonight will not change anyone's mind on this particular issue. Nothing that was said here tonight will change anyone's mind. The one thing, at least, we have been enlightened about is the sort of grandstanding engaged in by the Democrats. The sort of attack they have made on the Attorney-General has been unjustified. They will never change. They will always be in cuckoo land, in fairy land, in relation to these particular issues. I suppose this particular proposal should go to the bottom of the harbour where it belongs.
—Mr Chairman, I will be brief.
—Heaven save us.

—If Government senators had been a little more patient, a little more alert and on the ball they would not be in the trouble that they are in now, least of all the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). This Bill has been sitting in this chamber since August of this year-
—May.

—Since May, that is right. It was not as though this amendment was sitting here as some sort of ambush waiting to knock over the Government. This amendment was conceived very recently when the Government announced its intention to fund only one side of the case. The Attorney-General talks about his department doing everything instantly. If it had done everything instantly on this occasion we would not have this amendment. This amendment was conceived ten minutes before this Bill was due to come on.
—You have done your homework.

—He is damned right I have. My original amendment was to fund both sides. Surely it is impertinent and arrogant for the Government to presume that money ought to be spent on only one side of the argument. Surely if $1.25m were to be spent on the Yes case, the Yes case would be reasonably presented. Surely if $1.25m were to be spent on the No case, that position would be clearly understood. The Attorney-General suggests that most people in Australia are shrouded in darkness and ignorance and unaware of the arguments, and that that is why they tend to vote no. But to allocate money to both sides would have enlightened those people. They would have been in a position to make a judgment. But that was not to be the case. The Attorney-General wanted to ensure that the No case was submerged and smothered, that the Yes case was put and the No case censored, and that the media would not be able to-
—Were Joh and Gray going to spend it evenhandedly?

—They represent presumably the view of their States and their States invariably have voted against such proposals. If members of the community by and large in the smaller outlying States vote no, it is because they feel comfortable with the Constitution as it is. They do not have this blind passion to change the Constitution for the sake of change. They are not dedicated to having a new constitution by 1988. They feel comfortable with it as it is. I do not believe that the No case necessarily starts in front. If it does , it is because people tend to be suspicious of politicians and wonder why they want change. It is not without significance to note that it is Western Australia , Tasmania and Queensland that vote no to most proposals because most proposals seek to reduce the power of the Senate and of the smaller States, and these people understand that, which is why they vote no. I think it reasonable and sensible for the Attorney-General to agree to equal funding.
—You have got it, to the tune of $2.5m.

—Oh, come on! The Attorney-General admits that people do not read the small print. Why does he need money if he believes that they can get all the arguments out of the letter box? He knows that they cannot. He wants to distort the argument by having $1.25m spent on the Yes case to smother and submerge the No case. I put it to him that it would have been a much more sensible compromise if he had agreed to fund both sides equally. My original proposition was that we should have equal funding. But no, the Attorney-General could not have that. The fall back position that others agreed with was that there be no money. As a result of his incapacity to compromise, he has no referendums.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I wish to put a bit of balance into the shouting and the tumult. I would like the opportunity next February to support in Western Australia four of the five amendment proposals. I would like to see those four amendment proposals carried. I believe that the effect in Western Australia of the Government taking the unfair action which it has taken to tell the people in Australia that this will be a distortion and that for the first time in Australia only one side of a referendum question will be put by the government of the day, and not the other side with the same publicity glare, will be to damage the case in favour of the referendum proposals. I regret that the Attorney-General has seen fit to damage the case which he purports to represent with those proposals.

That the motion (Senator Gareth Evans's) be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On a number of occasions reference has been made in questions without notice and in statements to allegations of financial improprieties and improper conduct by officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and of the Australian Federal Police. I inform the Senate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, has received a letter dated 14 December 1983 from the Commonwealth Ombudsman, Professor J. E. Richardson, concerning these and other allegations. The Ombudsman's letter sets out the results of his investigation into allegations by Mr D. W. Witheford, an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs, against officers of the Australian Federal Police. The Ombudsman notes:

SPEECH.PARA: Matters raised by Mr Witheford have become public knowledge by reason of reference to them in the Parliament and the media. Further, Mr Witheford's allegations have constituted a source for trenchant criticism in the Parliament not only of the Department of Foreign Affairs but individual officers of that Department. Again, that criticism has attracted attention in the media. I consider it to be in the interests of the Australian Federal Police and the Department of Foreign Affairs as well as in the public interest that I provide you with a statement setting out the results of my consideration under the Complaints Act of Mr Witheford's complaint.

The Ombudsman finds Mr Witheford's complaints against the Australian Federal Police to be unsubstantiated. As to allegations alleging criminal action by officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs, the Ombudsman finds as follows:

While I did not investigate the actions of the Deprtment of Foreign Affairs, I am satisfied from my review of the reports of the Department of Finance and the AFP investigations that Mr Witheford's primary allegations did highlight a number of administrative deficiencies, but not criminal misconduct or misdemeanours. The relevant Commonwealth agencies have since acted or propose to act to remedy those deficiencies.
I table the Ombudsman's letter for the information of the Senate. I present the following paper:
Department of Foreign Affairs-Ministerial Statement, 14 December 1983.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement and paper.

I had this tabling statement with the paper delivered to me a little over an hour ago but I have not had a chance to read them very closely. I appreciate the fact that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has brought the papers into the Parliament before Parliament rises. This matter has had some renewed interest because of the further allegations made by Senator Primmer in the Senate more recently. Clearly, Mr President, the letter which has been tabled highlights the reasons why we have been concerned about Senator Primmer's more recent activities. I find at page 17 of the Ombudsman's letter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, reference to the complaints which were made in earlier debates in this place and which were apparently based on the allegations which were made by Mr Witheford, allegations which have been generally found not to be valid. At page 17 the variants of Mr Witherford's complaints are set out, as they have found expression in what the Ombudsman refers to as the Hansard debate. On page 18 the Ombudsman states:

I do not need to comment at any length on these variants of Mr Witherford's complaints. My analysis of the complaints (a) to (f) leads me to reject matters (i) to (iv) as having no evidence to substantiate them. Matter (v) is somewhat different-
He continues:
There is . . . no basis for linking (v) with any of the preceding variants-that is, as part of a general course of misconduct by the AFP investigators designed to further the alleged coverup.
The letter concludes:
If I may summarise, then, I found Mr Witheford's complaints to be unsubstantiated. This was after thorough examination of a large volume of evidence and lenthy discussions with Mr Witheford.

The point which I wish to make is that there is a very significant gap in time between the making of the allegations in the Parliament and this further and, indeed, most detailed refutation which has been tabled today by the Attorney- General. It is that sort of gap which highlights the wrongfulness of making allegations of this sort in the Parliament without having first ensured that every possible effort has been made to deal with matters of complaint outside the Parliament by the proper avenues of police inquiry, administrative inquiry, representation to Ministers and so on. For those who have been defamed in the Parliament there is a very long wait for this sort of exoneration. I do not believe that that sort of long time gap justifies using parliamentary privilege in the way in which we have seen it used in the Senate of late. I do not wish to labour the point. We have a great deal to do and the hour is late. But I thank the Attorney for introducing these papers. I think it is very appropriate that they should be brought into the Parliament now. I notice that the letter from the Commonwealth Ombudsman is dated 14 December. I think that degree of promptness is most appropriate. I acknowledge that prompt action on the part of the Government. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
