SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement concerning the cost savings resulting from the review of distribution of parliamentary papers.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

Honourable senators may recall that the Joint Committee on Publications, under the Chairmanship of Senator Archer, in its report entitled Inquiry into the Purpose, Scope and Distribution of the Parliamentary Paper Series, made a number of recommendations concerning the free distribution of principal parliamentary publications, excluding Hansard.

In their response to the Joint Committee's report in November 1979, the Presiding Officers accepted the recommendation that the free distribution list for principal Parliamentary Publications be revised.

The Joint Committee on Publications was advised last year that the first part of the review, that part concerning Notice Papers, Journals, Votes and Proceedings and Bills had been completed and resulted in savings approximately $ 75,000 per year through a substantial reduction both in the quantity of documents distributed and in the number of addressees.
The Publications Committee was recently advised by the Presiding Officers that the second and final part of the review concerning the distribution of Parliamentary Papers has now been completed.
This review resulted in significant savings through a reduction of the number of free Parliamentary Papers issued, by approximately 54%.

Reductions in print-runs have already been effected and the estimates provided by the A.G.P.S. indicate that, in 1982 terms, the revised Parliamentary Paper distribution will result in a saving of over $215,000 per year.
The complete review has resulted in overall savings in the order of $300,000 per year.

The Joint Committee on Publications has also been advised by the Presiding Officers that the distribution of Parliamentary Papers and the other Publications will be kept under review on a regular basis.

As Chairman of the Joint Committee on Publications I would like to place on the record the Committee's appreciation of the co-operation of the Presiding Officers in this matter and of the officers of the Department of the Senate and the Department of the House of Representatives who have undertaken the work of this review.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Northern Territory Criminal Code-Presentation of Petitions

PROCTEXT.PARA: Northern Territory Criminal Code-Presentation of Petitions
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. On 18 November a question was asked of the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, regarding the Northern Territory Criminal Code and he spoke at some length in answering the question. At the same time he tabled a letter written by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and addressed to Mr Paul Everingham, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. In that letter the Prime Minister indicated several concerns regarding the Northern Territory Criminal Code. The letter, which was tabled, caused some considerable comment once the media took it up. The matter has been debated at some length. Today a letter has been sent to the Hon. Bob Hawke, the Prime Minister of Australia, from Paul Everingham, the Chief Minister. It is a lengthy letter regarding the Prime Minister's concern about the Northern Territory Criminal Code. I ask that the letter be incorporated in Hansard so that those people who are interested in the matter will be able to see the response from the Chief Minister. I would like to point out that the Chief Minister is most keen to see that the discussions between the two governments continue.

SPEECH.PARA: At the beginning of his letter it will be noted that he says:
At the outset let me say that I hope my letter will not be the end to discussions between our Governments if you consider there are areas of concern.
At the end of the letter he says:

As stated at the outset, I would not like this to be an end to our discussions on this matter if your concerns remain . . . In the meantime, a very careful watch will be kept and if anomalies are discovered proper use will be made of the executive discretion to remove any possibility of injustice arising from them.

I have taken the opportunity of showing this letter to the Minister in charge of the House at the moment, the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan), and I now seek leave to have this letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
December 15 1983
The Hon. R. J. L. Hawke, A.C., M.P.
Prime Minister
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Prime Minister
I refer to your letter of the 18th November relating to the Northern Territory Criminal Code.

At the outset let me say that I hope my letter will not be the end to discussions between our Governments if you consider there are areas of concern. Reasoned criticism as provided in your letter and as provided by Mr Woltring in his discussion with Territory officers is appreciated. Unfortunately, a considerable amount of the criticism from other sources has not been well informed and reasoned, nor, for that matter, was it forthcoming at the time when the Code was being drafted.

Having said that, I express my concern that your letter formed the basis of a political issue during the Territory election campaign. I would hope that my reply may lead to a more constructive and consultative approach.

When my Government was fixing the policy issues with respect to the Code the very grave problem of alcohol related crime in the Territory had to be faced. We have a homicide rate six to ten times the national average and an incidence of serious assault at a similar level. For your information I enclose copies of drafts and statistics prepared by the Australian Institute of Criminology relating to these matters. According to the Institute's report the Territory also has a far higher incidence of sexual assault than any other jurisdiction. Add to this fact that over 80% of violent crime in the Territory is alcohol related and you will understand that a Government that ignored these matters would be failing in its duty.

I accept that the application of the criminal laws is not the complete answer to the problem of alcohol related, violent crime. Of course other measures are needed to combat alcohol and drug abuse and you will be aware that my Government has done more than most others in promoting the awareness or alcohol abuse in the community. Considerable efforts have been made and are still being made to provide treatment to persons who are suffering from alcoholism. However, and without losing sight of that, the criminal laws must provide proper deterrence to people who will not exercise restraint in the use of alcohol and drugs and concerning their conduct when they are intoxicated. With considerable justification I feel, many people are claiming that in the past too little notice has been taken of the victim's interest and the public's right to protection under the law.

Given this level of alcohol related crime it is obvious that the anomalies that appeared in the law as the result of the rule propounded in R v. O'Connor (146 CLR 64), which a number of the judges of the court deciding that case themselves emphasised, had to be corrected. As Sir Harry Gibbs pointed out, the law would leave the community virtually unprotected against the person who kills another whilst under the complete mastery of alcohol or drugs: page 93. See also Murphy J. at page 112. The anomaly referred to by Sir Harry Gibbs has been corrected by section 154 of the Code. It would mean that a person who killed in the circumstances considered in R v. Lipman (1970) 1 Q.B. 152 (by strangling a girl when he was under the influence of LSD because he thought he was fighting with a snake) would, if acquitted of murder and manslaughter, be convicted under section 154 and liable to imprisonment for 14 years. An alternative to the provisions in the Territory Code which follows the rule in O'Connor, but with the anomalies corrected, would be to legislate for the ''Majewski'' rule (1977 A .C. 443). This would have brought the Territory Code into line with the Queensland Criminal Code and the Tasmanian Code. However, the effect of this would have been to deny to an accused person a defence based upon intoxication when the offence charged did not specifically include an element of intention.

You refer to discussions between Mr Woltring of the Attorney-General's Department, Mr Sturgess of the Queensland Bar and Mr Conran of the Territory Department of Law. You would appreciate, as I understand was noted at the time, that any final decisions relating to the Case would be matters for the Government and that no assurances could be given.

With respect to amendments to section 383 or its replacement, that will be considered after my Government has had the opportunity to see how things work in practice. Section 383 addresses another anomaly that appears as the result of the rule in O'Connor. The rule also would exempt from criminal liability anyone who has damaged or destroyed properly whilst under the complete mastery of alcohol or drugs. Sir Garfield Barwick recommended a new statutory offence to deal with the situation: p. 87. Much the same matter was also considered in the Butler Committee's report on mentally abnormal offenders where similar recommendations were made: Cmnd. 6244, Chap. 18.51 et seq. My Government considers that the problem may be able to be met by calling on the person responsible for drunken conduct that leads to damage to or destruction of property, in proper circumstances, to pay compensation to the victim and even the community that has to bear the costs of the prosecution of him. You should understand that section 383 is on trial, as it were, and if it should appear that this section does not provide a satisfactory answer to the problem, then the advice of Sir Garfield Barwick and Lord Butler may be acted upon.

Mr Woltring raised the matter of a discretionary life sentence for murder in the case of a convicted child. It was taken up immediately and a suitable provision was included in the Juvenile Justice Act (section 39 (2)) passed by the Legislative Assembly during its October, 1983 sittings. Contrary to the belief held in some quarters, the Territory government is willing to consider reasoned criticism of the Code.

The criticism of provisions dealing with the control of sexual instincts again is a matter that will be considered when the operation of the Code is reviewed next year, but I do not consider it to be a matter requiring urgent attention at this stage.
I now propose to deal with more specific matters referred to in your letter.
1. Intoxication-''Reversal of Onus''

I assure you that the principal draftsman of the Territory Criminal Code Mr Sturgess, is well aware of the decisions quoted by you and their implications. He needs no instruction in that regard. As I stated earlier, unless the anomalies were addressed, my Government considered the rule expounded in O' Connor's case inappropriate in the Territory. Mr Sturgess was given firm instructions in this regard.

You criticised the presumption and state it has no place in the criminal laws of Australia. Section 7 (b) creates a rebuttable presumption and, in the view of Murphy J., represents existing law: O'Connor pages 114-147. So far as my Government is concerned it also makes good sense. It only applies when the prosecution has proved conduct, i.e. activity the accused person has ''lead'' himself to engage in the natural and probable consequence of which is the proscribed act or event. It is, as Murphy J. pointed out, a ''practical intellectual instrument''. One also must understand that in today's times and given the ready availability of drugs, it is very easy for a person, who is spoken to for the first time about an alleged offence some days after the happening, to claim falsely that he was, at the time in question, ''high'' on drugs and that it is a very difficult, often impossible, task for the police, with their limited interrogation powers, to refute. My Government believes that this is a perfectly sensible and just law: if a person is proved to have engaged in conduct, the natural and probable consequences of which is that he will kill or injure and he does so, and his only excuse is that he was too intoxicated to know that that would happen, it is for him to persuade the jury or the magistrate, on the balance of probability, that that, in fact, was his condition . My Government does not accept that this will present some impossible task to him. If, in truth, he was in such a condition that he can remember nothing of the occasion the subject of the charge then he can say so. He can also give an account-it will probably be fragmented, but this will increase its credibility- of when he began to drink and when and with whom, or in the case of drugs, the drugs he remembers taking. The knowledge of all such matters, usually, will be peculiar to him.

I do not agree with your comments in relation to the presumption of innocence and fair trial guaranteed by Article 14 of the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights. In relation to Article 14 (2) the report made by Australia to the Human Rights Committee had the following to say (paragraphs 249-250):

''It is a fundamental precept of the Australian system of administration of justice that an accused person is presumed innocent until proven guilty. The prosecution in criminal trials has the persuasive burden of proof and must prove its case ''beyond reasonable doubt''. Where a defendant has a defence available to him, he must produce evidence of it, but except in the case of the defence of insanity and reasonable mistake of fact (where his burden of proof is persuasive and he must prove the defence ''on the balance of probability''), the standard of proof is evidentiary only.

''This common law rule has been displaced by statutory provisions that shift the evidentiary burden of proof to the accused under certain limited circumstances. Such provisions apply only in situations where it would be extremely difficult for the prosecution to prove facts known to the accused, and where it is considered that the interests of the public outweigh the interests of the accused (e.g. presumption under the Prohibited Drugs Legislation that the possession of certain amounts of a prohibited drug is possession for the purposes of sale or supply to another person, unless the contrary is proved). The provisions referred to do not reverse the presumption of innocence-they make the existence of certain situations, which are first to be proved, presumptive evidence of guilt only. The burden of proof in these circumstances is the civil standard of proof ''on the balance of probability'', i.e. a lesser standard that the proof ''beyond reasonable doubt'', which applies to the prosecution''.
2. Intoxication-''Aggravation of Penalty''
I have already dealt with a number of the matters you raised in this section of your letter and I shall not repeat them.

Section 154 has, as it were two functions. First, it removes one of the anomalies created by O'Connor. This has been discussed. Secondly, as the result of section 31 inadvertent negligence, however gross, is excused. Were it not for section 154 the very drunken motorist who kills or injures, unless he sees the risk and deliberately runs it, would be exonerated. In other words, to give the totally subjective flavour to section 31 that has been given, section 154 becomes necessary in order to proscribe seriously negligent behaviour. The section recognises a number of aggravating features one of which is intoxication . Where or not in the circumstances of a particular case intoxication, in fact, will lead to an increase of penalty is entirely a matter for the sentencing judge. In practical terms it all means that the drunken motorist who, through gross negligence, has killed a number of persons will face one charge in which the maximum penalty is 14 years. It is not without interest to note that in Queensland section 328A of its Criminal Code (dangerous driving) has been amended to provide that intoxication is a circumstance of aggravation that adds two years imprisonment to the maximum penalty. Also, the sentencing policy of the courts recently has seen an increase in the sentences imposed upon the drunken motorist. In Queensland again, the Court of Criminal Appeal recently increased the sentence imposed upon a drunken motorist who had killed two persons as the result of ignoring red traffic lights by increasing his sentence to 10 years imprisonment.

You quoted Muirhead J in Jabanunga's case. We could trade quotes for ever. One of the isues that most concerns me is the protection being afforded to members of the community from persons who commit these violent acts. Particularly, I am concerned with the plight of Aboriginal women who are, most often, the victims of violent behaviour by Aboriginal men. The Territory has seen too much of this type of violence. I refer you to page 25 of the transcript of Jabanunga's case where the trial judge had this to say: ''. . . speaking for myself, I would not be prepared to pat them on the head and say 'I do not think this will happen again' because I am beginning to wonder whether we are giving any protection to Aboriginal people''.
3. Abolition of Dock Statements
I have already discussed this matter with the Law Reform Commission and I can do no better than quote exactly what I there wrote:

''With respect to the abolition of unsworn statements, you will be aware of all the arguments both for and against their abolition. The decision to abolish unsworn statements from the dock was taken in light of all those arguments and also in light of the infrequent use of unsworn statements in the Territory. In making this decision the Territory is now brought into line with the majority of common law jurisdictions throughout the world. I note, in particular, that unsworn statements have been abolished in Queensland and Western Australia where there is a significant Aboriginal population and it has not been suggested that this has resulted in injustice. I am sure if one were to suggest that unsworn statements be introduced in those jurisdictions, the call would be rejected.

''I understand the argument that Aborigines, especially traditionally oriented Aborigines, may have difficulties in giving evidence in criminal trials. This argument can, of course, be extended to include migrants and, indeed, any persons who have difficulty in expressing themselves clearly. I consider, however, adequate protection can be afforded to defendants who subject themselves to cross-examination. Indeed, the judges of our courts in the Territory have shown particular solicitude in that regard.

Further, I had faith in the jury system and believe juries are quite capable of making a proper assessment of a defendant and appreciate and allow for the difficulty some defendants face in giving evidence. Finally, the fact is inevitably stressed by both counsel for the accused and trial judge, as should be the case.

''In addition to those matters, the Government in making its decision also considered that on the infrequent occasions such statments were made in the Territory, they were often abused, not by people who may have difficulty in expressing themselves clearly, but by defendants who were more than capable in their control of the language. My Government is not just concerned with the abuse directed towards the police; it is particularly concerned with attacks on innocent victims of crime and innocent witnesses. You will appreciate that as an elected government we must consider all relevant matters. In this instance, my Government has chosen to abolish the unsworn statement. I appreciate your views, but in this regard my Government must disagree with you.''

You refer to the Anunga rules. I do not accept this as a good analogy. The Anunga rules are guidelines provided by the court for the police when interrogating suspects. Police interrogations are quite different from interrogations conducted in the courtroom under the supervision of a judge. You would also know that the trial judge has the power to prevent and control cross- examination.
4. Mandatory Life Sentence

I have provided you with details relating to the Territory's violent crime statistics. My government considered this issue very closely, but in the light of those statistics a discretionary sentence was thought inappropriate. It was decided that murder must be deeply stigmatised and set apart from all other offences.

In relation to this matter there are two possible approaches. One is to provide a discretionary penalty; the other is to provide certain defences that will reduce murder to manslaughter and retain the mandatory penalty. In the Territory we have chosen the latter approach, hence the defences of provocation, diminished responsibility and coercion. Such defences provide, I believe, a degree of compassion not generally available in other jurisdictions. They show compassion for the beaten spouse, compassion for the tribal and non-tribal Aborigine and compassion for the provoked. Such persons will not bear the stigma of a murder conviction. I consider that to be important.

You express concern in relation to Aborigines convicted of murder where there may be a customary or tribal basis for the act. The defence of coercion was deliberately fashioned so that the Aboriginal pay-back killing can be treated as a manslaughter. The Attorney-General has made a number of clear statements to the effect that in such matters it will be recognised that a defence of coercion exists and the charge will be manslaughter.
As to the defence of diminished responsibility let me again quote from my letter to the Law Reform Commission:

''In 1981 a Queensland case in which a young Cape York Aborigine, Alwyn Peter, killed his girlfriend when drunk attracted considerable national publicity. The defence intended to raise diminished responsibility, but at the last moment the prosecution accepted a plea of manslaughter. However, much of the information that would have been used to support the defence was then used in the proceedings relating to penalty. The persons giving such information were distinguished in the fields of anthropology, transcultural psychiatry, psychology and social science. My reason for mentioning this case is that it showed in a very public way the utility of the defence of diminished responsibility in the case of an Aborigine who has killed when he is drunk and depressed''.

Generally, in relation to punishment, I draw your attention to the provisions of section 392 of the Code which, so far as I know, are unique in Australia. Any person convicted of any offence other than murder, in appropriate circumstances, may be discharged without record of conviction.
5. Attempted Suicide

Your comments on this subject disappoint me. It has been clearly announced that the purpose of this offence is not to prosecute people who attempt suicide. It is there to protect them. It is a serious error to suggest that every person who says he is going to suicide is mentally deranged. To start with, not a few of them are merely making a gesture, but at the time it is not easy for those who have to deal with them to discriminate between those who are making the gesture and those who are not. Then there are those who are quite sincere in their intention and who are perfectly sane and, in fact, in possession of a good reason for ending their lives. I believe that in all cases where people announce an intention to commit suicide the community rightly expects the police to step in and do something about the situation. The police have to be equipped with adequate powers to do so and they also need to have the power to subdue and detain. There are many lonely places in the Northern Territory that are far from medical assistance. For the same reasons other jurisdictions also have created an offence of attempted suicide. It is simply untrue for anyone to allege that in enacting this offence my Government was minded to punish people who would attempt suicide. It is all designed to protect those persons. You have my word that so long as my Government stays in office there will not be a prosecution for attempted suicide and I do not believe that any other Government of the Territory will act differently.
6. Terrorism and Proscribed Organisations

First, if there is a Commonwealth law to deal with an act of terrorism that is the end of it; it will be dealt with by that law. However, there are acts that are not and cannot be the subject of Commonwealth law. An example would be if a person threatened to set off explosions in public places unless a demand-such as the release of a prisoner-was complied with. I cannot understand how anyone can seriously question a law that would proscribe such conduct.

You have expressed concern about the provisions of sections 51 and 52 of the Code and the use of the word ''propensity''. My dictionaries tell me that propensity also means ''proclivity'' or ''bent''. Using these meanings, for the exercise of the power given by section 51 (1) the members of the organisation must have ''demonstrated'' a ''proclivity'' or bent to use violence of a kind that causes, or is likely to cause, the death of, or grievous harm, to a person. Immediately upon the exercise of that power the Legislative Assembly must review the decision-section 51 (2) and (3). With respect, I find the concerns (I appreciate you do not suggest they are yours) referred to in the penultimate paragraph of your letter, that the provisions may be in conflict with international obligations to ensure freedom of expression, the right of freedom of association and the right of peaceful assembly, to be absurd.

It is true that no right of appeal to the courts from the decision of the Legislative Assembly is given and I would regard such a right as an extraordinary, novel and dangerous precedent. My Government believes that responsibility for action in this area, where urgent decision may well be called for, belongs with the legislature; not the judiciary.
The provisions in question were considered by the Criminal Law Sub-committee of the Law Society of New South Wales acting as a committee of the Law Council of Australia which had this to say:

''We know of no other State which has legislation covering a similar area. In principle, these provisions do not seem inappropriate and it may well be this area is deserving of consideration by other States.''

As stated at the outset, I would not like this to be an end to our discussions on this matter if your concerns remain. With respect to the criminal laws there will always be areas of difference of opinion. The production of a criminal code is a very large undertaking. My Government has been told to expect, and it does expect, that almost certainly amendments will have to be made to the Code after 12 months of its coming into effect as the result of the experience gained in that period. In the meantime, a very careful watch will be kept and if anomalies are discovered proper use will be made of the executive discretion to remove any possibility of injustice arising from them.
Yours sincerely
Paul Everingham

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the Senate for long, but I just want to refer to a matter which has been raised with my by constituents who are members of the Right To Life Association of Western Australia. Those constituents wrote to me because they had forwarded petitions to an honourable senator from Western Australia asking him to present petitions to the Senate regarding the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983. I might say I have also received a significant number of petitions from that organisation and those petitions have been lodged. This most recent batch of petitions were sent to me as the honourable senator concerned refused to present them because he disagreed with the Right To Life Association's stance on the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought it was worth raising this matter on the adjournment because the general tradition in this place as I understood it was that we did not, when our constituents sought to have us present petitions on their behalf, pick and choose between them on the basis of our views as to what the petitions contained . I have had a number of petitions sent to me, not by that particular organisation as it happens, where I have disagreed with the content. Indeed I have even had organisations write to me and say: ''Are you prepared to transmit our petitions and present them on our behalf to the Senate?''. I might say I have never sought authority for it, but it seemed to me that the apppropriate course was to accept them.

I simply draw the Senate's attention to the fact that, having now looked at Odgers's Australian Senate Practice, there does appear to be a fair body of precedent that suggests that honourable senators should present petitions even though they may have personal views and feelings which are contrary to those of the petitioners.

I refer to page 209 of, I think, the most recent edition of Odgers. I do not intend to read it. I think the statement of the principle is clear enough. The gloss that I would put on Odgers would simply be to say that I believe that, were we to adopt any other practice in this place, we could reach the situation in which substantial bodies of citizens who simply could not find a senator who agreed with them could be denied their constitutional right to petition this Parliament. I do not think any senator would in fact put constituents in that situation, but I do think it is undesirable that the practice we have had in the past of presenting petitions on behalf of our constituents, without identifying ourselves necessarily with the views of the petitioners, is one that we should seek to uphold. I raised this matter on the adjournment so that that practice and that particular statement of past Senate practice is drawn to the attention of honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe I am the senator to whom Senator Chaney referred. I believe that because someone from his office this afternoon indicated that Senator Chaney might raise this matter on the adjournment. I thank him for that politeness. What he did not do, and what that person from his office did not do, is seek an explanation of the circumstances. I think if that explanation had been sought it would have satisfied Senator Chaney and this matter might not have arisen. But since it has risen in these terms I would like to make a few comments on it.

SPEECH.PARA: I have taken my responsibilities here as a senator very seriously, and as a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Standing Orders I do not in any sense shelter from any potential argument about the Standing Orders and procedures on the ground that I may be a novice senator. All honourable senators are equal whether they are experienced or not. I think that that has to be said because I do not in any sense pretend that it is because of inexperience or any other actions on my part that I did not immediately present the petitions that were lodged with me. It is my view that any person or organisation properly constituted in Australia that wishes to address itself by way of petition to either House of the Parliament should be able to do so by way of petition. That is a fundamental right. I too have looked at Odgers's Australian Senate Practice , and that view is repeated in the expressions of several distinguished previous senators and/or constitutional lawyers. It is a right that I accept and, in fact , believe is fundamental.
On this occasion, however, the Right to Life Association of Western Australia wrote to me on 28 October and enclosed a petition which it asked me to lodge in the Senate. The Association went on:

We believe the Sex Discrimination Bill is an obnoxious piece of legislation after receiving advice from our legal counsellors and ask you to oppose it on the grounds of the dangerous implications which will certainly flow from it in its present form.

That letter was signed by Peter O'Meara who one presumes is a properly constituted officer of the Right to Life Association. I wrote back on 12 November returning the petition to Mr O'Meara. In my letter I said:
I write to acknowledge receipt of your letter and petition concerning the Sex Discrimination Bill.
As I am a firm supporter of this piece of legislation, I suggest that you lodge your petition with a Senator or Member whose views are more in accord with those of your organisation.

I wrote that letter not to deny the Right to Life Association or Mr O'Meara the opportunity to lodge the petition but because I believed that since the Right to Life Association is well known to me and me to it, and Mr O'Meara to me and me to him, it would be more consistent if the Association lodged the petition with an honourable senator who was more sympathetic to its cause. I did not decline to lodge the petition; I simply suggested, in terms of the letter I read into the Hansard, that it might be lodged through some other source. I think that is an important distinction. If the Right to Life Association wishes me to proceed with the lodgment of the petition it should refer its petition back to me and I will see that it is lodged properly. However, I think that it is somewhat odd, given our public positions, that the Association should seek to lodge its petition through me. It would be more appropriate and compatible to the Association's organisational aims and philosophy if the petition were lodged through someone else who was more appropriate. However, in public life one understands and expects that these things may occur. I think when they do it is reasonable for honourable senators to suggest an alternative course. If an organisation wishes to persist it is reasonable that honourable senators should proceed in accordance with its wishes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kilgariff raised some matters concerning correspondence between the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Everingham, and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I will make sure that Senator Kilgariff's views on these matters are made known to the Prime Minister. Senator Chaney raised the question of whether senators had an obligation of some kind to lodge any petition which was presented to them by a constituent. Senator Cook, in reply, made clear that he was aware of the convention in this respect but that he took a particular course of action for reasons which he outlined to the Senate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 4 October 1983 :

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Aviation aware of problems involving Trans Australia Airlines' excursion 45 scheme where computer failures have caused people to miss out on seats despite the fact that seats are available.
(2) Will the Minister investigate this matter to ensure that the scheme is operating effectively and efficiently.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) TAA has advised that the airline has no record nor any reports of computer failures causing excursion 45 booking requests to be rejected while registrations are still open. Traffic results indicate the booking system is operating smoothly but in the light of the honourable senator's question, TAA has intensified its monitoring system.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 12 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the current area, in hectares, within Australia of both native forests and other native tree plantations capable of being harvested.

(2) Does the rate of harvesting of these trees compare with the Australia-wide programs for replanting and if not, what is being done to ensure that our timber resource is not being eroded more quickly than it can be grown.
(3) What is the current area, in hectares, within Australia of both non-native forests and other non-native plantations capable of being harvested.

(4) Does the rate of harvesting of these trees compare with the Australia-wide programs for replanting and if not, what is being done to ensure that our timber resource is not being eroded more quickly than it can be grown.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The area of productive or potentially productive native forest in Australia is currently estimated as 40.8m hectares of which 15 million hectares are managed for wood production. Native tree plantations or Araucaria and Eucalyptus species amount to 85,000 hectares.

(2) Yes. The harvest rate of native forests is currently of the order of 10.5 million cubic metres per annum, indicating a removal rate of 0.7 cubic metres per ha/annum from forests managed for wood production. The current removal rate is lower than the growth rate of native forests. The mean annual increment of managed native forest in Australia which includes reforestation and natural regeneration is in excess of 1 cubic metre per ha/annum. The moist eucalypt forests like alpine-mountain ash and karri show growth rates in excess of 6 cubic metres per ha/annum.
(3) There are no exotic forests in Australia. Exotic plantations mainly of coniferous species amounted to 736,149 hectares as at 31 March 1982.

(4) Yes. The harvesting rate of exotic conifer plantations is currently four million cubic metres per annum anticipated to increase to a capability of about 23 million cubic metres per annum in the year 2020 based on the current annual plantation rate of 36,000 hectares and average growth rate of 16 cubic metres/ha /annum.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 18 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Government intend to pursue and support the aerodrome local ownership plan with a view to transferring as many airports as possible to local owners.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following reply to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: It is the Government's intention to pursue and support the aerodrome local ownership plan (ALOP) with a view to transferring as many aerodromes as possible to local authorities. However, acceptance of ownership of Commonwealth aerodromes under the Plan will be voluntary and on a mutually agreed basis and the ALOP cost effectiveness is currently under review. The result of that review may affect the future direction of the ALOP.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 18 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: At the time of commencement of the airport local government ownership scheme, how many airports owned by the Commonwealth were eligible to be transferred to local ownership.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: At the time of commencement of the aerodrome local ownership plan in 1958, 116 aerodromes owned by the Commonwealth were assessed eligible to be transferred to local ownership. The number was subsequently increased to 152.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 18 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Since the commencement of the airport local government ownership scheme, how many airports have been transferred to local ownership.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Since the commencement of the aerodrome local ownership plan 105 aerodromes have been transferred to local ownership. Of these 81 remain as licensed aerodromes participating in the plan. The balance were either re-classified as authorised landing areas at transfer, or were de-licensed since transfer and hence no longer participate in the ALOP, or are not presently eligible for grants under the plan.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 18 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many local ownership applications since the commencement of the airport local government ownership scheme have been rejected.
(2) Which ones are they and for what reasons were they rejected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Negotiations between my Department and local authorities regarding the transfer of Commonwealth aerodromes, or the entry to the aerodrome local ownership plan of aerodromes developed by local authorities, have lapsed at various times over the 25 years in which the plan has operated, generally due to a loss of interest by the local authority or to the inability to reach mutual agreement between my Department and relevant local authorities regarding operating arrangements and justifiable works expenditures.

There has never been a rejection of an ALOP participation submission by an eligible local authority on grounds other than the inability to agree works for which the Commonwealth would provide grants, that is, to agree that the aviation need for the works has been demonstrated and the association expenditures justified.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 18 October 1983:

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Based on aircraft movements and excluding the capital city airports, 11 of the 20 busiest airports are not now under local ownership. In descending order of aircraft movements they are:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 3 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Communications aware that a racket involving the sale of imported and illegal telephone equipment has been flourishing on the Gold Coast, aided by the fact that many consumers failed to identify false approval stickers attached to the equipment.

(2) Has the Department of Communications, or Telecom Australia, taken measures to ensure that approval stickers on telephone equipment offered on open private sale are impossible, or at least difficult, to forge.

(3) Does the Minister consider: (a) that such measures are worthwhile; and (b) that advice on correct identification of authorised approval stickers be sent to consumers with telephone accounts to minimise the extent of communications interference from sub-standard instruments.
(4) Are consumers who, unwittingly or otherwise, purchase illegal telephoe equipment liable for a penalty; if so, what is the penalty.
(5) Have any Telecom technicians been involved in the installation of unapproved telephone equipment on the Gold Coast or are these instruments being installed by owners to avoid detecion.
(6) Does owner-installation of telephone instruments constitute an offence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice received from the Department of Communications and the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, the Department of Communications issued a Press Release on 28 October 1983 drawing attention to the fact that unapproved cordless telephones were causing serious interference to telecommunications in the Gold Coast area and that persons buying a cordless telephone should ensure that it is a type approved by both the Department of Communications and Telecom.

(2) and (3) (a) Telecom requires that suppliers shall attach to a permitted telephone in a prominent position a metallic Mylar plate of dimensions 40 mm x 25 mm. However, there is no cost-effective or fool-proof way of ensuring that permit stickers cannot be forged.

Nevertheless, Telecom is concerned with the number of non-approved telephones available, particularly from the viewpoints of the electrical hazards to the public and its staff and the detrimental effects on the performance of the telephone network. This matter is being considered further by Telecom and the relevant departments. The banning of non-approved cordless telephones has been under separate examination by my Department and Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations, prohibiting the import of cordless telephones which do not meet Telecom standards, are in the process of being drafted.

(3) (b) A bill insert called Telecom Topics is used by Telecom to draw attention to the need for customers to ensure that telephone instruments offered for sale have a Telecom permit identification. The matter is also drawn to the public's attention by the use of press advertisements and brochures which are available from Telecom business offices. Telecom is not aware of any cases where false Telecom approved stickers have been used.
(4) No. However, Telecom has the power to prohibit the connection to the telephone network of private equipment which does not meet its specified standards.
(5) Telecom is not aware of any of its technicians being involved in the installation of unapproved equipment.

(6) Owner-installation of telephone handsets is permitted if the equipment has a Telecom permit authorising owner connection or is purchased from the Telecom sale telephone range. Standard Telecom rental telephones may only be installed by Telecom staff. As mentioned, Telecom has the power to prohibit the connection of unauthorised instruments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 14 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Prime Minister still agree with an article he wrote for the Courier Mail on 8 September 1977 which states in part: 'I would hope in the next few weeks to convince . . . the people of Australia and the Government that the A.C.T.U. Executive decision to seek a referendum on the uranium issue is the overwhelmingly proper course to take . . . We are saying that the people should speak'; and also stated that he could see no argument for refusing to hold a referendum on the uranium issue.
(2) Does the Government have any intentions to poll the views of the people of Australia on the issue of uranium mining at a referendum.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The article to which the honourable senator refers appeared under quite different circumstances to those which now prevail. At that time, the Fraser Government had undertaken to allow wide public study and debate of the second report of the Ranger inquiry before making decisions on the uranium industry. Yet within weeks of public release of the report that Government proceeded to make decisions on new uranium contracts. In the ensuing six years Australia's involvement in the uranium industry has developed as have our international commitments. There has now been extensive public discussion of the issues and the weight of public opinion is decidedly in favour of development and export of uranium for peaceful purposes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 15 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Western Australian Chip and Pulp Co. Pty Ltd have approval to export 900,000 tonnes of woodchips from Western Australia per year; if so, when was the export quota increased from 750,000 to 900,000 tonnes.

(2) Was an environmental impact statement prepared for the additional 150,000 tonnes; if not: (a) why was one not prepared; and (b) will the Minister for Primary Industry direct the preparation of an environmental impact statement before the company is permitted to export any amount beyond the initial 750,000 tonnes.
(3) Will the Minister table a copy if an environmental impact statement was prepared.
(4) What species of woodchips may be exported as part of the additional quantity and from where are they to be derived.
(5) For what duration was approval granted to export the additional quantity.
(6) Were any conditions imposed in relation to the approval granted to export the additional quantity; if so, what are the conditions.
(7) What were the conditions under which approval was granted to export the initial 750,000 tonnes.
(8) What quantity of woodchips has the company exported each year since it began operations.
(9) What percentage of the quantity exported each year was (a) karri, and (b) marri.
(10) Has an environmental review and management program ever been prepared for the project; if not, will the Minister direct that one be prepared; and if so, will the Minister table a copy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes; the export quota was increased from 750,000 tonnes to 900,000 tonnes on 1 January 1980.

(2), (3) and (4) An environmental impact statement was not prepared, on the advice of the relevant Commonwealth and State authorities. I am advised that an environmental impact statement was not considered necessary by either the then Commonwealth Department of Science and the Environment or the Western Australia Department of Conservation and Environment because the additional 150,000 tonnes of woodchips was required to be derived entirely from jarrah sawmill residues, that is, waste that would have otherwise been destroyed.
(5) The approval extends from 1 January 1980 to 31 December 1990, the termination date of the primary licence.
(6) The following conditions are part of the company's approval to export the additional quantity.

(a) The woodchips are to be derived solely from jarrah sawmill residues defined as wastes associated with genuine sawn timber production consisting of slabs, offcuts, dockings, and boxed hearts rejected in the normal sawmilling operation.

(b) In the event of the volume of sawmill wastes available to the company yielding less than 150,000 tonnes of chips in any one year the shortfall shall not be made up by operations of a different nature without the prior approval of the Minister.
(c) The approval is not to be construed as conferring on the company in any way the exclusive right to any material from which woodchips may be derived.
(d) The approval is subject to review in the event that the requirements of existing or future wood using industries can be satisfied only by access to material currently exported.
(e) If required, summary reports showing amounts and origin of woodchips, are to be provided to the Department of Primary Industry on request.
(f) Feasibility studies on the further processing of the material in Australia are to be undertaken at agreed intervals and submitted to the Commonwealth.

(7) The company was granted approval to export woodchips in accordance with the Western Australian Woodchipping Industry Agreement Act 1969-1973 and in terms of the agreement signed between Western Australian Chip and Pulp Co. Pty Ltd and its overseas buyer. The company was also required to observe any environmental requirements arising out of the work of the inter-departmental working party on the economic and environmental implications of the woodchipping industry which it would be reasonable to require the company to take into account. No such requirement arose.

(8) It is not Government policy to reveal information which has been provided by Australian manufacturers on the basis of commercial confidentiality. However, I understand relevant statistics are published in the annual report of the authorities controlling the port of Bunbury.
(9) The proportion of karri and marri logs accepted for chipping by Western Australian Chip and Pulp Co. Pty Ltd from State forests since financial year 1976-77 is as follows:

karri marri 1976-77 34 per cent 66 per cent 1977-78 24 per cent 76 per cent 1978-79 22 per cent 78 per cent 1979-80 22 per cent 78 per cent 1980-81 24 per cent 76 per cent 1981-82 30 per cent 70 per cent

The actual proportion of karri and marri in woodchip exports would have been affected by the admixture of chips produced from sawmill residues and the quantities of logs derived from private property.

(10) This project has been considered in the past by the Commonwealth and Western Australian Environmental Authorities and the Western Australian Department of Forestry, all of which have agreed that an environmental review and management program was not necessary for either the original 750,000 tonnes or the additional 150,000 tonnes. The company's present approvals are not subject to review until 1990 which will be the next opportunity for the Commonwealth to consider its position in respect of environmental reviews under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 29 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What new authorities, committees, bureaus, or other such groups: (a) have been established; or (b) are proposed, by or within this Department, since 5 March 1983:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 29 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are people in the situation where a woman who has never owned a house marries a divorced man who has relinquished his house to his ex-wife and children entitled to a first home owners grant; if not, why not.

(2) Would the people in the above situation be eligible to receive a first home owners grant if the position was reversed and the man bought a house in his name ; if so, why does this difference exist.
(3) Will the Minister investigate this area and take measures to ensure equity is achieved in these situations so that unnecessary hardship can be avoided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Previous home ownership by any applicant involved in a home acquision and not simply following a divorce/remarriage situation, is a bar to the payment of assistnce under the first home owners scheme to all of the people joined in the application.
(2) No. See answer to 1 above. There is no difference in treatment between men and women; all partners must join in the application and each must be a first home owner.

(3) The payment of assistance in particular cases where there has been previous home ownership would require the exercise of some discretionary power to take account of the degree of hardship arising from loss of the first home, and of the amount of benefit, direct or indirect, derived from its ownership. the difficulty is that few of these factors are readily, if at all quantifiable.

The Government is very conscious of the difficult position of many people attempting to establish another home. However, the fact remains that our priority has had to be to help those who have never had the opportunity to own their own home.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 7 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why is the disability pension classified as income for those on a social security pension and not for pensioners on a service pension.
(2) Does the Minister for Veterans' Affairs consider this to be an anomalous sitution; if so will he recommend a change when the Repatriation Act is reviewed next year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The disability pension is not counted as income for service pension purposes under the provisions of the Repatriation Act. The Social Security Act does not contain a similar provision and, therefore, disability pension is considered to be income for age and invalid pension purposes.

(2) I do not intend to recommend any change to the Repatriation Act on this matter. It is my view that the disability pension should continue not to be taken into account for service pension purposes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 7 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Department of Veterans' Affairs fulfilling the Secretary's statutory obligations outlined under section 24AB (1) of the Repatriation Act; if not, why not.
(2) Under what circumstances is a medical report or a specific incident mentioned by the claimant in support of his claim not 'a matter to which the claim relates'.
(3) Are departmental medical officers aware that they are required under section 48 of the Repatriation Act to report on doubts that the condition claimed is not caused by the claimant's war service.
(4) Have departmental medical officers been instructed not to write these reports in an adversary manner.
(5) Will the Minister for Veterans' Affairs ensure that all claimants are given legal aid to help them prepare the initial appeal if the proper procedures are not adhered to.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) It is not possible to give a specific answer to the question as posed. Whether or not a specific issue is a 'matter to which the claim relates' will depend in each case on the nature of the claim and the relationship of the particular issue to the claim.

(3) Medical practitioners reporting in terms of section 48 are required to indicate any doubt concerning any matter upon which they are required to report under sub-section 48 (1). This is a wider requirement than that mentioned in the question. If the practitioner does not have doubts as to the opinions expressed, he or she is not required to say so. All Departmental medical officers reporting under section 48 have been made aware of the requirement under section 48.
(4) Yes. I am forwarding for the honourable senator's information an instruction to medical officers forwarded by the Chief Director, Medical Services, on 29 April 1982.
(5) This is a hypothetical question. I point out to the honourable senator that there is a range of ex-Service organisations providing advice and assistance to veterans lodging claims or appeals.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 September 1983, (Hansard, page 327) Senator Reynolds asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the apparent anomaly which presently prevents the Bush Nursing Association from receiving Federal Government financial assistance on the same basis as that given to the Blue Nursing Service in urban areas.

QUESTION.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The Queensland Blue Nursing Service receives funds from the Federal Government under the home nursing subsidy scheme. The Government introduced the scheme in 1956 specifically to encourage the growth and development of home nursing services in Australia. Assistance is provided directly to approved home nursing organisations by paying a subsidy based on the numbers of eligible nurses employed. It is a condition of the Scheme that the State and/or local government must also provide at least matching assistance.

In order to encourage the expansion of the organisations already in existence in 1956 it was decided that only the additional nurses they employed over and above the number employed in September 1956 would be eligible to attract subsidy . However, to ensure some equity between pre-1956 and post-1956 organisations, a two tier subsidy arrangement was introduced at the inception of the scheme and the arrangement is still effective. The subsidy rates are based on the salary rates for a domiciliary nurse and are regularly adjusted in line with increases in the award rates. Currently the rates are:
for organisations established before September 1956-$17,180 per annum for each additional full-time nurse employed over and above the number employed in September 1956.
for organisations established after September 1956-$8,590 for each full-time nurse employed.

The Queensland Bush Nursing Association, QBNA, is a pre-1956 organisation and unfortunately in the ensuing years it has not employed more nurses than the seven it employed in 1956. Consequently it has not been eligible for Commonwealth subsidy up to this time. Were it to employ more than seven nurses it would, of course, be eligible to apply for subsidy at the higher rate for the eighth and subsequent nurses. However, my Department is currently reviewing the dual subsidy rate arrangements to see if it is practicable to introduce a more equitable uniform rate of subsidy for all nurses employed including the number employed prior to September 1956. If and when such an amendment is introduced the QBNA would be able to apply for subsidy on the basis of its existing nurse numbers.
